name: Dishonored
description: Dishonored is an immersive first-person action game that casts you as a supernatural assassin driven by revenge. With Dishonored’s flexible combat system, creatively eliminate your targets as you combine the supernatural abilities, weapons and unusual gadgets at your disposal.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows Vista / Windows 7 Processor: 3.0 GHz dual core or better Memory: 3 GB system RAM Hard Disk Space: 9 GB Video Card: DirectX 9 compatible with 512 MB video RAM or better (NVIDIA GeForce GTX 460 / ATI Radeon HD 5850) Sound: Windows compatible sound card
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows Vista / Windows 7 (enhanced for 64-bit OS) Processor: 2.4 GHz quad core or better (enhanced for multi-core processors) Memory: 4 GB system RAM Hard Disk Space: 9 GB Video Card: DirectX 9 compatible with 768 MB video RAM or better (NVIDIA GeForce GTX 460 / ATI Radeon HD 5850) Sound: Windows compatible sound card

reviews.review_text: Dishonored is a true memorable game. It does everything right. You have a diverse arsenal of weapons and powers at your disposal in your story of revenge. As Corvo Attano, you put the mask of an assassin in a city tormented by chaos. Your way of dealing with problems will influence the city, since killing will take chaos to new levels or being a pacifist will get you a happy ending. Level design is well thought, so being the good guy is not impossible but rewarding, while being the bad guy is really fun. The chaotic play style is the one where you'll fully enjoy your ablities and their upgrades, but as you progress that way, things get harder, as the game adapts to you to be challenging. Assassinating your targets is fun, but handlling things peacefully is actually more attractive, as you'll deal with fascinating NPC's . If you'll take your time to explore, you'll get to know an engorssing world. Overall, this game is a gem that deserves everyones attention and while it is kind of short(I didn't wanted it to end) the score of 9.4 does it justice.
ATTENTION ALL VIDEO GAME DEVELOPERS:  Build more games like this and i will buy them from you.  That is all.

One of the most AMAZING games of all time, I have never had more fun replaying a game than in this one, the story is amazing, the gameplay is something you'll never love more in any other game it is absolutely phenomenal. It is a beautifully detailed, has multiple ways to complete each mission structure and is one of a kind when it comes to the design and feel of the game. You are able to play this completely without killing a human soul, or be a ♥♥♥♥ing barbarian.
11/10 would murder again to prove innocence

overall 9,5/10   + great presentation, awesome art style + great variety in gameplay + as a result great replayability if you want to play it a different way + the right length no matter what you hear that it is short, if you play it right and pay attention to everything 15 hours is the minimum to complete it the first time + great story driven dlcs  - stealth could be more rewarding (had to write this, since it's difficult to find any negatives)
Is Dishonored good?  'Indeed. I believe so.' 'Never doubt it.' 'Chances are very good.' 'Yes, of course.'  10/10-Guards
10/10 800 hours gameplay and still love it

Dishonored delivers on not only being a love letter to the Thief series and stealth FPS in general, but it succeeds in allowing player emergence to run wild in an array of varied, open ended levels. It\'s fun--it\'s really, really fun.
The illegitimate child of Thief and BioShock

I've been meaning to give this game a try before Dishonored 2 came out. When Bethesda announced that for a limited time you could get this game free with a preorder of Dishonored 2, I pounced on the offer. This game is really fun! The main appeal of it to me was its dynamic story; it can play out with a lighter tone or a very dark tone depending on how many people you kill.   You have a plethora of different ways to kill the enemy, as well as ways to take them down in a nonlethal manner. You can sneak up on them and put a knife in their throat, or you can put them in a chokehold and knock them out. You can blast them in the face with a shotgun, or put them to sleep with a tranq dart. You can summon a swarm of rats and watch them LITERALLY DEVOUR your enemies... or you can stick to the shadows and slip by the enemies entirely. The amount of tactical freedom in this game was staggering, both with how to dispatch your enemies and how to move through the level.   I'm trying to keep this spoiler free, but as a warning if you want the game to play out in a happier way, I highly, HIGHLY recommend you play as nonlethal as possible for the first half of the game (first 3-4 main missions). From what I could tell, the tone of the story was largely determined in that time. I'm rather disappointed with how depressing my story ended up; you are given a warning at the beginning of the game about the consequences of playing highly lethal, but I didn't take it seriously enough. I unleashed utter carnage in the first few missions and killed all of the main targets. After the first few missions I already started to see the negative effects that my actions were having on the story. I decided I needed to change my ways: the whole second half of the game I played very nonlethal, sparing all the main targets and inflicting very few casualties. But it was too late, and the story went spiralling down despite my best efforts to turn things around.  All in all I loved my time in the world of Dishonored, and am REALLY pumped for the second installment!

So far, I'm having a blast!  Loving the level designs, very open and alot of ways to complete a mission. Kinda reminds me of Hitman, Deus Ex, Assassin's Creed and Thief all jumbled into one.  I also really dig the unique art style. Cell shading-esque. Never a bad thing.  How many times have we played stealth-based games and they've been too repetitive? Too many! This one keeps it refreshing though. Try it!

'Their fate rests on your effort. On the strength of your hands, and of your heart...'  Arkane Studios and Bethesda really outdid themselves with 'Dishonored'. It's an amazing stealth FPS that'll leave you wanting more.  You play as Corvo Attano, the Empress's Bodyguard and you've just brought news from foreign land in seek of help from the rat plague that has infested the city of Dunwall. Due to unforseen consequences, you are framed and became enemy of the state, hence the title.  The story of the game is not bad, but not great either, although I love the ending that I got. Some parts are predictable while others are unexpected. I do love the fact that your actions affect the outcome of the story. I feel as if I have control over the game and not just following a scripted flow of events. Plus, making wrong/different decisions add drama and tension to the plot which makes you careful in deciding what to do next.    Visuals are smooth and well-made. It's using the Unreal Engine 3 so you'll find it somehow similar to the cartoony nature of Bioshock Infinite, but darker. I honestly prefer the atmosphere of Dunwall to Columbia, for reasons I am not entirely sure of :/ Ambience wouldn't be complete without music, and it fits very well with the visuals. It's by no means the best, but it's just perfect for the game.  Now, I wasn't really a fan of the stealth genre but 'Dishonored' made me think otherwise. It's fun, smooth and rewarding. You wield a sword in one hand and a Charm/Pistol/Crossbow/Trap/Grenades in another. It's kind of confusing to sort them all out, but once you do, it's fast and easy ^_^ Speed and silence is key, this game rewards you for not attacking enemies head-on because once you do, they will outnumber you in a matter of seconds. I love how you can play the game at your own pace, you have to go from point A to point B, but it gives you freedom how to get there e.g. Use the rooftops and go unnoticed by ground forces, or use the shadows to slide past your enemies, or explore the area to find hidden passages. You're given the tools, and it's up to you, how you want to use them.  Overall Experience: This was honestly one of the best games I've played so far. I just love the freedom it gives you in gameplay and the astounding atmosphere it sets you in. You don't need a high-end PC to play this game, it's very well-optimized and that's always a plus for me ^_^ I highly recommend 'Dishonored' even if you're not a big fan of stealth.  Tip: Explore the surroundings..... you'll find untold stories that add to the ambience of the game.

Do YOU like loading screens? Well then you're out of luck, 'cos in this game, they're more of a subliminal message flash than a loading screen. I probably didn't even get to read the majority of the loading screen tips.  A very Assassin's Creed-like game, if Assassin's Creed were capable of producing a story you actually cared about.   As predictable as the story can be   (Really, we're achieving all our goals  this  early? That seemed a bit easy, I wonder!)  , I found myself connecting with it, with Corvo, with Emily, with poor, ol' Sam. The game isn't just about calculated choices to achieve ends that I want. I found myself passionately hating certain characters. I felt disappointment when I realised I won't get to put a knife through their eyes. I felt mercy after hearing the tale of another character. And so it goes.   And if you want a bit more challenge, play through the game without killing anyone, or being detected - and not just because of the associated achievements. There's genuine focus and thought necessary to clear out clusters of enemies. Figuring out the enemy patrol patterns, best angles of approach and the timing. Heck, I probably spent a good hour clearing out one part of Flooded District, home to the Assassins. I felt genius anxiety about there being an assassin around the next corner or on the next rooftop, and very overlapping patrols/sightlines.   Overall, it's a great game with a less-than-original story that is presented incredibly well. The combat mechanics aren't the greatest if you just run around with knife and pistol, but once you start being a bit more creative, you can have loads of fun decimating piles of Watch Guards. Just do yourself a favour and reconfigure the combat controls, blocking with Mouse2, Sword attack with Mouse1 and Power/Gadget on a thumb button of preference worked really well for me.
Think you'll get your own squad after what happened last night?

In Dishonored you're allowed to choose your own path, instead of constantly being lead by the hand through the whole journey, and all your actions carry their own consequences. The locations are wonderful, the main story is rather nice overall, and it definitely has a high replay value.
My favourite stealth game, but so short.....
One of the best stealth action games i have played in my entire life! if not the best!

The first time i played this game i fell in love with the main characters and the story line. The graphics are amazing and look unique to anything iv'e ever played with many little details to give you a feel of the atmosphere. The gameplay is truely inspirational making me play this game over and over with many different options allowing you to decide how you want to play, the lore and secrets of Dunwall really give you an idea of how the developers want you to feel while playing this game, whale oil powers everything? Truely unique and original ideas by the developers have made this game feel very special and making you feel like a true hero as you take out many important figures using non-lethal ways makes this world really fun to explore, the only criticism i have is that the storyline can be hard to follow because it is SOOO in-depth so if you are playing while listening to music or not concentrating on the story-line you will miss out on a lot of the secret stuff and you will miss the entire point in what you are meant to be doing and why  Thanks Bethesda for the experiance! :D

Dishonored is becoming one of my favorite stealth games, nay, one of my favorite games of all time.  It has it all. Amazing gameplay, dialogue, story, art direction, world, level design, freedom, and replayability. The biggest strength of this game is that you can be extremely creative with how you kill your enemies or sneak around, lending itself to many playthroughs and playstyles. The amount of detail and lore put into the world is just staggering, each note and book you find only adding to the fascinating world of Dunwall and the cities beyond. As icing on the cake, the voice acting is top notch and you can always catch interesting conversation between guards and noblemen alike.  I can ramble on and on about how wonderful this game is, but you should play it for yourself. It's rare to see a game that's so well crafted in every aspect. 10/10

The game is good for at least two playthroughs. As are the DLC missions. The levels are designed brilliantly, allowing one to reach one's target in many ways. The graphics are interesting and difficult for me to describe, but I believe that they add quite a bit to the atmosphere and steampunk aesthetic that the game possesses. This charming game is well worth a buy for those who enjoy stealth or action games, as it can be played as either genre or as a mix of the two.

Dishonored is an insantly good game. It's a great combination of Deus Ex and Thief with an emphasis on magic and some great style. The world they've built is cool as hell and the lore is actually worth getting invested in. Levels are open ended and the gameplay encourages experimentation be it going violent, going nonlethal, or never engaging at all with multiple ways of completing any objective. Dishonored is fantastic.  As for the DLC, the trials are kind of whatever but Knife of Dunwall and Brigamore WItches shouldn't be missed as they're lengthy campaigns that set up Dishonored 2 really well.

Dishonored in quite possibly the most innovative and enjoyable single player game I've played since I was a kid. Why?   Corvo, the empresses bodyguard turned 'Assassin' by a group of loyalists that wish to put Emily, the late empresses daughter, in charge of the kingdom. How you do that however is compleatly up to you.  You will get missions to go Eliminate targets and you can do this by Killing them or 'Removing' them if you are the 'I can't be bothered to use stealth!' type of person you can run in there willy nilly and stab your target or you can be more creative. Poison, choking them out and throwing them into a pack of hungry rats, or using your magic to send them to the moon Or on the flipside, you're the type of person that likes stealth and to be as non-leathel as possible you can find alternitive means to eliminating your targets.  The way you play greatly affects the outcome of the story  This game is increadibly innovative. Good line of sight on guards, fun and interesting ways to kill and neutrilize people, amazing story with charaters you get attached to, combat that makes you think of how you're going to tackle groups of enemies, whilst still being a challenge to the player.  So far I've played this game through to the end 3 times and every playthrough has been different.  If you're browsing through steam for a good game to play at a reasonable price, £7.99 at the time of writing this, I highly recomend this game.
Dystopian Neo-London Hitman with super powers.

Bethesda really has done a great job on this one, you can walk through the city like a killing machine (not one the highest difficulty though). sneak over roofs and pipes. or run through sewers as a rat. kill your assasinatian contracts or let them live by marking them as a heretic for instance more difficult but more rewarding. every choice you make comes back to you in the future.  how does it end for you? does the plague take over? do you lose everything you toke as assured? or do you restore the peace and the throne of the new empress? i should say: buy the game and find out.
A better Thief game than Thief 4. 11/10 would timestop again. While you're waiting for Dishonored 2 to be fixed, play this :)

Dishonored is such a great game, and I am very happy to have finally come back to finish it with Dishonored 2 right around the corner! If you like a great story, a well built world with many places to explore, supernatural powers, stealth action, and much much more pick up Dishonored!

Even having played this on the PS3, twice on the PC already and now the DLC, I am having ♥♥♥♥ load of fun. There is always a new thing you can try, there is always a different way to combine your powers in a way you never though of. Of all the games that gives you powers like Bioshock, Deus Ex, etc, this is one of the very few which allows you to combine the powers in an organic fashion. Making the replayability of this game incredible.

Hell yes I definitely recommend this fascinating game. Rich storylines, decent graphics regarding its generation... It's so impressive how you can pick your way of doing the mission, there's no inevitable way; which is the best way to avoid repetition. What can I say... This game is exquisite!

No matter how you look at it, this game is a masterpiece, 10/10, AAA and pretty much just epic. If you didn't play or dislike this game, you're terrible at gaming in general and should uninstall Steam. The first DLC isn't too interesting, but the other 2 are great so you really should go for the GOTY edition.

Dishonored is a very good, very well put together game. Don't let Yahtzee's review discourage you (unless you also completely despise silent protagonists, binary moral choice, powerful superhuman abilities (wait, that's a bad thing?) and want more than 5-30 hours of gameplay [depending on your pace]). Besides, despite his apparently negative review, he still listed it as 5th best of 2012 (same goes for The Walking Dead, at #4). Also, the game resembles Thief, Half-Life 2, and Bioshock. That, together with the fact that it's actually pretty good should be plenty reason to play it.

It feels like a Mixtape between Bioshock Infinite and Thief. It's about revenge; armed with deadly weapons and supernatural powers, you seek vengeance upon all of those who orchestrated your downfall. It's about a city; the plague-ridden industrial port of Dunwall is lovely to behold, exciting to explore, and seething with secrets. It´s about rescueing a little girl the daughter of the murdered Queen.  The Story is very exciting and its told in a good way..not too much and not too less. So you are never bored and have to skip videos and you also know always why you do what you do. The incredible variety of ways you can engage or evade your enemies is impressively flexible and utterly captivating. The Graphics are fine. Im using an old 2 Core Computer atm..it runs perfectly smooth on it, so it got very well programmed. I didnt see any Bugs. It has easy controls and also Full Controller Support, both work perfectly fine. I cant say anything negative about this game. If you love Games like Bioshock Infinite or Thief then defenetily buy it. Its in the sales for 3,24 € and its worth minimum 20 € compared to the quality of this game, so im very pleased with it.
I didnt feel very dissed nor honored.

A solid and smooth stealth game.   A really great game the controls are great and the gameplay is amzing. story is cliche but in a good way and is done in a way that is interesting and imersive . biggest problem would be length since i like really long game but at 11-14 hrs to beat the game does have multiple endings and great reaplayablilty due the varius ways that you can appoarch missions   a must have/play for anyone that likes stealth games. looking forward to my second play through in the near future.
Tryed it when it was for 1-2 days free One of the best first person stealthy games ever, the story is cool and the steampunk buildings, machines and others are awsome
a masterpiece. awaiting the sequel...

It is kind of late for a review for this game, but after my second playthrough I think I should tell you guys how great this game is.  You play in first person in a medieval world with magic and science.  You will start a level with at least one goal, sometimes the goals change or you get more goals or you can decide which of the ways to reach the goals you want to use. Mostly it is the decicion: Lethal or not lethal. Inside the level you are free to go where you want.   You can play the whole game like DARK, you try to not to be seen, your only target is the mission goal.  Even if you do so, you can still decide if you kill at all. You WILL be responsible for dead/capture, but you can make it kind of... third parties fault.  The complete different approach is the killing spree. If you use knife, crossbow, pistol, grenades, mines and magic to the fullest extend you can do incredible cool things. You can freeze time and put a grenade in the hand of someone, take a bullet from the air, teleport behind an enemy to strangle him, send rats to eat your enemies alive or blast them against walls. You can take over a fish or another animal and use different routes, take over a human and walk him out of the sight of others, reprogram towers to kill your enemies and so much more.  So you can either play the I-do-not-kill-guy with a good ending or the kill-all-enemies-guys with a bad or at least dark ending.  Either way, the game is fantastic.  I really love the graphics, I love the music and the gameplay is very smooth and fun.  The only thing which is not so good: the character faces are... don't know.. kind of ugly. All of them.  This game is a must play. At least once!  I did 2012 the killer-guy playthrough, 2014 the ghost - not in all levels :( - playthrough and now I will have some fun with mindless killing again :)

Just finished my first completion of Dishonored. I was trying for as bloodless as possible and I had many flashbacks remembering the Thief series while playing. It's not the same game or story but being able to sneak around through a game again is so much fun. No moss or water arrows but that's good because they got to be a bit silly with that.  As it stands, you have a massive number of options for completing your objectives in Dishonored. You like rooftops? You can be Spidey. The sewers and maintenance areas feel more comfortable? Crawl away! The myriad paths and the optional side missions make some of the missions exceedingly long when you don't know the maps but they are still all enjoyable. I can see real opportunities for speed runs when you know exactly where to go but you'd miss so much of the content.   The story is well done and detailed with believable characters though the end is a bit overdone. Even many of the NPCs are almost fully fleshed out with backstories - families, friends etc. You will eventually hear guard conversations repeat simply because you encounter so many of them but it often pays to hang out for a minute and listen to the guards because they are chatting about optional paths or things you are interested in...if you hover around.  All in all, I enjoyed the hell out of Dishonored and strongly recommend to anyone who remembers Thief or the old Metal Gear Solid when it was stealth focused.
The best game since the original Deus Ex. 0ver 9000/10

Right everyone. If you havent played this game, go and play it. this is one of my favourite games in existance and i will play it for many many many many years after this. This game was an attempt to recreate thief, but became its own flushed out game that i bloody adore. gameplay is smooth, storyline is gripping and THE GORE IS BEAUTIFUL. and if you dont think the whalers are adorable you have a problem with your eyes!  buy this. 10/10 1000 points out of 1000 A* victorious.  Lets hope thief is as good.
One of my favourite games of all time. Hopefully Dishonored 2 will be like this one.

I was a big fan of the Bad Rats franchise. I'm glad they made a newer version with updated graphics and a better story. I recomend this game to anyone who loves being a rat, and seeing rats eat people. 13/7

You play as Corvo, a man who has guarded the empress and her daughter for years. Soon after you start into the game, mysterious assassin's attack and kill the empress, steal the daughter, and the guards are believed to thought you've killed the empress. Soon after, the 'Outsider' grants you all sorts of magical powers, that allow you to 'Blink' through an area, see through walls, create gusts of wind by flicking your hand, possessing an enemy, going inside of them and controlling them, summoning rats out of the ground, and a magical heart that shows you where runes and bonecharms are. Would reccomend.

The game might be short but it is intense. The story draws you in if you take your time and with so many solutions to each scenario the game has solid replayability. The ONLY thing I wish they would do is give us more.
Very good game and easy to re-play it several times!  Maybe a bit short, but you can play it in many different play-styles & enjoy it every time again.  More then worth to try it out ! 8/10 !!!
Great ambience, great story, great graphics, both stealth and high chaos play, good DLC's, etc. I only have good things to say about this game. Just buy and play. I'm on my 13th replay.

Agent 47 meets Ezio Auditore and Booker de Witt in  City 18    Again, one of my reviews:   in short  This game blends quite succesfully a  First Person Hitman  experience with the verticality of  Assassin's Creed's Ezio Auditore . There is an evolved version of  Bioshock's Plasmids  which don't just copy the BS ones. The art director is the same as in  Half-Life 2  and sadly sometimes you feel really like in a  City 17  clone a century before. Through a  Low/High Chaos  system, the game ensures that there is a stealth approach, as well as a 'standard' FPS one and provides the enemy spawns needed. It caters to the Fantasy community, but after the first 2 chapters, it is even for someone like me playable. Recommend it, if you like stealth games, though w/o frustration due to supernatural powers and blood & gore approach possibility. Recommend yes, but a 87-90 meta score would have been more than enough: Entertaining and a nice blend but nothing too special; still one of the better games, I guess.   in detail   story  Hm, personally I am not a Fantasy person and not really into empresses, mana and haunted castles, so forgive me being biased towards this game, but as mentioned, I nearly skipped the whole game after meeting the empress and all of that  Outsider 's gibberish. I collected all audio tapes (or  Voxophones ) in  Bioshock , which added greatly to the atmosphere and gave insides. Here, this abundance of audio diaries, notes and books either merely state the obvious or are simply boring ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t which is only loosely connected to the main story. Sometimes hints are buried under these tons of 'paper'. - The overall story is ok though and the characters themselves got personality, just the collectibles are hastily done. Voice-acting itself is brilliant, but the dialogues are flat but getting better towards the end. Background score is another plus.   gameplay  positive:   leaves many options and approaches   even in hardest achievement combo, w/o killing nor alerting anyone, nor using superpowers not frustrating (on  normal )   side quests are well integrated into the main story - this is a huge plus and only the  Half-Life  franchise manages that from what I played so far   few but distinguishable weapons and gadgets which I prefer over tons of the same  negative:    very short in a blood & gore approach   unlike  Assassin's Creed  not open world at all - cannot understand some comments which state otherwise.    nothing really exciting level design-wise. Get from low ground to high ground and back down again    unlike  Notes ,  Books  don't disappear after being picked up and are often double, which is a pain when leaving all cover just to find out, you already got that one. Obviously should help to collect them, but no good approach.   graphics  Really, have to be mentioned because this might be the most controversial part of my review and again, before you downvote my review for not being  helpful , please accept my personal view on this: I found the graphics unlike HL2 very kitchy and the coffin like structures everywhere were a too unsubtle reminder of the overall plague situation in  Dunwall . Besides, the citadel structures next to the  Boyle  estate made me looking for  Alyx & Dog ; sorry this was too much of copying  City 17 . Besides, and this is non controversial, the graphics also feel as dated as in HL2 and this was 10ys ago. Ok, one or two sunsets doesn't make much of a difference.  The characters lack polygones, but this is nicely compensated for by using caricature like expressions. Again, the ♥♥♥♥♥ are a disgrace like in any American video game's brothel: No ♥♥♥♥ or ♥♥♥♥ to see as usual but at least some shiny tattoos. Why is it an adult game then - nipples are worse than chopped off heads or what?   bugs/etc.  The game itself seems ok, but I had massive bugs in the Steam overlay due to failing synchronisation which caused game critical bugs (as in killing the game). Exiting and re-entring Steam helped as a workaround. Luckily, this only happened once in-game.

Dishonored is a love letter to everyone who has longed for more stealth action games in the vein of Thief. With its vast levels, openness, and its plethora of different ways of play this is a game that should be a great fit for practically everyone.

Favorite game of all time. I cannot recommend this game enough if you love a vibrantly decorated and immersive stealth game. Even with all this though, the game could have been longer. But I havent ever seen a game before that let you move as freely as this one.

Dishonored.  There is a lot to say about this great masterpiece of a game. A game you can decide how you want to compled it , as a silent or brutal killer. Or just be a stealty tactical player who finishes the game without killing someone.  The game catches you with his great atmosphere and great charakter desinge. If you play the game you´r 100% in the game and you won´t notice anything else. If you don´t want to play the game full stealth you got a big arsenal of weapons or powers to slay everything that stands in your way.  Seeing how the world corrups if you choose the way of a killer and the story changes is just amazing. A game that don´t get boring if you play it multiple times !   Story 7/10 Atmophere 9,5/10 Charakterdesigne 8,5/10 Gameplay 10/10  controls 8/10  Graphic 8/10 (for a 2012 game)  I would recomend this game to everyone who like sneeky games or just want to slaughter a few people with a huge arsenal of weapon and power. Or just people who enjoy a great dark atmophere.  -Cat

While I don't find as good as other people say, I still find it as a great game and I do have my reasons  First of all the good:  + I love the Steampunk setting + All of the weapons are useful and are fun to use, my fav being the Crossbow + Lots of powers + Fantastic weather effects + Chaos system is a good idea + Some fun levels + Runes and Bones are fun to find + Dat mask + REALLY FAST LOAD TIMES AND I MEAN FAST!  Downsides:  - Stealth has been glitchty for me, before you say your doing it wrong, I compeleted MGS 1,2 3, 3DS, 4, twin snakes and Peacewalker all on Euro extreme/hardest setting stealth, no alerts and no kills, so I know stealth. But here, guards keep popping out of no where, and dark vision does f*ck all to see them, I know it has a range, BUT WHEN THE RANGE IS 2CM, THEN WE HAVE AN ISSUE, other then that, Stealth CAN work sometimes, most of the time guards just insta spot me while I'm hiding in the shadows, so I'm forced to go in guns blazing 75% of the time.  Also smashing glasses does f*ck all, not joking, I smashed a glass in a guards face and he did nothing, didn't move, didn't attack until I walked infront of him....  - The Story is unintresting, while in the beginning it plays the obvious parent is gonna die and the child is gonna be kidnapped card, thats the only intresting thing, rest of it is boring and I keep finding myself skipping them.  - Some powers are no where as good as the others, like I mentioned Dark vision works whenever it feels like it, Blink is broken and is the only power you should use, freezing time while fun, is only good for escapes or quick kills, Devoring Storm is nearly useless, and the Wind Power is decent.  - Some cutscenes can't be skipped, while others can..... why?  - All company logos can't be skipped.... why?  Other then that, this game is a lot fun.

I originally thought that Dishonored was an open world RPG similar to Skyrim or Fallout, but it turns out that it’s actually closer to Deus Ex Human Revolution (action/stealth). Since I only had the free weekend to finish the game I didn’t try to go for all the achievements that I normally would. However, the game lets you know right from the start that the fewer people you kill, the better the outcome will be. That means no hacking and slashing like I was planning to.   In the game you play Corvo, the chief bodyguard of the empress. When the empress is killed and her daughter kidnapped, you get framed for the crime and sentenced to death. Your main goal in the game is to rescue the daughter and bring the actual murderers to justice. Since the bad guys are high up in the government, this means you’ll mostly be fighting government soldiers and religious zealots. You’re not alone in your quest since a magical being called the Outsider gives you powers that you can use to complete your objectives. The game does a lot of its background storytelling through notes and books that you run across all over the place. The Dishonored world seems to be roughly 1800’s technology with magic thrown in, resulting in a steampunk environment. The graphics are very similar to the Bioshock games (including that annoying blur effect when you walk through falling water).  As I alluded to earlier, Dishonored is not really an RPG. You don’t gain experience or level up. There’s no big reason to kill or knock out enemies if you can just sneak around them (unless you want them out of the way for exploration). Your magic powers are upgraded by finding “runes” throughout the game world. Each rune acts like a skill point that you can use to gain or improve your magic powers. The main power you’ll be using is Blink, which is a short range teleport, which is great for getting around and avoiding enemies. The magic powers are generally not “offensive” meaning you’re not throwing fireballs or shooting lighting. Generally they’re for supporting your stealth (see through walls, killed enemies disintegrate, turn into a rat). Almost all your objectives have multiple solutions. You can run through fighting (not recommended) or find various hidden paths like climbing roofs or going through small tunnels. Similar to Deus Ex, when you sneak up on an enemy you can choose a non-lethal takedown or assassinate. Then you need to hide the body since enemies will raise alarm if they find dead or unconscious buddies lying out in the open. There is also a combat system which includes guns and the sword (you can block enemy sword swings). Since I played stealth, I didn’t engage in very much combat. And since I didn’t do a lot of fighting, my ammunition filled up really fast. You can hold a small number of healing/mana potions and arrows/bullets for your weapons.   Overall Dishonored is great and well worth your time. However I wouldn’t say it’s “must play” like some others (Bioshock Infinite, Tomb Raider 2013, etc.). If you’re not into stealth games you will probably get annoyed at times when the enemy random patrols just don’t give you a chance to sneak past. I’ve read online that some people thought the game’s story was weak. It’s not amazing but not bad either. The story mostly just drives the gameplay and tells you where to go. I managed to finish the game during the free weekend a few days ago and it took roughly 16 hours, probably because I was going for no-kills and no-detection. Failed both by the way :(

Dishonored is an immersive first-person game that emphasises stealth. The game allows for different ways to approach an objective and has several different skill sets. The latter two points greatly adds to the games replayability. This is one of my favorite games from 2012. If you haven't played it, I highly recommend it especially if you can get it during a steam sale.

You can play this game like a mad men, relishing in the superb feel of the controls as you obliterate every living soul you come across by unleashing a storm of flesh eating piranha-rats, throwing baddies off cliffs or, if you’re a traditional kind of guy/gal, shooting them in the face.  But here’s the best part - You can also play the game, from start to finish, without killing ANYONE or even letting your enemies know you were there. This thanks in large part to some of the best level design in recent history.  However, there is no excuse for this game to feature a conveniently silent protagonist where you play a supposedly influential character with deep relationships and where major plot points could be averted with a simple “Nope”.
900 hours later and I'm still playing it. I suspect only Dishonored 2 can make me stop at this point.

Highly enjoyable and highly recommended. Dishonored hits stealth right on the head. Not since the Thief series has stealth felt so good in an FPS. More importantly, the game gives you options to play the way you want to. You could murder every living creature in your path, or never harm a soul. You could go in guns blazing or never be seen once. There is no strict morality system, but is one where your actions contribute to the level of chaos in the world which ultimately affects the ending and the environment around you.  The powers and weapons are satisfying, the world is refreshingly different, and the story is compelling. Wipe the rust from your whale oil powered rig and install this game.

There are a few things that make Dishonored quite compelling: The story is unique and interesting, and can have different endings, depending on your play style. You can complete your objectives however you want, whether you like moving through the shadows or charging in, whether you want to kill your enemies, render them unconscious or simply sneak past them, whether you want to use your arsenal, or your supernatural powers, or none. Besides the many missions in the main story, the DLC also provide quite a lot of new content.  Other things to be noted: The interface is nice, the keybinds are customizable.  The graphics are good, and the game does not require a fancy PC to run on. The AI is pretty smart, although, guards have fixed patrolling routes. Most achievements are unlocking without issues.  As for bad aspects: Your character interacts awfully with the environment and does not actually talk; you communicate with the other characters via text only.  Overall: 8.5/10

What I mostly like about this game are the choices. While they may not always have real consequences (mostly affecting the chaos rating of the city), they give the player the feeling of freedom.  I'm almost done with my second playthrough. The first one was magic-using sneaker, where I only killed people if they caught me by surprise. While it was quite nice, finding alternative routes and hiding all the sleeping bodies, the second playthrough has been so much better.  For a game that rewards you for being a good guy (sneaking, not killing), being a badass warrior is too damn fun. While I don't use any magic on this run, the feeling of battling half a dozen guards at once is amazing. Blink behind, stab, shoot another one to the face, lob a sticky grenade on one, blink away from explosion, lock your sword with the last one and remove his head. It is frankly quite intoxicating.   Also, seeing all the differences between different runs make you appreciate the game much more, even if the differences are small.  The fact that you can be shot or stabbed in the back while swordfighting another guard, is really good compared to Batman / Assassin's Creed type of combo-counter brawl. You have to think ahead or be ready to use your weapons, you can't just jump in the middle of a group of hostiles.  10/10 would play again (almost did already)

I just realized that I never got around to recommending this, so I'll do it now. I'm not going to try to write a review, but I want to explain why I love this game so much.  I love Dishonored because it puts me in a world filled with intricately linked systems and sets me free to experiment with them. Every item effects every other item in logical ways, producing a depth of interactivity that is incredibly deep, with combinations of systems coming naturally as you think about your environment as an actual world.  I love that Dishonored doesn't try in vain to deliver photorealistic graphics, and instead utilizes a gorgeous visual style of watercolors and caricatures combined with surrealist lighting. Where so many other games struggle for life-like detail and end up slipping into the uncanny valley, Dishonored uses a non-realistic approach that is evocative and suggestive, making every character and locale a joy to look at.  I love how Dishonored feels when I'm moving around. Every motion in the game is so beautifully smooth, from running to climbing, jumping to sliding. After playing Dishonored it's hard to go back to games where sprinting is limited and I can't jump up and grab a ledge to get over a wall. Mirror's Edge did running so well, and Dishonored surpasses it in every way.  I love playing Dishonored because of all the options I've given when approaching a situation. There are countless ways through each area and multiple solutions to each objective, making stealth and combat equally viable playstyles.  I could go on and on, but I'm going to cut this short. Simply put, it's a game that does nearly everything right. Every single aspect of the gameplay is masterfully crafted and polished to perfection. Buy this game. Buy it right now.

9.5/10  This game had everything going for it to make a great game. The developers truly gave a sometimes linear game a very non-linear feel. If you enjoyed Bioshock Infinite then this game should be on your next to play list as both of the games play very similar making your experience fun and not too convoluded. The only reason this did not get a 10/10 is because it had some annoying texture pop-in sequences every once in a while which strained my eyes, but they happened only once or twice. The game included excelent voice acting and a script that was engaging when being assigned smaller tasks or even when talking to the citizens of the city of dunwall. Overall though the game had a great stealth system rivaling that of the Metal Gear Solid franchise. Many people would say that it was basically a first person assassin's creed, but it is much more than that. The game not only discourages killing but it rewards you with less enemies the next mission and less obstacles to overcome, this makes stealthing not only fun but also more satisfying knowing that it will be even easier for you during the next mission. The dlc did not feel as if it was a waste of money. in fact it was far from that. The exploits of the master assassin Daud were just as timeless as those of Corvo mkaing it a must buy for those that own or are looking at the game. Overall this was a fantastic game and was non-stop intrigue and fun that will motivate you to keep on playing even if you get frusterated. As stated earlier i give this game a 9.5/10

Actions speak louder than words in the city of Dunwall, a cesspool of crime, corruption, and plague. Corvo Attano, the hired bodyguard for the Empress, must use everything at his disposal to clear his name and rid the city of corruption and deceit.  Dishonored has surprised me in many ways, from its unique watercolor art style to its brilliant combat system. Ultimately, the game is not what I had expected after seeing the first theatrical trailer featuring a man in a jail cell. That being said, I wasn’t a fan after the first twenty minutes of play. Eventually, I put it down and moved on to other things – after a few months, I came back to give it another try. That was when I realized what I had been missing.  I’ll summarize my thoughts about this game in a simple pros/cons list, but I will elaborate on each item.    PROS :  > Unique Art Style < The brushed watercolor style that decorates a unique city called Dunwall may initially come across as outdated and technologically inferior to other games created during the same time period. Some players may view the style with that pessimistic attitude, and some may view it as a unique work of art. I chose the latter.  > Interesting Story and Deep Lore < The story is a special experience, and your actions will matter – remember who you are and whom your actions affect. Read the books you find and drop eaves on conversations to discover the surprisingly deep backstory.  > Excellent Voice Acting < You will certainly recognize whom you're talking to, because the voice acting is consistently stellar throughout the entire game.  > Worthwhile DLC < Although they rarely see big sales, all three DLC packages are worth your time and money.  > Best Assassin Experience < There is no better assassin experience in any game. I’ll explain this below in the sections on combat and stealth.  > Brilliant Stealth < The game can be completed without ever being seen by an enemy – ever. It’s a tricky thing to master, but it is a very fun way to play the game. The player may also rush into battles with guns a’blazing and blades a’sparking.  > Combat Is Incredible < The combat system is intricate, diversified, and very expertly crafted. There are many ways to go about clearing an area (it rewards those who enter a battle with a plan of action).  This game is much, much more fun if you are creative  – trust me.    CONS :  > Game Length < I would have loved to see more, but perhaps that’s why we buy DLC. Also, keep in mind that the length of the game depends on how you play. Fast and furious will make the game shorter, while slow and stealthy will make the game longer. Both are great fun.  > NPC Animations < Corvo's actions look swift and fluid, but the actions of other NPCs seem a little repetitive, stiff, and awkward during conversations. This may take away from how much you care for characters.  > Story Vagueness < Some elements of the story are a little vague, but this is minor. Plus, it is usually fixed by digging into the lore provided by books and conversations.   I would place Dishonored somewhere among my top twenty favorite video games. It’s a worthwhile experience that is always fun to revisit. Do the right thing and buy this game, already.

Stands tall on its gameplay, visuals and setting. Disappoints with a predictable main storyline.    *Spoiler free. Combined review discussing Dishonored, Dunwall City Trials, The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches.*   I've never been a fan of the silent protagonist. Dishonored and its two DLCs, 'The Knife of Dunwall' and 'The Brigmore Witches' present an interesting opportunity to play as both a silent and a voiced protagonist within essentially the same game. The main game has you playing as Corvo Attano who has a backstory but is otherwise a blank slate for you to control. Both DLCs put you behind the eyes of Daud, an assassin that you first run in to as Corvo. It would have been jarring to suddenly strip Daud of the voice he had in the original game, so he retains it into the DLCs and, in my opinion, they are better for it.  As Corvo, you sit and listen as characters monologue at you or talk to each other. As Daud, you have conversations, relationships and motives of your own. Giving your protagonist a voice makes him or her interesting, allows for natural conversations and doesn't force the game's writers to avoid lines that would normally elicit a response. And it doesn't come at the cost of robbing players of making choices at key moments, as the DLCs demonstrate.  There are positives to get to, but let me get through one more negative first. Dishonored's primary story and characters are mostly predictable, standard fare. NPCs are limited to the aforementioned monologues that are generally kept short in favor of gameplay. Both DLCs are significantly better in this regard but don't expect RPG levels of depth. The voice acting, however, is all around excellent.  The main attraction of Dishonored is its gameplay. It's a fusion of stealth, parkour, magic, and both melee and ranged combat. All slickly delivered from a first-person perspective. Besides the blink spell (short range teleport), you are given the choice of what spells and upgrades you want to unlock first to best match your play style. There are two general play styles that result in different endings to the game: the nonlethal (often stealthy) 'low chaos' path and the 'high chaos' path that revels in death and battle. This is true in the DLCs as well. Whichever style you choose, the level design will allow you numerous ways to get around and sometimes multiple ways to accomplish an objective. Game length can vary wildly with high chaos being the quicker route.  While Dishonored's story may be lackluster, the atmosphere of the world it takes place in is wonderful. The art and sound design both excel at bringing this place to life. The soundtrack takes a more subtle, atmospheric approach that gets the job done but is otherwise unremarkable. You'll find notes and books scattered throughout the game that fill in the details of what goes on in this world. I hesitate to list this as a complaint, but there is a spell that significantly alters how the world looks for the worse but is so useful that I rarely turned it off. It allows you to see enemies through walls while tinting everything orange (similar to the Batman Arkham games' detective mode).  Dunwall City Trials is exactly what it sounds like it is: purely gameplay. No story, no impactful player choices, just arcade style pursuit of high scores. I would suggest replaying the rest of the game at a different chaos level than your first playthrough and then if you're still hungry for more, play these.   Dishonored: 7/10  --- 16 hours*  Dunwall City Trials: 5/10  --- 3 hours*  The Knife of Dunwall: 8/10  --- 6 hours, no alerts or kills*  The Brigmore Witches: 8/10  --- 7 hours, no alerts or kills*   (* estimated playtime for my single low chaos playthrough)

This game, created by Arkane Studios but published from Bethesda, has everything a fan of stealth, story, gameplay and RPG needs. The graphics are wonderfully stylised, with a selection of interesting characters that aren't too out of the ordinary, but not bland enough to make you forget them. The protagonist in particular, Corvo, is wonderfully created, so you can imagine what kind of man he would be and play him to that image, whether he's the forgiving kind of killer or whether he just wants to see Dunwall burn. The story-line is intriguing and there's plenty of different turns you don't expect that I've enjoyed so far. Plus I love the man eating rats. The game has levels of customisation whether you want to use a gun, crossbow or the supernatural powers you're given early in the game, with plenty of collectbles to find each mission and requires a level of intelligence to find, as getting to them are sometimes puzzling. So far I simply adore this game and if you're a fan of Assassin's Creed, Thief and Bethesda's works, I can't recommend this game enough.

Dishonored sits high upon my list of ultimate favourite games. A beautifully morbid setting as Dunwall falls to a mysterious and infectious plague, you, as Corvo Attano, the body guard of the empress, is charged with her assassination. Starting from the bottom up you have to escape your execution and find out who really committed the assassination, as well as put an end to the plague that threatens to send the entire city into further ruin.  The graphics have always been one of my favourite points about Dishonored. An odd sort of soft cell-shaded that perfectly fits the tone and mood of the game. Granted some of the character's faces do look a little weird, but that could easily be down to artistic license to better portray the 'personality'.   As a previous consolefag who moved to PC gaming recently, I do have a few unfortunate downsides as opposed to the Xbox 360 version, which I played and completed first. The default controls have a half second response delay which is really noticable when you get into combat, or attempting to use the teleport ability and need precise, accurate aiming. Using a controller is slightly better, but there's still that moment of delay that could quite easily hinder someone. There's also this odd crackling noise in the audio that'll cause the music and any other noise from going quiet while it goes on, and occurs over a period of several seconds to a minute at sporadic intervals. Whether or not these can be fixed in the options menu I've yet to find out, as I've admitted before I am fairly new to PC gaming, but in either case I loved the game enough to buy it on Steam despite having it completed 100% on Xbox - you honestly can't compare it, even with its faults. It's definitely a game for people who enjoy a more unorthadox art style in gaming, a morbid, supernatural setting (a la Mythos of Cthulhu), branching story lines and clever stealth based systems.

Brief review.  Story: Epic tale in league with Bioshock Infinite. Simple story richly told. Likable characters. Interesting surprises.  Mood: Half Life 2 and accompanying episodes. Moderate anxiety stealth with enhanced sensory awareness and many choices.  Mechanic and special powers: reminiscent of Bioshock and inFAMOUS Second Son.  Sets: Beautifully designed levels.  Powerups: Rare but sufficient powerups dispersed throughout the levels. Health and special powers elixirs.  Special powers system: “Powers” that you can select and use with one of your hands as in Bioshock and Skyrim. “Bone Charms” that give you special personal skills as in Fallout 3.  Difficulty: Challenging missions, but very doable if you are patient and carefully plan your moves. Few boss fights and they are not crazy hard (on “Normal”).  Replay value: High. Many different options, different gameplay styles to decide upon, different routes to take on any given mission. High chaos: many encounters with enemies. Low chaos: avoiding enemies with meticulous planning and stealth.  Overall impression: One of the best games in my library. Compelling and immersive story that motivated me the way Bioshock Infinite, Wolfenstein: The New Order, and Half Life 2 did.  Final thoughts: With a little modification, this game could have formed a solid foundation for Half Life 3.

This is one of those games where you go back to play it months or years later and realize 'wow, I forgot how good this game was'. Stealth works pretty well, though it can be unintuitive (basically, if you can't see an enemy, they can't see you, even if that doesn't make sense in the given situation). The setting is a pretty effective low-key horror, macabre without being over-the-top. Story is unintrusive--you can pay as much or as little attention to it as you want without it affecting your experience much. It's well put together though, as well as largely character-driven. The main annoyance is the protagonist being silent for no apparent reason (though he'll apparently be talking in the upcoming sequel).  Oh, and DEFINITELY take the non-lethal options for all your assassination targets. They're WAY nastier (and funnier) than just killing them outright, and the targets are all rat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who deserve it.  In short, this is a way better Thief reboot than the actual Thief reboot.

I've now completed this game 4 times. Once with a pirated copy, once on this edition and twice on Dishonored RHCP edition that came because of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ region locks and the idea of me wanting the GOTY edition after playing the original game.  So, let's talk about the game now.  The sound design is good, the visuals are great with it's cel-shaded graphics and overall colorful world. Now, before you say 'Oh, it's just gray and brown' I'd like to bring up the difference between contrasted colors and just colors. Everything makes sense and fits there. I've found myself immersed in the game like a 12-yr old being immersed in the idea of big boobs so many times.  The combat is iffy for sure. It's fun if you're willing to make it fun for yourself. That doesn't mean that you should put in place restrictions, but kind of the opposite. You should be running, jumping around and using your powers to a full. In normal combat, the enemy will usually just stun kick you away and just doesn't give you a chance to fight them one on one properly.  The stealth is easy but keeps being satisfying. Thanks to the powers like blink, it's very easy to just teleport past the guards without much of a hassle.  The level layout is everything that you would like. Multiple entrance points. Multiple ways to traverse the levels and the abilities will make it even better. Now, the last thing to mention is the story. And all I can say is that 'It's a'ight!'. It's nothing special, it's not bad, some main characters are fleshed out, some are completely random and just feel like set-pieces. I still don't remember who is who and why they did something or didn't do something. It's an ok story that's not amazing.   Overall: With its flaws, Dishonored is still an amazing game.  8/10 (All games start off at a 5/10 and the grade will increase/decrease based on pros and cons)

As part of a generation of self-proclaimed 'Final Fantasy Allstars', it was always hard for me to really give other RPGs other than Chrono a real chance. It was always me asking myself, 'What could this other game that looks alright, really give me in a 50+ hour playthrough, that I couldn't get out of another run through any of my favorite Final Fantasies.' I then sat through the opening sequence of Dishonored. What Bethesda and Arkane do here is a slice of the steampunk cake, that makes me want to sit here and keep eating until there is nothing left. Albeit a story which really gets hacked off at the knees with a rather weak ending, the environment and sound-tracking for Dishonored finds me hard pressed to suggest another RPG outside of my FF comfort zone. I had also never dabbled in the stealth games before, but even though that wasn't my thing when I started, and I hacked my way through the storyline, Arkane built the game so that based on type of play the storyline sees real changes. If you are going to break out the digital wallet to pick up a new game, the game design alone had my steampunk and proto-industrial side poking like a nail, and everything else the game had to offer was just a huge plus. Don't buy any other RPG, except maybe what I remember as being a reformatted FF8 (New to Steam, but not the same without a controller) - Dishonored is it. Just exploring Dunwall was more than worth my money - so do it, and you won't regret it.

One of the amazing things about Dishonored is how vast the gameplay can be. You stealth it out, using sleep darts and choke holds for a nonlethal approach, or you can charge into battle with your sword, crossbow, and demonic powers. The gameplay accomodates for both, giving plenty of customization and augmentation for your weapons and abilities. Every single choice you make throughout the game, from character dialogue to deciding to kill someone, can lead to a different ending. Truly, Dishonored is an amazing game, with a whole world of options at your disposal.

Its like a darker version of the Assassin's Creed games. Lots of different ways to get through each assassination. Not only that the game is very well developed in all avenues. You don't just need to use the stock standardard duh/obvious way to do things in order to complete a mission. Furthermore, there is also excellent replay value as there are many ways to complete everything. Very well done game, highly recommended.

It's been criticized for its short storyline and its apparent copying of games such as Deus Ex, Assassin's Creed and Bioshock, but damn if Arkane didn't pull it off amazingly. Dishonored is highly immersive and an extremely fun game. The graphics are nice, gameplay is smooth and easy to understand, and the story is very intriguing. As I mentioned, the campaign is a bit on the short side, but the game does offer some degree of replayability due to the multiple methods you are offered in taking out your enemies. Similar to Deus Ex and Hitman style games, you have a ton of options on how you want to play the game. Whether you prefer to sneak by every guard undetected, or rush through with guns blazing and sword drawn, it's up to you. You don't even have to kill your assassination targets; instead you can find clever ways of making sure they're never seen again. The music is also absolutely amazing, and I'd hope to see an official soundtrack released at some point in the future. All of this combined with the Dunwall City Trials DLC (in which you compete with other players online in various mini-missions to gain the high score) makes this game a must-play, and one I wouldn't pass up lightly.
Very,very cool game

fantastic game. if you like stealth action games, this is the best one in the last year. I'm glad Arkane got a chance to shine and look forward to the next game as Bethesda has said it has sold well enough to warrant a franchise. the thing that stood out the most is the movement feels so smooth and not clunky at all. the art style is very enticing and there is so much lore to explore in the world and we only experience a tiny slice of it. the dlc featuring Daud is also excellent. they improved greatly on the main game by adding additional gadgets and tweaking the void powers to make for more interesting gameplay.

Dishonored is, without a doubt, my favorite stealth game ever. More than Metal Gear and more than Deus Ex. You are Corvo, the royal protector who was framed for the murder of the empress. You must then take your revenge on those who framed you with the help of magic from the Outsider and gadgets from Piero to aid you in your stealthing.  One of the main reasons I love this game so much is player choice. My playtime reflects that you can play the game more than once. If you're playing it once you aren't doing it right. At the shortest, you can play the whole game excluding the even shorter DLCs in about ten hours. However, the game offers many ways to play it through multiple times. In this regard, Dishonored is like an RPG. To compare to Fallout, another Bethesda game, my first run in both games is what I would do. In Fallout, I would side with the good guys (mostly) and be mostly nice. In Dishonored, I would use as much magic as I could, get as many runes as possible, not kill many people (murder wasn't out of the question though) and do other things I won't get into for spoilers' sake. I played a female psychopath in Fallout next, and in Dishonored I got all three achiemements for not killing anyone. You can play the whole game without killing anyone and in the sequel, you can do the whole game without magic.   Speaking of the magic, it's a great thing to put into a stealth game. In games like Metal Gear, it focuses on raw stealth in which you use distractions and funny looking diving to sneak about. With magic, you augment your sneaking so it becomes easier and more fun. It's optional however, except the first tier of blink. With blink, you can teleport a short distance to reach high places or traverse crowded streets faster. There is also dark vision that lets you see through walls. All of these powers make the game a very fun escape from traditional stealth games. Along with these powers, you get bone charms that add passives.   To get this magic you have to collect runes and bone charms. These are often placed off the beaten path and finding them leads you into interesting sidequests and cool lore to find. The game is rich in lore. Books are everywhere and audiologs explain a lot of things. You will learn about the seven scriptures of the overseers and why they name the months like month of nets. These sidequests and alternate pathways are different each time you play. If you seek runes early in the game, someone will ask you to poison a bootleg elixr distillery, and in the very next level, you are recruited by the person you ruined to do something.   With a story rich universe and fun mechanics and player choice, Dishonored is a must play for fans of stealth and story.
Best game I ever played.
I haven't had this much fun stealthing around since Hitman 2.

You are Corvo, a royal bodyguard turned into a cold-hearted assassin, passing judgement on the authority figures of Dunwall, killing everyone in sight. You assassinate guards and corrupt leaders by the dozen, using a blade, a crossbow, and occasionally go all out, blasting people down with a powerful handgun. You are the most murderous being in history. Or not. You can make your way through every candle-lit hallway, smoke-filled room, and gloomy street with complete silence, never taking a life, and only taking someone down by suffocating people in to a still alive unconsiousness. You never have to take a life. You can slip past guards and expose the evil authority as corrupt. Not a single drop of blood has to touch your blade, not a single dead man has to hit the cobble-stone, growing colder by the second. You can change the world in whatever way you wish. As one of the best games I've ever played, I would highly recommend it to anyone.

It sometimes feels a bit cheesy and 'seen before'.

Coming to the market from people blatantly trying to recreate a work like Thief the Dark Project, I bought this game with some skepticism. I leave a skeptic as akways, but it is certainly worth the purchase for someone interested in the genre.   Gameplay: Dishonered lets you float like a butterfly, sting like a bee, almost to the point where you feel like you are playing Theif with cheat codes. This feeling of absolute power seems to stem mostly from the absolute power of being able to blink (teleport short distances) which is probably the most valuable power you could ever dream of controlling in a stealth genre game. The game manages to create a set of mechanics that allow you to approach a situation from many possible angles, allowing your individually crafted outcome to become something quite unique. However, I felt the environments were still stagnant, and never really forced myself to approach problems from new and unique angles. Dishonered throws you all the God like toys, but it never really forces you to get creative with them and really push the limits of the puzzle aspect it provides you. Overall the game feels a bit too easy, finishing in just over 20 hours, with the only replay content being some DLC and going scavenging for missed runes and charms which is simply no fun for someone like me. A note: games like this tend to boast their open ended approach, but in the end it still feels like you are being led along at the end of a leash. Each objective is tagged with an omniscient arrow, which if you disable, you may easily be clueless about where to go next.  Story: I found the story interesting enough, and it wasn't terribly difficult to sympathize with your character (Corvo's) plight. There were many missed and unread notes and many nuances I probably didn't pick up from the extended material, but it is all saved in your journal so you can go back and read. There seemed to be a definite morality system based on your action, big and small, and somehow I ended up being an agent of chaos, even though I felt like I tried my best to be a good guy. Some larger decisions feel rather forced, and since my gamplay was very intermittent, I felt like I didn't have enough information about who should be saved and who should be eliminated. I find games that constantly nag me to be the purveyor of some arbitary justice to be a bit forceful and annoying. In other words, I feel like they throw these situations at you because they know its this idea that theoretically all gamers crave weird difficult moral scenarios, so they throw a few random decisions your way because their producers breathe down their necks about it.  overall i give it a 4/5, worth it, but could be better.

Well, I have to say the truth. I wasn't expecting much of this game, but this fella punched me right in the face within the first 10 minutes. The noticeable thing in the game is the enviroment that gets you pretty fast in the game. You can almost feel the plauge fear and the atmosphere of the game in your veins.   If we talk about the desing of the game, there isn't much to say: Perfect. You can smell the steampunk even in the very first minute of the game. Buildings, gagdets, paintings in the wall, scent of the dead, clothing of the people... etc. It just fits perfect when you combine these things! You can always find different routes if you play the game couple of times. I may be saying these because while Bethesda was working in this game, they transferred one of the main designer of the Valve to their team. (A Half-Life fan boy here- Give us the freaking HF3!) If you pay attettion to the enviroment, you can feel Half-Life-ish atmosphere. I'm not saying that this game is copy, they made their job pretty well.  Characters are pretty well, too. While playing the game you can find every type of person and see the war between the classes in the game. You can make deals with people that will change the game pretty much. You can use characters to make your ending brighter or even darker. You can make a person dissappear from the game -with a cost of course.   *Be wary spoilers start* With the DLC's you can play as Daud's -one of the main characters in the game you see within the first 10 minutes of the game. Playing the game from Daud's eyes made pretty different appreance about Daud, the Killer of the Empress. The main hero was Corvo in the game if you play in low chaos and sort of savior in high chaos, but this doesn't matter because with the DLC's you can see the true savior was Daud even though he killed 'Her'. *spoiler ends*  In the end all i can give to this game is my cosplay, my money and my sympathy. The things that this game can give you is much more than that. I even cried a bit in the end of the main game. Perfect gameplay combined with not bad graphics (I can tolerate a game without Crysis or Battlefield graphics if the story is this nice!), pretty good enviroment, characters and The Outsider! 9, even 10 out of 10 if you play the game over and over again.  9/10 -Bethesda, I'm looking forward for a new DLC to make things even better (Like a new person that has a Mark on him/her) or even Dishonored 2 i don't know. Give us something like this game Bethesda!

Released in October 2012, Dishonored is a stealth action-adventure video game developed by Arkane Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks. Dishonored definitely holds place for one of the best games I have played. Why?  Pros:  + Amazing artistic capabilities from developer + Optimization on its peak + Plot in this game is outstanding + Unique stealth and assassination mechanics  + Unique abilities with variety of kill options + Voice acting + Upgrade and abilities system + It took me about 11 hours to finish the game + DLC's  Cons: - Maybe only complain would be that in order to make all achievements, you have to buy all DLC's.  Other then that, this game is very original. I already finished it two times. Second time, I finished it with achievement 'Clean Hands', which means, you have to finish the game without killing and alerting anyone. So its definitely stealth game, but at the same time the game has one of the most unique lethal mechanics. And I can assure you, you won't regret buying it. Love it!

I have been, and continue to be a fan of Arkane Studios, the makers of Dishonored. They are not prolific and in fact have released only a few games (Arx Fatalis, Dark Messiah of Might and Magic, Dishonored) and helped with a few others (COD:WAW, Bioshock 2, Half-Life 2) but those titles they do release are excellently developed and well designed.  Dishonored has large amounts of flexibility on how you want to play from stealthy to outright carnage and destruction. There are so many options and such interactivity that the game still surprises me to this day as I play around with the levels and see what others are able to pull off. You only need to spend 2 minutes watching some of the play videos on the web to understand how well developed and interactive this game is. I suggest taking a moment to watch StealthGamerBR or Volound videos, even if you have already played the game, to see what the engine/game allows for gameplay and the amazing amount of fun you can have.  Highly recoomend this game for all types of first person game fun.

I try to keep reviews semi-professional but this game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. This game offers a unique spin on your typical hack and slash or assassination based game.  There is a gameplay type for anyone and everyone whether that be murdering brutally then feeding the corpses to rats or slipping through vents and shadows like a gust of wind to the enemy, you can do it. the varied powers in this game offers many unique playthroughs (In which I have played through around 4 times). After playing the game I purchased the two DLCs featuring the leader of the assassins seaking redemption and answers after killing the Empress and kidnapping the heir to the throne. the best part about the two DLCs is that it offers new powers offering a multitude of new routes to take.   Overall, to cut it short. This game will make you lust for more, needing more of the rewarding gameplay of tackling the hard points of the game and killing or neutralising your target to fit your gameplay style.  Downsides: Short campaign, repetative combat, DLC maps are plain with few exceptions. 9/10
