A great first-person stealth game. Avoids being too frustrating (one of the things I don't like about some stealth games) by providing a nice quick save and quick load system. The level designs are very non-linear in a way I haven't seen in other stealth games, letting you make the most of whatever abilities you choose, allowing for discovery of all sorts of secrets and alternate ways to complete stages, and generally giving you a nice variety of options.  On top of simply completing each stage, they provide a wealth of optional challenges that can increase the difficulty of the game or give you something to go for with repeated playthroughs.  Some might consider this game to be short. I appreciated the short length. Some games try to drag the experience out and end up becoming repetitive slogs, and they tend to do this towards the end of the game so you finish the game on a less-than-stellar note. This game doesn't do that. You only spend a short amount of time in each new environment, and the story moves along at a constant pace. If you do find yourself wanting more, there's replayability in going for the challenges and achievements or in playing the DLC.  That said, while the game was fun, it didn't pass the same threshold of fun that some other games achieve. There's no Dark Souls-esque fiero (apparently it's a word used to describe the rush felt when accomplishing something difficult) at completing a difficult challenge or besting another person in combat. There's no grand 'aha' moment as you finally solve a difficult puzzle (like in many puzzle games). There's no sensory overload like you get with fast-paced arcade-style games (you want to avoid detection, so you just end up quick-loading whenever that happens instead of playing it out and adopting a 'run-and-gun' style of play). It's not an 'audio-visual treat' as some might describe games like Dyad or Fez. It has some elements of each of these, but not to the extent of other games.  As far as problems go: I was frustrated at how many options it gave you for lethal kills while telling you not to use them. I ended up only buying the movement, blink, and time stop abilities and relying on the sleep darts. That whole time, I was staring at all this other cool stuff that I was not supposed to use. I had fun playing in this way, but I wished, if I was supposed to be stealthy, they would provide more tools and abilities for such a playstyle. Also, the writing is kind of unintelligent and contrived. The characters do things that don't really make sense, in retrospect. It ruins the immersion of the game when you start to notice the ways in which the characters don't act like real people and makes you less invested in the plot.  So, it's fun and it has only a few problems to speak of, but, as a whole, it's lacking the 'peaks' of entertainment that you can find in other excellent games. If you're looking for something that reaches that level of 'amazing', I might pass on this game, but if you're looking for a solid first-person action game with an interesting story, I recommend this game.
Very good game, I've got three copy's: one on the Xbox, one on the pc and one on the other pc    P.S I've pre-ordered Dishonored 2

I could go on and on like the thousands of reviews already on here, but the only thing to say is that this game is awesome. If you haven't played it then you owe it to yourself to do so. I started playing this game 4 years after its initial release, and the only thing i regret is that it took me this long to finally play it.
Damn good fun, wish I didn't blow at stealth.

If you like stealth games with lots of different ways to go about your objective, with great gameplay, and a amazing story, than this game is for you. This is one of my favorite games of all time, I would strongly reccomend this game to any gamer out there.  9/10

One of the best games EVER. It's like a mix of assasins creed, Skyrim and the arkham games. Maybe slightly shorter but the depth and story line definetly make up for that. At first I underestimated the effects that your playstyle would have on the game (whether you decided to kill or spare), but I was amazed at the difference when I replayed the game without killing (and vis-versa), whole scenes change, maps looks different, and even some areas and artifacts are unlocked!   In conclusion I highly reccomend this game.

Welcome to the city of Dunwall, a city infested by plague, rats and corruption. The game started kinda hard (atleast for me). I didn't found any motivation, or something interesting to keep playing it, but it was all going by itself mission after mission, where the story got a bit more interesting.  Review doesn't contain storyline spoilers.   This game adapts as you play it. You have -tons- of choises within the storyline, as well as different approaches and ways to play it (stealthy, lethal, non-lethal, full rambo, etc). Everything you do has a huge impact on the ending, which is not always the same.   Going onto the gameplay and mechanics. They are fine for a 2012 game. Not really polished enough for my taste. NPCs are not so bright if you ask me :D (stupid as f*ck). If you're going on the stealthy side, you will have a challange not because they are intelligent or have eyes, but because they are many. If you are going on the rambo side, you will have a -huge- challange 'cause they are many. Combat is fine, although it gets irritating when you are like 1 vs 7.   Going onto the graphics and over performance, well, it will receive a 5/10 from me for graphics and 11/10 for overall game performance. Yeah, half of Steam Community will jump on my head, but for a 2012 game, the graphics are not what they should be. I maxed out every setting and had a stable 130FPS (which I think it's capped there, otherwise I think it would jump right to 99999999), and I felt like playing Left 4 Dead 2 on Low settings.  On top of everything, it was a nice game, although won't be my last time playing it. I still have to finnish the DLCs and I still want to re-do the storyline on a stealthy non-lethal approach :).  And for the 10Euro I paid for the full Dishonored game, it's worth it.  8/10 would recommend.
great game.....

Probably some of the most fun I have had in a video game for a long while. I have finished this game at least four times, and every time I still enjoy it all like I did the first time. With the ability to either do it stealth or full on action, it adds a fair bit of replayablity to it. On top of that, both ways of doing things are fluid, fun and rewarding in their own way. All of the powers are useful, but not neccicary, so you aren't pidgeon holed into anything.   9/10 - IGN.

Still not played the PC version but on my xbox I have clocked at least 300 hours on this and will continue to do so until I am satisfied I have completed the game in every way possible.   The game has a great story with incredible characters, from Granny Rags who seems to have a dark and mysterious past, to the main protaganist Corvo himself. Loyal and deadly bodyguard on a mission to avenge the Empress in Dunwall's darkest hour.  I mean the game itself looks stunning, the painting type effects make the game feel very dark and suit it very well. With cool side characters like Slackjaw you can really play the game how you want to to achieve your final goal, however the way in which you go about this will change Dunwall, for better or for worse is up to the player to use their head.  The combat for the game is incredible, you can pull off some pretty insane kills with the large choice of weapons given to the player, that's not even including the magic. There are millions of horrible ways to dispatch your enemies. Or perhaps spare them. Should they really be held accountable for the actions of those in command? This is where the game shines.   I would give this 95/100. The only possible thing I could say bad about this game is the campaign is quite short, but when there are as many ways to complete it as there are, who really cares?  A sequel to this would be much appreciated. I would happily spend £100 on another if it was as good or better than this.

This game is just so cool. The vanilla story take me 13 hours to finish, while playing and exploring well. It has a good rejouability, you can play the story again wither other ways to play. It's really funny to infiltrate and kill everyone like a ghost !

Dishonored is definitely one of my favourite stealth games of all times, and also one of my overall favourite games. The scenario and time period in which the game takes place is very fitting, and it makes for a very great historical experience. The gameplay itself is very well done, and it makes the player feel powerfull and stealthy, which makes it very enjoyable to play or to watch gameplay of. The mechanics are very solid and not too complicated, making the game easy to play and be somewhat good at it, but most importantly, make the player feel powerfull without needing great skill. Overall the game behaves pretty good, and makes playing it really enjoyable. I could go on about the good things for a long while, but I'll just end this review now, for I'm lazy and I think this should be enough. Last thought: Dishonored is a great game. Case closed.

I could write a book about all that there is to love about this game. The combat system is fantastically simple, and simply fantastic. The stealth gameplay is unparralleled. The game is expansive, and rewards exploration heavily. The characters are memorable, the voice acting is well done, and the interactions stick with you. Even the DLC is well made and creates intriguing changes in the story. But the best thing about Dishonored is that it creates a world where your choices truly make a difference. The people you kill, the people you save, and (most importantly) the person you are, will affect everything and everyone around you...especially those closest to you. And when you finish the game, and see the world as your actions have made it, you will see what is truly great about Dishonored.
You can jump off a roof and have no fall damage because you stab someone in the face. Now that's some physics right there.
Excellent game very good all around.

Dishonored has you playing how you have always wanted to play. You can choose many different ways and paths through the game to have the storyline follow along. This game lets your creativity into a stealth game.

Dishonored is a fun unique game. It grants you the power to teleport, slow time and more. It is a less hardcore and more casual and enjoing game but it isn't hardacore stealth game. If you want a hardcore stealth game get theif and definetly pick this up on sale.

I would like to make it clear that, even with the limited hours I spent in this game, it was a decent game. I just didn't find the time to click into a game with so much stuff going on in it. None the less, its actually a very good game.    You play as Corvo Attano, whom once was the Empress' bodyguard, and best friend. The start of the game leads you into a realization that those you once called 'friend' are just wolves in sheeps clothing. Never the less, even after being framed for a murder you didn't commit, you set out to take out those truly responsible. Along the way you must save Young Lady Emily, whom you are introduced to at the beginning of the game by playing, or not playing, hide and seek with her. If you're looking for a game where you can choose to kill lots of people, or remain hidden in the shadows, this game is something worth looking at. Along the way there are some interesting characters, and even more interesting stories to uncover about the Empress, and the town plague.   Pros & Cons

The best UI customization I've ever seen so far. The cityscape bathing in sunrays looks just gorgeous. Decent story, steampunk environment, pleague.. Just one of the pseudo magic spells is actually crutial to the whole experience and that is blink. Love it.

Looking back at Dishonored: One of the best stealth games I had ever played. Try not to abuse the quick save system. Other than that, this game is a pretty good 'assassin simulator'. It's also pretty good for a first person point of view. Knowing that Dishonored 2 is currently in development (as I am writing this review) makes me happy.    My review when the game was still fresh in my head 2 years ago: [A really awesome, if not probably the best assassin game you will ever play. You can either play on two paths: Non-lethality, which means you will have to use stealth most of the time and choke your enemies to death OR; Lethality, which means killing EVERYONE because it is awesome. The combat of the game is great! And you have really cool powers so use them to your advantage. This game really makes you feel like an assassin. Okay maybe thats the sole purpose of assassin games, but killing key targets are pretty fun. Time would slow down a bit and music would play as you kill key targets with your blade, whether it is a stab from behind or a full-out frontal assault. A few downsides of the game are namely 1. How they poorly introduce you to Lady Emily, the daughter of the Empress, 2. The eyes of the characters dont really show any expression, they blink but they dont really change, and lastly 3. You will have a 'bossfight' later in the game, but it was so easy I dont think it's a boss fight. Overall great game. I dont care about the downsides I just mentioned. It's 10/10]

Soak in it because of its amazing aesthetic and rich world; experiment with it because of its malleable and precise mechanics; spread the word about it because it's a thrillingly fresh, new IP in a sea of sequels and remakes; buy it because it's a PC port done right for once.

There are two play styles for this First Person Stealth game - Batman Style or Deathstroke Style, one focuses on non-lethal force, avoiding detection and dispensing justice, the other focuses on lethal force, being LESS than subtle and killing without remorse.  It gives you the option to kill your targets, incapacitate them or avoid them when you can. For those that want a change from the 'SHOOTY SHOOTY BOOM BOOM' type of game and want something that probes their mental capability, I'd get this! It kicks ***!

One of my favourite games this year. The game does extremely well in providing multiple routes (for both stealth and brute force characters) to complete the objective. I have to add that the port is very well done, I did not encounter any crashes, v-sync stuttering, etc that are so common with console ports.  The game is very forgiving with speedy traditional save and load instead of the check point system like most recent console games. Some people might find it too easy but I found it just right for a casual gamer with only a few hours each night to play.

I Highly Recomend this game, It won many awards. One of which was game of the year for 2012, for good reason. You can scale the difficulty up and down. Save any time. It loads super fast and is extremly well optomized. The guys at Arkane know their stuff. You get some really good thief vibes in it but ultimatley its a game on its own. One for the hall of fame for sure for me ! Pick it up on a sale! Also...the DLC is awesome! I highly recomend getting a bundle pack. Have fun!

The game seems impossible (or damn close to it) without powers, due to the actually-fairly-good AI and their uncanny nack for looking in all the right places, so your prison escape is usually the most difficult part. Aside from that, the game seems to have a lot of emphasis on 'let's count the ways you can commit mass murder' for a game that has a pseudo-morality system, the graphics and aesthetic are very nice (if just a combination of Bioshock's aesthetic and Half-Life 2's aesthetic), the gameplay holds up well until the absolute last bit of the absolute last level (where the guards are combination of immovable and clueless, for reasons I can't come up with), there are a fair number of powers but not enough runes to go around and not enough powers that can be used non-lethally (most of them focus on lethality or cause needless death when used), and the audio is very nice.  Overall I give it a 4/5 (would recommend if it's $10-15, MAYBE $20), and it could be made absolutely perfect with modding. Personally I've had my fill of the game's mechanics (which for me, boil down to 'blink behind guard, choke guard, hide guard, don't get caught, ad nauseum'), so I'd skip the DLCs.
1. Started Game  2. I realized I could save  3. I realized I could run it on ultra with no lag  4. Killed some guards and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s  5. Blew ♥♥♥♥ up   ...  10/10

Dishonored has got to be one of my favorite games, and by far my favorite stealth and assassin game. This game gets you thosed in the middle of a kindom of choas, like a world about to crumble, and you have the job of keeping it together. The story sucks you in almost immediately, as after mostly watching and a little bit of playing the intro, I was already saying 'Wow' and wanting to playing this game. The highest point of this game is it's gameplay. Stealth and/or assassin games are both either do really really well or really really bad. This game was focus on what it should: gameplay. There are moments that are just so satisfing, and leaves you wanting more. The CPUs are very smart and only somewhat glitched, which I wish I could say about some games. They made the AI very well, and it's something you have to see to believe.  Now comes to the bad part. The bad parts. I though I recomend, I wouldn't rate this game very high. It is one of my favorite games, but there are just to many bugs. The CPUs I mention earlier, though they are well thought out and working on hard, I find it *small spoiler* the first 3 levels are easy, then the AI just skyrocketed. The last few missions where really much more challenaging, and each stage was 30x harder than those *small spoiler again* 3 levels. The whole game should have been like that! It offered challages and stituations that required thinking. There was 3 ways to do it on the *small spoiler again* first 3 levels, but the last there were a million, not counting the ones that didn't work. Getting over the CPUs and level design, lets talk about the story. Though the story immers you from the start to finish, and you always want to see what happens, it's to predictable. Nothing in the story truely shocked me like they ment it to. *small spoiler once more* The only time something the story happened that I didn't expect was small small parts in the end. My last complant is the use of magic. The game allows you to use magic that helps you out in some situations, which I'm glad they did, but they made it to hard to use. The only way to be able to have use for ALL the magic stills AND level them up AND get the other type of magic charm is by going out of way and spending another 2-3 hours on the game. Spending a much tolerence as possible on the game, I spent about an hour more collecting extra 'runes' and still I didn't have all the magic powers like I planned. The creators may have done this on purpose, but I find it annoying (the game is still beatable with out them, it's not THAT hard to beat the game without them).  So overall, I give this game a 8.5/10. It satisfied me, and in the end is the best assassin game to date. They could have just done so much more with it, but from there point of view, I see how at the time it did look perfect therefore was very understandable. For the price of the game and the DLC, It's worth more than what it's listed at or what it ever was listed as. Can't wait for Dishonored 2!!!!!!
Amazing game, great gameplay great story and great stealth gameplay.

This game is fantastic. It runs amazingly, the gameplay is smooth, the bugs are minimal, and the world of Dunwall is incredibly lifelike and full of nooks and crannies to explore. Oh, and the replayability. Don't even get me started on the replayability.   10/10 would get framed again.

One of the few stealth games I enjoy, not even being a fan of the genre. I'm not very patience, making this a genre that doesn't match with me, but in this game I cannot even recall a moment where I felt bored waiting.

An absolutely incredible game, very reminiscent of Deus Ex and yet somehow much better. It drops you into a situation and tells you to figure it out; an odd yet compelling mix of linear and non-linear gameplay. Dishonored is a true gaming masterpiece.
Like Skyrim but with guns.

This game is a break from your traditional routine. Stealth, blades, rats, blink, are some of the amazing features that I got to experience in a steampunk/victorian city. It as got reply value, for its ending is not one, but many, according to your play style.
There are both inedible AND edible rats 10/10

Simply one of the best game of the 7th generation and one of the best stealth/action games as well. The gameplay offers several possiblities of approach for every single stage of every single mission and this offers a huge number of hours of fun due to his high replayability level. The plot is simple but effective and, technically speaking, this game is astonishing. The unique graphic style, with the choice of dieselpunk atmosphere and technology certainly make Dishonored's world a well built one and one of the best of his genre as well. Consider also the good voice acting (I played it both in English and Italian) and an enjoyable soundtrack, the beautiful DLCs and the low price (which decreases a lot more during sales) and there you have one of the best adventures and stealth experiences ever created.    The truth is that gamers deserve the possibility to play more often majestic titles like Dishonored.

!m not good with reviews, but Dishonered is one of my all time favorite games. if you are looking for a fun and story filled game that isnt to hard, then you should definitely get this game! I can play it over and over again and still find some interesting stuff everytime that i havent seen before!  Controls are not hard at all and i find it very easy to pick up and play.
Great stealth game, very solid. Love stabbing people!

Freedom is the name of the game here, both in regareds to it's story and the excellent free form design of it's gameplay. Dishonored is one of the most refreshing first person action games I've played in quite awhile due to this freedom. It encourages stealth and non-violent methods of dispatching your enemies but gives you plenty of tools to do otherwise. Every weapon, tool and supernatural power works exactly as it should and allows you to creatively approach enemy encounters as opposed to going from point A to B while facing a certain number of waves. I also appreciated the format of the game as it striked a very happy medium of having just enough rpg mechanics to give it depth (a town hub with interesting NPCs and a store/upgrade vendor) while also having a focused experience when you were on mission.This game does not overstay it's welcome and is one hell of a ride; do not miss it.

This is the closest we've come to Deus Ex in a long time.  The movement, in particular, is excellent. Incredibly fast and fluid, and blink-powered fast-stealth is infinitely preferable to crawling around from box to box, waiting for guard patrols to drift out of sync. The levels are big playgrounds of possibility, not 'pick route A or route B', and are fun just as places to scale and explore while observing and planning. And observing and planning you will probably do, as it shines when played as a melting pot of Thief, Hitman, and Deus Ex, yet unlike those three if you go for a loud-and-violent solution, *that's* fairly slick too.  Harvey Smith has more than made up for Invisible War.
A really excellent stealth game

Dishonored (no 'U', bah, humbug) reminds me of Half Life 2 and Bioshock 1 (this is definitely a good thing). It is basically an FPS with RPG elements (some 'powers')..  Overall top production values. Unfortunately, and strangely, the non-lethal playstyle isn't catered for very well and isn't rewarding. Dishonored could have been fierce competitor to best of the Thief and Deus Ex series (a very good thing)... but it isn't. Still, Dishonored is an excellant game and you should get it if it is on sale.

GET THIS GAME. It is one of the best stealth games ever. You are basically an assassin with magical powers, guns, crossbows, sleep darts, poison darts, explosives, and a ton of tricks up your sleeve. The world is very much alive and dynamic. Everyone reacts to you and your actions. You can play violently or you can beat the game without killing a soul. Different endings happen depending on your decisions.

Imagine Hitman Absolution and Half Life 2 had a baby, they'd call it Dishonored. At 30hrs to complete in full stealth, I wouldn't say it's too short when to get all the achievements you have to go stealthy at least once. It's only too short because it's one of the best single player games of this generation.   Having only done a stealth playthrough I can't say it does anything wrong so far, in fact it does many things right in my opinion they outshine any complaints. If I had to pick one thing it's the scripted AI , like many other stealth games too. But this one has quicksaves.   If you liked Hitman but want first person and supernatural powers, get this one. I can't wait for the DLC.

It is labeled as a stealth game but considering the large arsenal of weapons that you can amass and how you can combine weapons/traps/powers, it's more like an inventive murder simulator. You can, however, go through the entire game without firing a single shot nor murdering anyone, which is neat ( and challenging ). At the end of the day, sneaking around is nowhere near as entertaining as using all of your powers and weapons and even simply using your sword to duel guards is more fun than sneaking.  The plot is quite intriguing but it abuses collectable books to explain it properly which may not be of your liking, considering you want to play a video game and not read a book. The story progression itself offers a nice sense of replayability and the way your perception of a level changes whether you decide to use stealth or go guns blazing just makes replaying it all the more enticing.  The setting is superb ( seriously, the obsession with whales and the lore are a very interesting read ) and the graphic style is quite pleasing and refreshing, definetely not something you see every day.  The two story-based DLCs improve completely with regards to the level design and some of the mechanics of the game and it explains another side of the main story, definitely worth picking up. The rest of the DLCs are not as great but if you end up loving the game and you want time trials and things like that, it is okay.  That being said, it is not a long game, very replayable if you like it a lot but also very short if you do not. You could probably finish it in about 8 hours or less if you go for the main objectives and ignore exploring the levels and doing all the side quests.
froze time as guy shot me. mind controlled his mate to move in front of the bullet. unfroze time, guy shot his own mate. 11/10
It's a good game but I always lose interest right before i finish it.

Dishonored is actually a pretty good game. The graphics are great, and the game makes you think and try new things. There are many differnt ways to complete a mission so you could always make up your own storyline based on how you complete a certain mission. Overall im going to keep playing this game.
Played this game on the Xbox and PC. Epic level variety and design. Overall solid and very fun game.
So I was playing the game. All of a sudden I realized that I could do something else. So I did that instead. 7/10

A great game, not because of the stealth, which is still good don't get me wrong, but the real strengths of the games lie in the decisions you make. From plunging a city into chaos by killing everything that walks, or being a shadow in the night that is never even seen, the possibilities are infinite (well pretty much). Not only are the rich level designs full of choices and consequences, but your decisions also affect the storyline and future mission levels. The more people you kill the darker the outcome, making future levels harder with more rats and weepers to deal with.  With the possibilities being endless the game is for all play styles, so you can do the ol' run and gun, or be like me and not harm so much as a rat, and finish the game without killing anyone and attempting to go for the insane personal challenge of collecting every single cent, (trust me its hard). Beside the decisions the game offers, the level design is deep and well written, plus the art style is great, personally I quite like the art style, very similar to the graphics displayed in borderlands and such.  With multiple different areas from flooded slums to militarised islands, and the homes or lords and ladies. Large array of weapons and supernatural powers, some of the weapons include shrapnel mines, grenades, a crossbow loaded with different kinds of bolts and a gun which later in the game becomes killer. The powers range from slowing time, teleporting, summoning rats and other cool powers that can help you sneak about like the rats you associate yourself with, or you can be a whirlwind or blades and sneakily slowed time grenade placements. With all these choices the game is brilliant, containing heaps but not too much, and if this isn't enough the DLC's provide even more...  Wow I wrote too much...again..
An ok story, the real fun is in the gameplay. great mechanics and with multile ways do do each missoin, has plenty to replay for. would highly recommend

The phrase “stealth mechanic” and/or “stealth mission” probably causes the everyday gamer to shudder. More often than not these are tedious, slow portions of a story which usually highlight the worst in level design, mechanics, and AI shenanigans. What starts off as the 'good intentions' of a player in trying to properly sneak around ends up with the Rambo'ing of an entire level out of sheer frustration.  Not with Dishonored.  I've yet to play any stealth based game, including any Metal Gear Solid offering (arguably considered the king of stealth) that supplies the level of fluidity, options, and satisfaction in not being seen or shedding a single drop of blood that Dishonored provides. So much so that any time I had my cover broken, and invariably forced to switch to lethal methods, I felt a sense of responsibility to the spirit of the story to load a previous save and try utilizing different areas of the level or player abilities to successfully get through said portion completely unseen. In any other game I would consider this a complete waste of time, and slightly insane. But like I said, the “cool factor” of the stealth here is so freaking cool that you have to indulge it.   The atmosphere, level design, and characters within the game are equally top notch. One thing I really appreciated was the fact that you don't have to suspend your disbelief too hard to get into the role of the main character, as the design decision not to make him talk (or see what he looks like) is absolutely the right one for a game of this nature.   Brilliant all around. Can't wait for the sequel.
This is another Bethesda masterpiece. I'm horrible at this game (I literally die every 45 seconds), but I still play it anyway.   9.2/10

First time i played this i rushed through killing everyone at a friends place. I didnt think much of it and found it quite forgettable. Then i picked it up on a sale and played it again, this time killing noone but creeping around fooling people and knocking them out. It was alot more fun this time and i also had a different ending!
Bioshock made sweet love to Deus Ex Human Revolution, and out popped Dishonored.
One of the best stealth FPS ever made. Must have.

Fun game, great story that actually made you care enough to follow (which is tough for an old school gamer like me- usually I just want to plow through the game and don't care too much about the plot), great voice acting, and many fun missions. Personally I'm not the biggest fan of stealth games- and to be fair, you CAN be 100% non-stealthy and kill everyone in sight, but that leads to the 'bad' ending...and since I'm a sucker for 'good' endings, I decided to play stealthy :)  Here's three tips for beginners that will make life much easier for yourself in the game (no spoilers):  - Get Tier II Dark Vision right away. A friend told me to do this, and boy was he right. Words cannot express how helpful this ability is- I can't imagine playing without it. I pretty much used only this and Blink throughout the game, and rarely used anything else. - Quicksave a lot (F5 by default). I got to the point where I quicksaved before doing pretty much anything, and now my F5 key doesn't work anymore after hitting it so many times (just kidding). But it takes just a second, and in the long run it'll save you a lot of time. - Remember that there's no reason to go after every guard. At the beginning I was doing this, but later on I just stared sneaking by. Also, if they have a key, know that you can steal the key without even touching them...for some reason I was about 2/3 of the way through the game before learning this.  Although it's a great game, I do have a couple complaints:  - I ran into so many spots where there was an invisible boundary preventing me from going a certain way. Frustrating when you have to rethink your whole strategy & approach due to an invisible boundary that doesn't even make sense as to why its there. - When I needed to choke someone out, there were a number of times where the game wouldn't let me do this for some reason. Occasionally I'd be right behind someone and in perfect position, but the 'choke out' option wouldn't appear, and then they'd turn around and see me. Then when I'd reload and try it again, I'd do the exact same thing and it'd work perfectly. Very weird and frustrating at times. - More than once I encountered a tricky spot with lots of people where I needed to carefully plan an approach...only to find out that this particular group is friendly and/or otherwise not going to attack you. The game sometimes doesn't communicate moments when you're among friendlies and/or are free to be seen without consequence. - The game is short. I'm slow as hell and like to explore a lot in these single player games, and I beat it in 11 hours. I'm sure many people finish it in 8-10 hours, if not faster.  Like I said though, it's a great game overall. My letter grade would be a B+ or A-

I just finished the game. I couldn't express in words alone how amazing this is. After trying it for the first time I was instantly hooked and found myself unable to stop playing. Real life? I didn't care for it anymore. Problems and worries? Gone from my mind as this reality became very much consuming. I found myself thinking of this game constantly, what I could've done better, what mistakes I could've fixed if I only saved more often to correct them, my noobish start which made things turn for the worse in the end... oh if only. It's been years since I've felt so immersed in something, so taken by another reality. Something I haven't felt since childhood.   This game made me have to think, and act swiftly. It made me think all were attackers, and would punish me when afterwards I'd realize they weren't. If I made a mistake like avoiding someone who'd offer a clue to the next part of the story, it wouldn't screw me over by never allowing me to progress like other games do. Most of all, it allowed you to choose how you would act, and take out targets and allow you to take multiple ways to get to one destination. That quality is what most games miss, and the option to choose peoples fates and your own is what made me fall so hard for Dishonored.   There were times, during the game where I got annoyed with certain things, mainly the guards. They'd repeat the same things over and over like a broken record. It's nice to know where they are, but perhaps a wider variation of what they say would be nicer next time. I don't want to hear harland garland 50 times in a row.... whatever the hell that's supposed to mean. Yes, the guards like to mumble that a lot.  Now the ending.... note I've only played this through once, so this might be biased due to multiple different ones. The ending for me was bittersweet. It honestly brought me to tears. I don't cry for a story unless it's good, and this, and the game itself, managed to do that. So overall, this game, from start to finish was amazing. I'm glad a friend got this for me, I'm thankful I spent the time I did playing it. I have no regrets. Please buy this game at the full price with all the dlcs so the developers can keep making more like this. I'm highly looking forward to Dishonored 2, and any upcoming games made by these people in the future.   TL;DR for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s: Buy it at full price with dlcs it's amazing.
If you like a good story, excellent combat, and tons of replay value then this game is for you!

It's April 19 in 2014 and I have just finished my first playing of Dishonored. I picked up the game of the year edition during it's last sale a few weeks ago. I don't know why I ignored this game for so long. I even played a demo when it was first released long ago. It is a complex game with a little learning curve and I didn't realize at the time that Harvey Smith was a creative director of Dishonored. Deus Ex was a taste changing landmark game for me. I wasn't paying attention and the demo didn't capture my imagination at the time. I must have been tired!  This is a great first person perspective game with lots of alternative map paths to complete the missions and lots of interesting game play mechanics to change up your approaches to the many missions. The plot was very involving for me with a great surprise twist in the middle of the game. The voice acting is great and the dialogue has lots of variation depending upon how 'chaotic' your play style. You are going to want to play this at least twice.  I am still waiting for that 'good deal' to update my video card for the next generation so I have played this with a 9800 GT nvidia with just half a gig of video ram. I can max out all of the settings and it still runs great. The art work is beautiful. It all works well and didn't seem at all compromised for performance at all. You can sleep dart your opponents, sneak by them, kill them with an interesting array of weapons all having attractive displays. I ended up using 'blink' and my sword a lot so it ended up being a great sword fighting game for me against other 'blinking' assassins. I was pleasantly surprised by this.  No one needs this review at this late date but I liked the game so much I just had to do it.

If you can get this game for cheap, I'd say it's worth it. It's got a 'Victorian era meets Half-Life 2' vibe going for it, which I think is nice. The gameplay using powers leads to some fun and interesting ways to complete levels. The swordplay is pretty awful, though, so this really shouldn't be considered an action game. There are definitely times where, even though you are lined up to hit enemies with a sword swipe, the game just decides you already hit once in the last 3 seconds, so you won't do it again. I can't say there's any memorable music, but the voice acting is okay. Having played this game shortly after it came out and again recently, I would advise against getting the DLC as it so far isn't adding to the story and the levels are not really exciting. The main game is good enough that even if you want to go through it again with a different play style, it's worth it and just barely wears out its welcome by the end.  edit: I really can't bring myself to finish the DLC. Save your money, just get the base game and call it a day.

Dishonored is an amazing experience while it's happening, you can choose your playstyle and stick with it and you'll never feel like the levels weren't designed for it. The ending is incredibly ♥♥♥♥♥♥, like they ran out of time or something, but everything leading up to that is spectacular. For any first-time players, try a stealth pacifist run; it'll keep you on the edge of your chair.

The only bad thing about this game is that if you're going for a no kill run be careful where you place your passed out buddies. If rats eat them or they get blown up or they get knocked over and drown or just die from the fall damage that counts as you murdering them. There's another hint for doing a no kill run but it would kinda spoil an aspect of the story so just play the game.   Voice acting, level design, story, graphics, etc etc it's all great. And most importantly it's incredibly fun. One of my top 10 games even though it came out just 4 years ago.

My god, I knew this game was full of options but WOW!  Very few games can manage to pull off level design as this game does, and the most intriguing thing is the levels aren't even that big. Dense is the word that comes to mind. There are literally so many paths to take, so much variety in the combat that I could to anything imaginable: stealth when I'm feeling sneaky, clever surprises when I wanna ruin someone's day, and murderous rampage whenever the dread of living in the real world sets in!   Game kinda punishes you with the ending if you get high chaos, but that's that's not too bad because I went on 3 killing sprees in the first 3 chapters and still did well enough to get low chaos on very hard, with a happy Emily! Oh if she knew the things I had done :D.  Buy it. Right now. Just buy it, let it stew in your library for a while, and when the burning curiosity sets in and you install it, get ready for the ride of your life!

I'm not even sure what to say besides the fact that this is still my favorite game ever since I started playing it a couple years ago. A lot of the negative reviews say that the game is too easy. I will admit that compared to other stealth games that I have played (Another of my favorites being Splinter Cell Chaos Theory, an oldie but goodie) the stealth is a bit easier because of the supernatural powers Corvo (you) has. However, I don't think that this impacts the gameplay as much as others are making it seem. If you really take your time and try to do a completely non-lethal run (something I am still going to attempt) this game is plenty hard and changes practically every time based on the decisions you make in game. Can't wait for the second one, already pre-ordered.

What to say about one of my favorite games ever? now at the time of this review i only just got it on my PC but i had it on the xbox 360 and boy did i play it alot, the combat is very fluid and feels very nice, wether you choose to blink around enemies and kill them from behind or just fight them face to face, combat is very good.   the story is a very interesting one that unravels the more you play the game and it gets better and better the more you play, what you do in the game will inflict the world around you in some way shape or form, doind a high lethal chaos run of the game will mean higher levels of security and more rats and weepers, low chaos non lethal runs (in my opinion the boring way to play) will result in less security and weepers and rats, whats good about this game is that you can play anyway you want, say you like games for the story but dont like killing and blood and all that stuff, you can play the whole game without killing any one!!   when doing a mission in the game the level is spilt into different instances inside one zone, its like a small open world area kinda like the Tomb raider reboot with places to explore and see as well as side quests to complete and things to find, there are also many different ways you can approach a mission, you can just walk in the front door and kill everyone or you can sneak across the roof and into the place via the windows.   Overall this game is a must play before the second game comes out, its great value for money aswell with lots of re-playability, if i had to give this game a rating out of 100 i think id give it a 94, it does have its flaws but there isnt many of them in fact i cant even list them off the top of my head.  But yeah this game is a must buy i highly recomened it. :)
You can torture people and flip levers to electrocute them. 10/10 would torture again

This game is amazing. If you're fan of steampunk type games, this game is for you!  You get to choose from killing important characters or simply let them live. (non-lethal way) The maps are really big and there is a lot of secrets to find. (Runes, Sokolov paintings, Bone charms, etc...) In my humble opinion I suggest this is a game worthy of your money. I highly recommend this game if you are into a stealth game or if you like to use brute tactics and force in order to achieve your goal.  Introduction: The game introduces you as the 'Royal Protector' Corvo Attano, which is returning back to Dunwall to meet with Jessamine Kaldwin; the empress of Gristol, to tell her that he has not succeeded in finding a solution to the rat plague currently infesting Dunwall. His reunion with Jessamine is made short however, since she is assasinated right infront of him. Corvo tries to battle the assasins, he is however knocked out, giving the assasins an oppertunity of escaping. Shortly after 'the royal spymaster' shows up blaming Corvo for the murder of the empress. You then have to find out who murdered the empress, and reclaim your honor.  Gameplay: This game offers diversity in terms of strategy. I personally found myself discovering new ways of infiltrating target objectives on my third and fourth playthrough. This game also allows you to choose how you want to play. You can choose if you want to kill someone, or if you want to complete the entire game without killing anyone. The way you play the game also affects how the ending will turn out. You are also able to use certain powers, some of these powers can be used for a stealthy approach, some can be used to kill.   This game has some glitches and bugs which I find a bit frustrating. Dialogue between NPC is cut whenever you are being detected by them. The dialogue does not countinue from where it stopped once they return back to their un-alerted state. There are also situations where something you haven not done is count as a kill, which is frustrating if you are trying to achieve a playthrough without killing anyone. It is also hard to recognize some of the NPCs' who will be alerted by your presence, and those who will not.  To conclude this short review: I believe this game is a good investment, since it offers great diversity in playstyle and player based choices. The story is also very good. The things I found negative about the game are minor. As a side note I want to mention that I have not experienced any major problems with this game (only very few crashes, as expected).  (I'm sorry for any grammatical mistakes made, as I am not a native speaker. Hope this review is readable)

With all the buzz about Dishonored 2, I decided to play through this game again. Shortly after starting I contracted an illness and went into violent coughing fits. This is the most immersive experience I've ever had with a video game.  10/10  Would contract rat plague again.

Dishonored. Nothing other then  amazing .  There's a very limited selection of games I would 100% recommend to my friends but this is  definately  one of them.    Pros      Amazing stealth gameplay. (Stealth options for lethal and non-lethal players.)    Very optimized. Will run on  any  modern PC.    Hours of gameplay. (15 hours after my first leisure run non-lethal.) I'm replaying the entire game again to get the  Ghost  and  Mostly Flesh and Steel  achievements.     Cons      The only  con  I have about this game is the inability to see if you've accidently killed someone without knowledge. It's seriously an amazing game. It goes on sale often for about $6 NZD. Definately pick it up, it's worth every hour.

This was a cool game. I love the character design, atleast for the main character.   The gameplay, for the most part, is exciting. With all of the abilities and options you have at your disposal, you feel very powerful. Sometimes, though, you can be a little too powerful. I played through for the first time on the hardest difficulty without a hitch. It's possible to play through the whole game without being seen or killing anyone, but that can get kinda tedious. Why have all of these brutal abilities if you can't use them? As the game progressed I got more ruthless and stopped worrying about not being seen or not killing.   One gripe I have with this game is the skill point collectibles. Since they are necessary to get more abilities, you constantly have to go out of your way to collect them.   The story was good and kept me interested the whole time. The world feels alive.

As a TL;DR for this review, I absolutely reccomend this game for anyone looking for an alternate art style game that delivers compelling stories with perfectly crafted combat and movement systems.  Dishonored, a game created by Arkane Studios, delves into the world of Corvo Attano, a highly respected assassin who must take back Emily Kaldwin, the kidnapped daughter of Jessamine Kaldwin. Using stealth or outright combat, along with a powers tree that is determined by the player, Corvo must make his way through multiple levels to silence those who oppose him, or to find out information of Emily's whereabouts.  The powers allow the player to choose how they play, they can even play without them. But they supply a whole range of attacks and advantages to Corvo that will shape the game world. For example, killing multiple people will riddle the game world with rats that can attack the player, and harsher enemies. A pacifist style player will see less rats, and a calmer world to deal with. These choices of powers come at a cost.  Throughout the world, players can find runes and bonecharms, the runes will supply the player with powers that they want to use, and the bonecharms offer bonuses such as a certain skill lasting longer, or sneaking quieter. These are just few examples. There is also a currency in the game, to buy equipment and upgrade them. Stealing fancy painting or wallets off of guards without their knowledge is just one way a player can expect to make money.  Dishonored is a game that can be played in so many different ways, and can reward you for doing so. Such as achievements and equipment in the game that tailors itself to a specific playstyle. Anyone new or veteran to a stealthy game like this is easily going to fit in, with just a bit of training with the blade and powers, you'll be the next Corvo Attano.  For my summary, the game is rewarding to a player that likes good play or good story, as the game supplies both at a beautifully high standard. Whilst it may no longer be the best, most cutting edge game or engine out there, it is sure to blow the likes of gamers away with its sheer immersion.
I would highly recommend Dishonored, great story, great combat system and just a whole lot of fun. the movement controls were great and the game graphics are beautiful. 10/10

Before I played this game, I was never all that interested in games that require sneak. But, now I have to admit that this game has changed my mindset in the fullest! The game mechanics are great, and the missions are extremely amusing. The lore of the game is well set out, you are an bodyguard who's duty is to protect your empress. You find that the empress has been assassianted and you are the one who is blamed. The whole base game's campaign is your character (Corvo) trying to find and kill the people responsible. Not kidding, this game is one of the best i've seen in a long time. Each level is set up in a way that you can always find multiple ways to complete your objective, and the maps are very interactable. There are side passages, and there are houses that you can take that will either help you find your way to the destination, or lead you to special treasures. All of this is packed into one game, and it makes for a very addicting gameplay. No doubt I think you should purchase it, the game is well worth it.
Can get frustrating at times, especially when it seems like the solution to a problem was hidden in a very strangely specific way, but it is definitely still fun, and worth the price.

One of the few games I wish I could play again for the first time. Such a great game, borrowing elements from other games to create a product greater than it's sum. If you like unique art style, stealth, and the ability to play naughty or nice, this is the game to get.
Great gameplay. Story wasn't that memorable though.

A very stealthy, stealthy game. Can give you the creeps sometimes, especially with the plague-ravaged, zombie-like weepers around. And when I say stealthy, I mean stealthy. Only until later does it happen that you might be able to take a guard head-on, because 6 extra hear what's happening and come to give you a good clobbering. The gameplay is lots of fun, especially during the second playthrough, as then you figure out new ways to beat the guards to death stealthily and kill the target with flair. The story is nothing special, being very linear and and having almost no plot.  Overall: 7/10 An old game still feels pretty fresh.

Do you like games that give you agency and choice in a world? Well Dishonored has delivered that more than any game I've played in the last few years! Every level is a new mini-sandbox, where you can truly define your own path, and experiment with your abilities to some crazy combinations. I've never encountered a game that has given me so many emergent moments, and is something that can provide a genuinely different experience multiple playthroughs.
very fun and not to stressful on computers.

One of the best stealth games I've ever played. People looking for a challenging stealth game should give this one a try. It really forces the player to plan out their moves and use their resources effectively unless they want to be punished harshly for it later in the mission i.e more enemies/weepers, guards are already alerted because of a poor choice, ran out of wires to tamper with machines and so on. Pros: Multiple methods for completing a mission that change the story based on your decisions Beautiful art style and steampunk themed world All skills are viable in this game and none are useless Extremely high replay value via different assassination methods (lethal/nonlethal) You can play as a fish! cons:  AI is pretty dumb, most guards won't check common areas for you Game may autosave when you are falling to your death forcing you to restart the mission ( had it happen twice but wasn't mad about it, I actually laughed) Many areas of the game can be sprinted through with blink and a few mana potions Playing as a rat gets me curb stomped everytime Overall 9/10

Just a tiny bit.   Highly recommended especially for those who likes stealth games. Sneak sneak motheffu.

UPDATE --- Dishonored is literally Dark Messiah of Might and Magic 2. That's good if you liked DMMM but it's also bad because it makes Dishonored not as creative as it first appeared;  Arkane Studios reused 95% of DMMM's gameplay and mechanics. ---  Ah, Dishonored. A game that I was truly anticipating.  I thought Dishonored would be a pseudo-open world game where you roamed Dunwall and you struck at your selected targets like a vengeful spirit.  From the cinematice trailer, I was under the impression that the Outsider freed you, gave you equipment and sent you out to systematically dismatle a heartless, 1984-like, cruel government. Like a Robin Hood of sorts. You see Corvo smoothy parkour rooftops and be an unstoppable force.  Cons --- *Spoliers <* What I got instead was a disappointing cabal who ordered you around and predictably, betrays you.  The Lord Regent is not a malicious, controlling man but rather simply wanted to revitalize Gristol's dismal economy by any means even if that meant removing the ignorant empress.  The targets for the most part have done nothing wrong to you personally and are only killed under the orders of the cabal to further its goals.  And finally ironically the cabal is the only target who should be killed (in high chaos)  Brigmore witches dlc's Corvo does not follow your Corvo's choices *> Spoliers* Also certain sounds, esp NPC sounds are too loud and repetitive.   The AI also is incredibly blind, dumb and deaf: They don't look up, cannot see through glass, don't notice missing objects, don't see thrown objects, cannot hear explosions down the street and have never eaten a carrot in their lives.  The game is very linear and there is no 'mid-chaos' ending.  The levels are too enclosed, rooftops are usually inaccessible so too much time is spent on the ground and very annoyingly, the game often funnels you to certain areas - as in a certain objective/location is only accessible through one path.  Also you are not as 'smooth' as the Corvo in the trailer and are quite clumbersome and have to rely on blink much too often.  The AI can dodge, bash, kick and throw grenades/shoot simultaneously etc while you cannot  The swords reach farther than their models  The Knife of Dunwall dlc - you don't feel like daud  The lore can be easily ignored while still understanding the plot  too easy to counter attack via blocking  Pros --- Overall good quality  Swordfighting is brutal & intense on the appropriate difficulty.  Brigmore witches dlc  Atmosphere and art design  Final Verdict: I was going to give it a 9/10 when I first started the game 6.5/10 by the time I finished it.

Stealth games, especially first person ones, are generally not my thing at all.  This however is something special (once you get past the prologue and the first mission) - each mission area is a small sandbox, how you meet the objectives is up to you: stealth, mayhem or a sneaky murdering mix of the two. You quickly gain access to a selection of tools and abilities that support all of the possible approaches such as sleep darts, proximity mines or mind control.  There are at least 2-3 really different play throughs here for those who want to try all the approaches and earn all of the achievements.  Its not perfect: - melee combat is functional but repetitive - relying on a block and counter attack mechanic. - there are some sections of missions that are mostly just long trudges through tunnels from A to B - It can get frustrating - expect to die quite a lot while trying to work out the right path and approach for each mission, there is always a way though.  Well worth a look at sale prices even if you don't normally like this style of game.  Have excite for the sequel due in 2016

Wow wow wow. Dishonored has been sitting in my queue for the longest and I totally regret that happened. This game was unbelievable. You play a former bodyguard turned assassin who is attempting to clear his name. I won't go into too much more detail but you will be crossed, double crossed and fed red herrings along the way. The story and the way it's presented is a lot of fun. Also unique is there are different endings depending on your play style. Keep the killing to a minimum and you'll get the 'happy' ending. Kill a lot of people and you'll get the not so happy ending. I went with low kills but it was a lot of fun sneaking up on guys and choking them out. In many ways, this a spiritual sucessor to Thief 2. The sneaking & the looting remind me of that game moreso than Thief 3 did (and Thief 4 from what I understand). Level design is excellent with a myriad of ways to get through them. But SAVE YOUR GAME OFTEN. I can't stress this enough because there are times you'll get past a situation and you'll mis click or the blink runs just short of where you want to go and you're surrounded. Another piece of advice. The two story DLCs are completely worth it. I'd argue 'The Brigmore Witches' DLC has the best level design in this game period and is one of the best story DLCs I've ever played. Dishonored gets an easy 10/10 from me and I'll be interested to see how Dishonored 2 compares.

I really don't know what to say about Dishonored. I was in London for the Eurogamer Expo 2012 and, while the twin banners hanging over Earl's Court were impressive, I was more concerned with Mass Effect, Skyrim and more established games. Belive me, it was my loss. Upon getting Dishonored on a whim at a friends recomendation I can say I regret not having paid it more attention. Really the only down points that come to mind are the occasinal silly AI stealth mechanics (though what stealth game doesn't have such problems now and then?) and the Faces. Dear god's the faces! It's like being back in TES IV: Oblivion all over again. Those aside, I can recommend Dishonored wholeheartedly to any fans of stealth shooters with a slightly darker twist to them or fans of steampunk in general (though there's no airships I'm sad to say but your goggles are kickass) The stealth mechanics (barring the odd curiosity) are good, combat is ballanced (as an assassin/bodyguard you know how to handle yourself in a fight but you're not about to take on a whole army by yourself. Not with out some mechanical toys or supernatural help) and the story line and lore are engaging. I find myself wanting to find out more about this city, this world I find myself in. And, much like Oblivion, while the faces may give you nightmares, the scenery will take your breath away. Normally I'd advise against playing any kind of sneaky stealth game in the dead of night with headphones on and lights off unless you're a die-hard horrer fan for fear of what dangerous monsters are lurking around the next corner but, in Dishonored, you are the scariest monster in the shadows. But what kind of monster? One that slaughters indiscriminately or one that slips in and out of the most secure buildings without so much as a whisper?

----Spoiler Free Review---- I don't normally write reviews in any depth, but this game definitely deserves it  An excellent game in an unexplored genre.  Stealth and assasination in most games end up being a side thing, something as an additional objective. Normally poorly implemented. Dishonoured combines both aspects into an integral part of the gameplay, however more importantly it gives you choice.   You can go through the whole game never getting involved in any stealth, getting into multi man fights and taking everything head on, you can play as a regular assasin hiding in the shadows waiting for the time to strike.  But perhaps the one thing that seperates this game the most from any other stealth/assasination based game is the fact that you can go through the whole game without killing a single person. A game The achievement 'Clean Hands' is also a reward for doing so, never killing anyone in a game all about assasination and extensive combat.  The graphics are stylised although realistic, they are generally very nice although not the focus of the game, all the areas that you will visit are extremely detailed  The story is also excellent, although as this is a spoiler free review I cannot go into depths of what will happen or why it is great. One thing to share is how you act directly influences how the game progresses, you have small dialogue options, although those options will be signifcant and even make you pause to think on how you want to respond. Your actions also play a big role in how the game will play out.   For those that don't want to read that I will also put direct stats of what I think the game holds up to   Graphics: 8/10, instead of going for a real life look they went a stylised version Combat Gameplay: 9/10, if you love sword fights, close quarter combats or the like, you'll enjoy it here Stealth Gameplay: 10/10, one of the few games to full on hit the mark in the genre Movement/General Feel: 10/10, The parkour system works perfectly with all the abilities given Story: 10/10, the story is excellent, and changes based on even your smallest actions   Overall if this game has interested you in even the tiniest, buy it, its very cheap too even with all the DLC, look around and pick it up.

Dishonored.  There are few words in the English language that can capture precisely what this fantastic work of art encompasses. It is, at its core, an immersive clandestine first person tale of betrayal, revenge, betrayal, and reconciliation, set in a blend of Steam Punk and Medium Fantasy Renaissance.   Go for the beautiful tapestry and watercolour art, stay for the fantastic gameplay, drink in the ambiance of sinister decay, corruption and desperation, and see if you, too, can earn the 'Clean Hands' achievement. I have. ;>  11/10. Would attend the Boyle's Party again and again.

Dishonored is a game that is set around an assassin seeking redemption after he was framed for the murder of the empress and the abduction of her daughter.  Throughout the game the story is fantastic and all the characters you meet along the way feel very life like with great voice acting and animations. The graphics are absolutely amazing, the world of Dishonored is vivid and alive in front of you. The gameplay is where the game really shines though, although I mentioned that you play as an 'assassin' you do not have to take the stealthy approach, you can simply run straight at a guard and cut him down if you wish. Maybe you want to be stealthy but ruthless, that's fine because you can sneak behind your enemy and slit his throat before he even knows you're there, or maybe you're a kind person that doesn't see the need to kill guardsmen? Great, you can render them unconcious by strangling them and then hide their body so no passing enemy will see them. Obviously, the stealthy approach is far more rewarding, as you will not have to cut your way through wave after wave of guardsmen to reach the objective.  10/10 a must have. Note: To understand the story further and to have more playtime I would highly recommend the DLC The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches, 10/10 for them as well.

Dishonored is one of the games I enjoyed most last year. It has around 10 hours of gameplay and you can play it exactly how you want to! Do you want to be silent? Sure! Use your Blink-spell to get higher up the building and use your crossbow to take out your target. Want to massacre everyone? Just kick in the door and start shooting with your gun, slash with your sword and summon plague-rats to eat your enemies. Don't worry about being shot! Just slow down time and dodge the bullet, after that, just slowly aim your gun on the head of the enemy, shoot and resume time again. You can even finish the game by not even getting noticed and also by not killing anyone! It's all possible!  Remember, every method takes it's time and it's skills. Decide which strategy you like best.  Rating: 8/10 It has some flaws, but it's almost invisible while playing! With the DLC's released you can even listen to the other side of the story. A must-have for people that like different styles of combat.

I haven't beaten Dishonored's main story as I'm writing this, but I'll start off with that first. The story is ♥♥♥♥ing useless. In the 3rd mission in the game, you beat it, and rescue Emily, your [spoileri]daughter[/spoileri] who is kidnapped at the beginning of the game. Then, the rest of the game makes no sense, as you try to clear your name as an assassin, by murdering/kidnapping/torturing your way to freedom! Speaking of freedom, you get a lot of it. In the ♥♥♥♥ing hub map, you get an entire open world to explore! And then, the powers are the best part. Get your infinite mana mods reasy, because these powers are amazing! Example of how I used powers to assassinate a target: I teleported into a window, through a door, poisoned the target's drink, and before his asssistant could call for help, I possessed a rat, and had it maul him to death, as I used slow motion to sprint past every guard in the area, and make it to my getaway boat before I got seen. Also, not killing isn't really that big of a deal, as the main thing it does is make more rats appear, and make more people get infected by the un-named plague, which cannonically doesn't even happen, so you can happily slaughter your way to victory. And the combat definitely needed work. The block/counter attack system works well, but punishes you if you want to play the game you want, becauase if you get ganged up on, you are ♥♥♥♥ed! You can't see what's behind you, and everyone has the same uniform, so you can't tell the gun wielding soldier from the normal minions, which makes sense realistically, but not gameplay wise imo. Also, the Golden Cat. 10/10 would replay again.

So, Dishonored, I have to say one thing first hand, Best. Stealth. Game. Ever. From what I've seen, this game has superb gameplay, and intriguing universe, and a compelling tw- I'll let you find out! Besides that, buy this game, buy it, B-U-Y, and I mean now. With Dishonored’s flexible combat system, creatively eliminate your targets as you combine the supernatural abilities, weapons and unusual gadgets at your disposal. This game was mediocre at best. I beat it with in 14hrs, so it's not much content outside of the achievments. I'm not the type of person that finds replay value in a game or a level just to unlock an achievment. I've killed or nocked out characters in multiple ways over and over just to see if there was going to be an actual consequence. I was under the assumption as i was playing the it was a sort of choose your own adventure style of gameplay. It's not. Ultimatly you are given limited choices, just to further the main story. There are some side quest but the don't affect the gameplay in the least. At most you'll get an achievment for it. Towards the end of the game, I was all out of supplies except for 2 grenades. Since your put in a ituation where you can't exaclty gear up near the end, I thought I might have to start at a previous checkpoint. Now I always play every game on the most difficult setting, even if I've never played the genre before. Playing this game though, it gives you multiple options to get through levels. I was able to sneak around and get the upper hand in the end. So in that respect I think this game is great.  The fighting is questionable at best. I don't like the fact that in order for me to go full assault i am required to buy upgrade after upgrade. At no time did it appear that any of my enemies feared death. I would be surrounded, hit the first guy and then get shot in the head. Since I was on a high difficulty, getting into a sword fight was not a smart option as the NPC's can dodge for days. I was usually reduced to sneak attacks. Tall boys were the bain of my exestince in this game. The only advice I could give is to get to a high vantage point or stock up on explosives.  Is the story worth it.... No. Not at all, it's nothing special and there are a lot of plot holes and unresolved questions. If anything if you want to play thing gme, play it for the powers. I've never been so pleased to watch someone get devoured by a pack of rats before.

This is a first impression review, as I've only placed 3 hours into the gameplay.   After 3 hours, the most notable thing is that stealth is very slow as I'm still working on the first mission after the 'tutorial' mission. Stealth is also very unrewarding, for example a house I went into as a side objective had 5 copies of the same key in various places, one or two per floor. After carefully incapacitating the person who had the one I picked up hanging off his belt, I was somewhat unpleased to find more just waiting for a thief to snatch up.  About an hour later, after finally beating the side objective, I was moving forward to the next side objective and had hidden myself underneath a platform, in a dark crawlspace below. Opposite my entry point, an enemy immediately spotted me through the solid wood and engaged in combat. The mechanics are all there, but they seem not to function correctly.  I ended this playthrough when I encountered one last failed mechanic. I managed to sneak up behind an enemy, more than close enough to reveal the stealth incapacitate icons, and held down control. I blocked since it was bound to the same button, but never took down the enemy. Confused, I tried again, same results, and then this guy turned around to continue his patrol and found me waving my sword around like an idiot.  The man then began trying to dice me up, but I took him down easy. Oddly, even though he never once said a word and didn't scream when he died (like stealth kills produce) three other men showed up.  I am a fan of stealth games, having enjoyed a couple Metal Gear Solids in the past, but though this one portrays itself as a stealth game I will be going in guns blazing, else it might take a month to beat the game.

Tried to like this game. Honest. After playing for some seven hours though, I finally figured out it's pretty buggy. I got close to completing the first mission where I was supposed to kill some religious leader V for Vendetta style, I did the ole' switch'a'roo of the drinks, and then waited. I waited, and waited, and went out, killed some more guys, came back in and waited. Turns out that if you don't play the game the way it wants you to, it takes all of its toys and goes home.  The religious leader guy and his compatriot he planned on poisoning just stood in their room the whole time, complaining about the weather, and about the progression of the World Cup. So they never came out, and after hours of play, I decided that for all its uniqueness, this game gets a 'thumbs down.' Sure, it's graphically stellar, but the missions were too linear, the story was bland and torn out of the pages of several different movies and games, and the dialog, oh lawdy, the dialog. Every character sounds similar, and the dialog felt stilted and disjointed.  It could have been an amazing game, but the dialog and gameplay were bland and boring, and the bug that broke my mission was the final straw.

Take one part powdered milk particles ripped from the dried pop-culture teat that is Steampunk, mix liberally with, in retrospect, a decent understanding of Thief's Legacy compared to other competitors; burn the edges of a standard stealth game moral and power system to remove any sense of flavor between the choices of QUIET GOOD or LOUD BAD and throw it into the broth, then spice with a clichéd child NPC the player should maybe care for and an interesting but mostly red herring Elder God - here to distract you from the lack of substance that several hundred notes or recordings make the illusion of a world of Dunwal out to be.  And voilà! You have a better programed Assassin game than anything Ubisoft could defecate out and stick a overpriced hoodie on within roughly a year.  Nothing you must own, especially not its DLC. However, if you simply NEED another stealth game, please don't pay Bethesda any more than 5 USD.

The gameplay is excellent. Stealth and combat are exciting and unique. The story, however, is reaaaaaalllllyyy bad. The ending gets even worse. Most of the character dialogue is forced and there aren't really any dynamic characters in the game. The dramatic shift in the story is WONDERFUL, but that's the only time (for only like 10 minutes) that any of the characters become interesting.   I was really hoping you'd get that feel of a huge expansive city like Assasin's Creed, but you end up playing on only a handful of really small, limited maps. This really hurts when you hit the invisible walls at the top or sides of the map, or just look in the distance to find cardboard cutout buildings isntead of real models.   Many levels have really clear A, B, or C type choices for pathways, so where you would like to be creative and find new solutions, you kinda get kicked into the mold. This hurts especially in the end, with your typical Evil/Neutral/Good endings.   Overall a disappointment.

Coupled with the fact that like many games the skill tree offer a combination of powers that make the player OP very quickly, the temptation is to tear everyone to pieces and get to the dialogue more quickly. Then the dialogue disappoints to it's back to the grind.  Promising and fun for a bit, pick up if on sale but I wouldn't recommend spending much time here.

Who is this Game For? ================== Dishonored is like Deus Ex and Bioshock had a beautiful child, but not a bright one. It takes a little from several games and doesn't really do anything special with it. Like Bioshock the world created is beautiful and the stealth mechanics are at least on par with Dues Ex, but no were as good as Thief (1998). While not exactly groundbreaking, Dishonored is still an interesting game for Bethesda fans or fans of Bioshock or Deus Ex.  Is it good? ================= Powers are interesting and the horribly overpowered Blink can be quite a lot of fun. The world does look great, despite the character models. There's also the option of neutralizing your targets by methods other than murder, which is something I'd like to see more in games. There is also a lot of story worth reading in books and notes scattered throughout the game, giving the world created a much lived in feel similar to Bioshock. There are a lot of great conversations and recordings in the game as well, with my favorite being when the guards were talking about how Corvo was probably hiding somewhere near them.   Does it have any problems? ======================== I can't really say it's boring, but the story certainly was. When the 'twist' came up, it was expected and I was a little disappointed that I had obviously finished that much of the game so quickly. It didn't help that we have yet another silent protagonist, which makes it tougher to care. The morality system was a major source of contention for me. For starters, it affects Emily's actions and outlook, and it bothers me that it's not explained how she or anyone else found out about whether or not anyone died. Sure, it could have been overheard, but with the ruling power being like it is, that's the sort of propaganda they're likely to spit out, regardless of what happened. Secondly, Corvo is frequently referred to as an assassin, but killing is what you get punished for. I should add that if you decide to go the non-lethal route, you'll be very limited in your choice of weapons.  Art style for the characters is pretty terrible with the exception of Emily and the Empress. Maybe this was done to reflect how monstrous the new regime is and if that's the case, congratulations are in order.   Final Thoughts! ==================== To sum up, it's not a terrible game, but doesn't really deserve to be compared with the titans that are frequently mentioned. Certainly not worth paying full price for, just wait until there's a huge discount on Steam. I'd give it a 3.5, but I don't have that option.  Edit: Personal insults don't explain why you like it or why I'm wrong. Secondly, these are opinions which will vary wildly depending on the experience of the user. I have received many personal insults for giving this game a ‘Not Recommended’. Any one leaving personally insulting comments will be deleted.
