This game have a few minor and major flaws which would not be enough to make it a bad game if it actually had perks. At the end, what we got here is as entertaining as an average game for your smartphone, just a way to pass the time. It does not deserve its impressive rating.  Some dare to compare this game with Deus Ex. Did you consider Deus Ex has musics? The only one I spotted in Dishonored was when I was chased by rats. Did you consider Deus Ex does not have a 'Purchase downloadable content' on its main screen? That Deus Ex characters don't feel the need to pee every 30 seconds?  The main flaws of the game according to me:  The Dark Vision, a tool which allows you to see enemies as well as objects through walls is so essential for the game you have to always let it activated. Too bad it turns your vision into a monochromatic one which turns annoying quite quickly. Maps without it look good more often than not, and yet you're almost obliged to turn them into shades of orange.  The city watch guards are extremely annoying. If you choose to have a stealth/strategic approeach instead of them running into them and killing them, you'll have to see and hear them pee every 30 seconds, repeating the same few sentences throughout the whole game ('Do you think you'll get your own squad after what happened last night?', 'Never doubt it.').  The game has a pseudo-freedom where you can choose to kill people or not yet you're often obliged otherwise incited to steal them. From the screen at the end of the map which display the money you found out of all the money in map without any distinction between found and stolen money, to the fact holding an inconscious/dead body makes you take their money without any choice, this game just offers a highly inconstistent freedom of having a moral or not.  Voice-acting is exagerated, sometimes unbearable like the voice of the heart, a feeling aggravated by the fact she says ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and uninspired stuff ('this place is the end of all thing… and the beginning').  Emily, a character you're obliged to help even though there's almost no reasons in the world not to hate her.   The level design, often great, is sometimes very repetitive.  Now the game gives you the illusion of freedom of movement, yet you're often blocked by invisible walls when you want to explore too much.  It also tries to make you identify to the character you're playing in the same way Half-Life does, except you lose the control of your character in some cinematics, seeing him doing actions which you may not have thought of (like holding the hand of Emily).  I genuinely tried to like this game, but at the end, the only thing I remembered from it was frustation and boredom.

I managed to complete Dishonored, all of the optional content and even replay certain missions again, in less than 10 hours. For a game that at the time cost between £30-40, this game really is not value for money.   The game itself starts off strong, seemingly offering a variety of paths, both in how to complete your mission and how to play the game.   You play as Corvo, the bodyguard to the Empress of a steam punky like empire who's main source of fuel is whale oil. Shortly after returning home from a mission, the Empress is assassinated (good work bodyguard), and her daughter and heir abducted. It turns out the assassins hired to kill the Empress and kidnap her daughter were hired by a triumvirate of high ranking members of the Empire who frame you for the crime.   Naturally, you escape and try to avenge the Empress, save the Empress' daughter and clear your name.   Storywise, the game is pretty solid, a little clichéd if you want to be overly critical, but nothing majorly is wrong with the story.   To me however, the story is the strongest thing going for the game.   Most missions can be completed in a variety of ways, ranging from killing people, which effects the game's ending, rendering them unconcious, which also effects the game's ending, or sneaking past them entirely. You can even choose to spear all the traitors who framed you, fancy that.   However, the game's combat is notably easy. You are given a pretty impressive arsenal of weapons, that means even if you are caught out of stealth, you can defend yourself more than admirably, or simply run off. Furthermore, the leveling system allows you to purchase spells, that only increase your level of power, from having people consumed by rats, to blinking silently around the map.   If you are really bad at the combat, constantly getting caught while hiding and can't get the hang of the spells there is one final tactic you can employ. Running. And I don't mean 'I'll run away, lose them and come back.' you can literally just sprint past enemies, most of which are armed with swords and you seem to be faster than them anyway, from start to finish. I found, even on the last mission, that I could simply run through enemies who took so long to notice me I was half way down the corridor by the time they began chase, and almost out of sight by the time they started running.   The endings also seem a bit generic, but I shan't get into them for that would be a massive spoiler.

Dishonored is a love child of Bioshock and Arkham Asylum.

Though I got Dishonored during the Free Weekend, I had the time of my life playing this game. At first I thought it was going to be something like the Assassin's Creed saga, but it's an entirely different thing. It tells a tale of darkness coming light, where the true darkness is in your allies, enemies, and the people. You must trust either your unlocked magic abilities (which helps you on your stealth A LOT) or your timing in open combat (which is a horrible choice). Sure the game is creepy (the rats, the rats especially), and it's very dark, but it's a masterpiece with a rich story compared to other stealth or adventure games.

In the tradition of Thief and System Shock, this game is a fun, immersive, interesting first person stealth game with a dark, engaging story, interesting characters, and a wonderful setting. This game is quite short, and replayability is limited. While everyone should try non-violent and non-lethal for the ending, the lethal options are much more interesting, and are worth the slightly darker result. All in all, challenging and fun and worth a play through for anyone who liked Bioshock, System Shock, or Deus Ex (the original).

To be honest, I had not paid any attention to the fact that I was playing a game by the folks who created Arx Fatalis, an overwhelmingly decent homage and tribute to Ultima Underwold. Dishonored is a fantastic mesh of old-school Thief games with a pinch of Assassin's Creed and possibly a few other great games I can't recollect or may have not played yet. The storyline, though others on the reviews will say is so-so, isn't so-so at all. It's not the best in the world, but it fits the world of Dishonored quite well, and that world is something nearly created from scratch. As a kid, watching fantasy-based Disney films or any other sort of animated or live-action movie not necessarily taking place on earth was a truly amazing experience. The experience of being transported to those other worlds with a child's impenetrable imagination to real life distractions. As an adult, I find it difficult to do that without a lot of effort, but Dishonored made me feel like a kid again in respect to losing my surroundings and traveling somewhere else for a spell. And the replayability is extremely high due to the multiple (more than two) ways to complete a mission. The nice touch being most of the assassinations don't have to end with an actual death, however the non-lethal route ramps up the challenge in a very fitting manner.   10/10, not going to say something that rhymes with ten at the end....here.

You can ignore the time i have speant on this game from here, as i played it for a lot longer on the ps3  Dishonored is a supernatural stealth action exploration assassin simulator. Even with playing it repeatedly i am still able to be creative 'sadistic' with my killings. And even creative with my evasion of detection. The graphics are pleasing to me. SPOLIER ALERT POSSIBLY!!! The 'moral choice' aspect is not as clear cut as people think. Its not a matter of killing is bad and not killing is good. You can kill all of the main targets and no one else. And you can still get the low chaos 'good ending' What the Moral situations is. Is that You slaughter everyone. The dead bodies attract more rats. Those rats multiply Thus spreading more and more plague, All the while the empress's daughter is young and impressionalbe and all she knows is to slaughter literally everyone. This game does not speak against revenge. It more says. Don't be a ♥♥♥♥  THE DLC!! dunwall trails. Not for everyone, but i very much enjoy it. There is something within the trails for everyone, But they are only fun little minigames essentially. ' race train' Explosive pigeon shooting' Ultimate burglar simulator' Supernatural street battle simulator' Time stop chain reaction murder everyone simulator' And a few other, and even some tough to get achievments if you like that kinda thing. After playing more of this game, I have much more to say about it. The gameplay is really fun and versatile, but the story is disappointing. There's not much of an emotional connection with the characters and even the world. The fact that low chaos and no killing is encouraged even in the storyline, but not rewarded with satisfying gameplay that comes from a high chaos run is also what holds this game back. This game is a good example of the inverse of Bioshock by having very fun gameplay (on higher chaos levels) with a poor storyline. Learning more about all the charaters and even the protagonist would help. Corvo either needs a stronger personality or to allow the players to project their personalities through him.  Good: -Lots of fun ways to kill people -Graphics are nice -Interesting world Bad: -Playing non-lethal is encouraged but boring -Bland story and characters, including the protagonist  I give it a 7.5/10

When I first saw the trailer for this I was stoked. A man out for revenge who happens to be a steam-punk-ninja-sorcerer. What's not to love.  After playing the game through twice there were far too many gameplay inconsistencies, idiotic development choices, etc. for me to give Dishonored a positive review.    Don't tell me I'm a badass and force me to play nice   If you've seen the trailer for Dishonored it is quite a sight. It's very well rendered, excellent voice acting, top notch action, raw and visceral both visually and emotionally. Gameplay footage showed Corvor performing unbelievably brutal assassinations, and when you play the game yourself, you over hear guards talk constantly about what an undeniable badass you are.  'You've never seen Corvo fight? The man is a whirlwind of death.' 'If you see Corvo don't try to fight him alone.' 'I saw Corvo go toe-to-toe with a weeper grizzly bear with nothing but a plastic spork.'  Then after getting out of the tutorial you realize there is a good and bad ending to the game. Every kill you do leads you down the path of the bad ending. Which is the same as losing the game in my opinion.   Don't tell me this is going to be a game about brutal vengance at the end of a sword and force me to play like a pacifist.  Playing the game this way is painfully boring as this locks you out of most of your weapons.     Dumb Development choices   Dishonored sports a power system similar to Bio Shock or Deus Ex. Runes/skill points are spent to unlock and upgrade ablitilies.  In addition to this you find bone charms which are amulets that Corvo can equip to give him passive buffs.  There are 35 charms total in the game and most of them are functionally worthless.  'Falling Star' Drop assassinating recharges mana by 20%.  'Clockwork Malfunction' Enemy grenades take slightly more time to explode. 'Plague Affinity' Damage by weepers grants a small amount of mana.  Falling star is incentivizing the player to do something that will hurt their chances of victory, ie: killing.  Clockwork Malfunction...if the enemy is throwing grenades at you, you're doing stealth wrong.  Plague Affinity? Who would deliberately get attacked by an  enemy to get a small amount of mana?  There are many more in the wikia but it's very clear to me  the developers didn't put much thought into Corvo's abilities or the kind of game they wanted to make.   This is further shown by the fact that this is a line-of-sight stealth game in 2014. No light meter. You just make sure a solid object is between you  and your target's vision.  Yet in the game Corvo can extinguish candles changing the lighting in a room...for some reason.  Also hand grenades and quite possibly the  loudest pistol in the world...in a stealth game?  The ending is pretty anti-climactic. Pick it up if it's 70% off or more. But it's just not a very good game.
Worth to buy. Regretted not buying the full pack. Tumbs up.=)

Dishonored has achieved the perfect mix of stealth, action and player choice.  Stealth is exciting, and puts enough power in your hands to make you feel like a true assassin. The non-lethal options for targets are exciting and add great gameplay. And if you're stuck in a croner with no way out, Dishonored also has great combat options that flow together extremely well. Both action and Stealth can be heart pounding, yet also immensly satisfying,   While Dishonored's storyline is not the greatest, it still holds its own, and is the King in terms of lpayer choice. Not only does dishonored offer different endings, but THE GAME CHANGES AS YOU PLAY, which means you get to experience the consequences or rewards of your actions first hand. It's a quality that very few games offer, even ones that are praised for storylines (like 'The Last of Us'). I hope Dishonored's Chaos system is one we seee in many future games.

Dishonored starts out with a unique alternate world setting - a plague infested island empire that employs elixirs and steampunk technology (I just don't get people's fascination with steampunk) to prevent and fight the plague and its victims (weepers = zombies). The Player - You get several cool powers and a large amount of minor player improvements achieved as side quests. You are also given several spy gadgets for a variety of ways to kill. The Story - The story is average, but cliche and predictable. The World - This is where the game is lacking. The world is not as open, interactive, or drenched in lore as you might like it to be. This game starts with a cool setting - an island empire, but you are confined to the handful of mission regions. In the game you have a base/home area which is much smaller than it shoudl be. The lore in this game is extremely wanting, throughout the game you can pick up TONS of notes, book pages, etc. (I read every single one for the first three missions until I realized they had very little to do with lore). Throughout the game almost no lore is revealed about key characters except that they had 'a very different and mysterious past'. The Missions - The missions allow you to get creative with your powers and gadgets, but overall they are linear. There are 9 missions in the campaign, they are each somewhat long, but it's that much worse for a game that is unforgiving if you are detected once. You will be forced to slay all the enemies that are called over to you, or reload. There really needed to be some kind of vanish ability, because blink really didn't cut it when the NPC can throw grenades at you if you try and get away to a rooftop. The Gameplay - Some of the game mechanics were really annoying. It is really difficult to act and stay hidden. You can't use many things as distractions like you would think, throwing a bottle or making something blowup far away from you can cause the NPCs to go straight to your location even if you are hidden away. I don't know why the game acts this way sometimes, while other times distractions work fine. You are given only two ways to incapacitate NPCs (not killing) shooting with sleep darts or strangling from behind. This game is mostly about waiting and being patient, (You need to save A LOT). The missions are long and one wrong move and the NPC guards are all over you. I would have enjoyed the game if it was more about stealth and less about winning fights with NPCs.  I give this game a 7.5/10

This is the best Stealth/Action game I've ever played. Although I'm a Stealth fanatic, I think everyone would enjoy this game if not for the Stealth, then for the action, and if not for the action, then for the story. This game can be completed in 15~30 hours depending on your play style and difficult; however, the session is easily prolonged by the replayability. This game is all about options, and with that, consequences. Even though this isn't an open-world game, you'll find yourself staying longer in levels due to optional missions/objectives.   The Action/Stealth aspect of this game can speak for itself. Gameplay is all about options: should you kill, or should you subdue? Should you act as a blood-thirsty spirit, wreaking havoc across Dunwall, or should you act as a spectral entity, accomplishing goals with minimal lethality? The options are endless; the concept is original; the combat is as fluid as you want it to be.   As for the story, I had a true sense of grief, a feeling seemingly unfamiliar to me, but strikingly nostalgic; the end of the game will also strike you the same way. The Story, like the combat, is how you shape it; it correlates with the type of player you are. Should you become blood-thirsty, and vengeful, the story will respond accordingly.

Dishonored is the Thief game that is really well done, gameplay, story, characters and art direction. Afer completing the game using non-lethal takedowns, I found that the game was really enjoyable and found myself constantly thinking about getting back to that world, to discover more and just be part of it again.  The opening sees your lover, the Lady Empress murdered before you and her daughter taken and hidden away. Your put in prison, but you escape and that's where the game begins. It took me around 30 hours to complete the game, as I took my time and explored the world. What I found was a heavy detailed world, a world rich in history and lore. I often wanted to go and see the other places and see new people and have big adventures.  You play a High Protector uh Corvo... Jones! You play as Corvo Jones, basically a body guard to the empress and he daughter. After your escape from prison you join some others who want to get revenge on the ones that killed the empress and you are given nine targets to see fit as you choose. You can either play as a mass murderer or a silent shadow that leaves everyone alive except your targets and then, you don't have to kill then but choose to have them face a fate that would be worse than death.  After playing 108 hours, I found that the game was really quite enjoyable on three play throughts, 2 low chaos and 1 high. The sounds and art design is really beautiful, that oil painting look of the world is what keeps drawing your eye to the city scapes, or the people that inhabit the world.  Corvo Jones has a really nice movement, it's fluid and smooth and has a nice bounce when he jumps. The game ran at a steady 60fps and never crashed once. With all the details cranked up, you'll find that this game is rock steady. I use tiamat 7.1 headphones and the sound from this game is quite impressive, nice beefy lows and great stereo pleacement make this game a joy to listen and play.  What I didn't like about it was that it ended, I just wanted to stay in the world and be with the characters that inhabited my life and explore more of the city. I would highly recommend this game to anyone that likes open ended and fun gameplay.

DISHONORED! Framed for an assassination of a monarch, become a vengeful shadow to clear your name and find the killers! Play how you want to! Slaughter everybody that stands in your way without mercy! Stealth and subdue your way to your objectives! Rely on your strength and aim, or invest in supernatural powers! Teleport from shadow to shadow! Summon hordes of bloodthirsty rats! Possess animals or even others to do your bidding! Warp the very fabric of time! Choose your path! Join the Dark Si... er wrong game. DISHONORED! 9 brutal stealth kills out of 10!

Though it's a tad easy on lower difficulties it's still a really fun game. Any experienced stealth player may find themselves self-appointing challenges to make it more interesting. But to go with your guns blazing hot is still never a good idea in this game. The uses of the environment and your skills and magic makes this game fun to play. Upgradeable abilities and gadgets are a key to finding new ways to be non lethal, not get caught, or blow someone to bits. The different ways to complete a mission also help with some excitement and the replayability.  Story - Pretty Good Fun? - Yeah! Gameplay - Awesome Visually - Awesome Replayability - Great 92/100

I don't care much about stories in games and Dishonered has a very predictable one and as with all games, not a very good one. But it's told in a compelling way, which made me interested in the story. As which most games that make story important, it does break the gameplay. In Dishonered it didn't bother me as much as I usually am. The gameplay is pretty good, you can choose different ways to solve a mission. The story suggests the ending is dependent on your style. I'm still in the process of figuring out if that is true. I'm now playing it a second time. It is not your regular shooter, and also not your regular stealth game, it does it all with a twist. The game is a real joy to play, but I doubt I will finish it for a second time. On a scale of 10, it gets a 7 - A joy to play, slightly better than average, not a must play

To any of you who played the original Thief games back in the days of early 2000's FPS games, DIshonoured feels a true throwback to those days (Whether intentionally or not) I felt a great sense of nostalgia playing this game. Each level provides a multitude of ways to gain access to the next area and complete your object, I went for the pacifistic stealth approach and tried to avoid killing, instead opting for silent non lethal takedowns, but the option is there to go in running & gunning if you want. The powers system adds a great game mechanic that only adds to this, for example, you can use blink (a power that allows you to instantaneous dash/teleport to wherever your cursor is looking) to traverse rooftops and feel like a true ninja, or you can use possession to enter the body of a rat or a fish and find your way into otherwise unreachable areas through small vents & tunnels. The sense of empowerment you get when fighting in combat is immense, there's nothing that makes you feel more like a bad ♥♥♥ than parrying an incoming sword attack, slowing down time to avoid a gun shot, using blink to close in on your opponents and clearing out a room without even getting a scratch. It truely is FUN to play with, and that's what the game is all about right?   The plot moves along at a decent place, unlike some games (Mass Effect 1's Citadel for example) you don't tend to get stuck in the same place for very long which avoids monotonous gameplay. The whole story of the game allows you to empathize with the lead character 'Corvo,' and really feel his desire for vengeance. My only gripe is I wish the game had been a bit longer, otherwise a great game and I hope for a sequel.

An absolute joy to play. After your first run, you will COMPELL yourself to play another go, and maybe even another go right away to see what else you can do. The gameplay is absolutely amazing. It's just a shame that while the plot is sufficent enough to keep the game afloat, it's not in the same class as its amazing gameplay.

One of the best stealth games in years. It reminded me of both Thief and the latest Deus Ex game. There are not a lot of missions, but they're very long and with a lot of options and side quests to explore. The Knife of Dunwall DLC is also of a very high quality.

A free-form stealth extravaganza. Sneaking through streets of guards, exploring forgotten areas of an abandoned city and finding the most creative way to take down your target are the main ways to enjoy Dishonored. Getting into a showdown with a dozen guards is never anything but awkward to deal with and - quite rightly for a stealth game - has the self-imposed feeling of failure all over it.  While each mission takes place in a small open world, full of secrets to find, don't expect a massive playtime from this title; I've racked up 33 hours from two reasonably thorough playhtorughs. Speaking of two playthroughs, it should be mentioned that Dishonored proudly wears the ever-so-stylish shoulder pads of a Binary Moral Choice System. While it doesn't do alot to aid the story, it has the best gameplay implementation of a moral choice system I've ever played. Rather than basing the ending on cumulative number of kills throughout th game, Dishonored has a 'chaos' rating which can be raised or lowered from mission to mission. As well as subtly changing the game's challenge, this means you can go crazy killing during the first half of the game and still get the 'good' ending by going pascifist for the rest.  Overall, with its characatured art style, steampunk environments and truly stealth-focused design, Dishonored is a great gaming experience. Just don't expect to able to sink all you time into this title.
So great game. Love it <3

This is a game where however you decide to deal with the people in your way, it can work. You want to sneak by him? Stab him in the back? Duel him? Throw a grenade at him? Feed him to the hungry rats for dinner? Knock him out? Throw him into a river? Throw him off a building? Teleport by him? Cut him in half? Put a bolt in him?  Let's see, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, yes, and yes.

Dishonored was my first venture into stealth games and needless to say it got me hooked. Though the story is not original (you must avenged yourself and your murdered loved one), it was strong and interesting enough to keep the game going. What separates Dishonored from other stealth games is how it allows you to be as creative as you wish to complete a level. You can be either a dark assassin out for blood, a pragmatic avenger who kills only when necessary or a man who ignores the innocent but ensures that death is a gift far too merciful for those who wronged him. And that's only part of Dishonored's charms. You can use you supernatural abilities to get ahead or destroy your enemies without breaking a sweat, or simply use your mortal skills to stab or sneak past the obstacles that lay on your way or combined both if you please.  There are consequences of course for each action but that only ensures that this games replay ability. The PC version is quite decent and the art direction is amazing - combining steampunk with 19th century architecture makes for a beautiful and yet haunting City of Dunwall. Eschewing picture realism, the world is done in such a way that it evokes a paint like quality and that makes you feel as though you're playing through an oil painted canvas. The universe has its own backstory and all the little detail that makes Dishonored feel alive and creepy and so interesting to explore. This elevates the game from being just another AAA game. You want to know more than just Corvo's desire for vengeance, want to know more about the Outsider, about that mysterious assassin who murdered the Empress, why has a city once so great fell so low, what was in Pandyssia, why does Granny Rags is reduced so...and so much more.  The game mechanics are smooth and quite intuitive and despite having many abilities and skills under your belt, it never once felt confusing or bloated. The way it was designed ensures that you truly feel like a badass (sort off) assassin out for justice.   The DLC - especially Knife of Dunwall and the Brigmore Witches - are a must add. These two are what DLCs are meant to be, a worthy addition to the main game that improves the familiar and yet enhances it. I recommend for anyone who are interested to get the Dishonored GOTY edition for the fullest experience. Trust me, you won't regret it.
Did not like this game at first look....looked very cartoony and weird...so never played it for ages...bored 1 night tried it..luved it...i even bought the addons.

Played through the first couple of missions and I have to say I really enjoy the game so far.  There is such variety in how you can tackle the objecives that I can see a few replays in the future.With all of the large open world sandbox games that are available these days it is a nice change of pace to be led and driven by a story that admittedly isn't amazing and mind blowing, though it is just interesting enough that I will be sticking around to see how it ends. Also to see how many different endings the game has.  Gameplay is smooth and easy to learn but hard to master. The stealth aspect seems to work really well and the action side of combat is great too for when you feel like running headfirst into danger. The music is spot on for building suspence as you try and stealth your way through the missions and the can cause panick when you suddenly get spotted by that guard that snuck up on you from around the corner!  Overall I would say that if you enjoyed Assassins Creed games and Skyrim (for it's combat/fps style) then this is a mixture albeit more linear of those two games in my opinion.

There are still things that I'm still to encounter, like the entire Granny Rags plot, and I'm yet to play the DLC, but this game has provided so much entertainment and really surprised me.

Dishonored is a beautiful game. The art style is magnificent and the graphics sense is phenomenal. The story is well-crafted and the gameplay is perfect. The story takes place in a plague ridden city called Dunwall, you are the bodyguard (Lord Protector) of the Empress, Jessamine Kaldwin, you, Corvo Attano, are wrongfully accused of the murder of the Empress and are required to set things right for the future of Dunwall and a 10 year old girl named Emily Kaldwin, whom you care for and protect with all your power. Dishonored has a very large variety of supernatural elements which have been given to you by an otherworldly being, The Outsider, neither good, nor evil and watches everything, including Corvo with 'great intrest' and sometimes gives you clues if you explore the world enough. The game has a very clever 'Chaos' system that is the pinnacle between evil and good, Low Chaos: your allies will be more friendly, there will be less guards, less rats and less weepers (plague victims), High Chaos: More rats, more weepers, more guards and allies will be less grateful for your help, this gameplay mechanic is very important, which I really like.   The game is ridiculously easy though, once you have collected enough Runes to buy all the Powers, you can kill everyone instantly before you can say 'The Outsider's Mark', but I have recently completed the game without killing anyone and it's safe to say the game offers a lot more challenge if you try the game that way without killing every enemy in your path, and I prefer not killing anyone.  Then there's the case of glitches which I'm glad to say that Dishonored has literally none, unless you count the ragdoll physics if you put them in a certain object incorrectly and a bizarre texture pop-in on peoples faces, even if you're staring right at them which is pretty weird.  Overall, Dishonored is amazingly made and deserves much more attention from gamers than it has since it came out, it may be very short and easy but it's damn well fun and in my all-time favourite games, well done Arkane. My final opinion and verdict for this game is a generous 8/10, if it wasn't so short and the texture pop-ins and the varius other minor problems, I would be giving this masterpiece 10/10, hopefully Arkane can fix all these minor problems in Dishonored 2, which I am extremely hyped for! (Don't mess it up Arkane, me and the rest of the Dishonored fans are counting on you!)  People who enjoy a gripping story, strong stealth elements and extremely open exploration then you guys NEED to pick up this game, you won't regret it, trust me. For new players, enjoy it!

Dishonored is as tasty a game as you can get right now without dropping Sasha Grey's panties. A near perfect game, it takes a lot from Half Life 2 and smushes it up with some Bioshock mentality. It really doesn't do as good a job as either, but it is a totally sweet ride with a lot of replay value and a very strong story/plot.  If you have the cash and just aren't sure if this game is worth it, then I can reassure you that you will be WELL entertained. Otherwise, this game should be saved up for and bought as soon as you can.  Totally worth it.

Very fun!  Story: Great tone and mood throughout. This game is amazing at world-building. You'll feel like you're really there. The missions are sort of contrived and the pace feels very rushed. Take your time or the game will be over before you know it.  Gameplay: Definitely not bad. remaining undetected is pretty tedious and time consuming. The game rewards you for being stealthy and fighting is just the worst. The most thrilling part of gameplay is using your special abilities to circumvent enemies.  Graphics: A little dated by now, but pretty good for 2012. If my eyes don't deceive me, it's on the Unreal 3 engine, so it looks very similar to BioShock infinite with it's comic-book feel. I personally like the way it looks, but it's not for everyone. Just look at the damn screenshots.  Sound: Music and SFX are on point. Not amazing, but done very well. You get a very immersive experience, and the sound plays a huge role. Some SFX can get a little repetitive such as the 'See through walls' spell that makes the same 'RASH LICE!' sound EVERY TIME you activate it, which is frequently.  Overall: People compare this to Half Life 2. I'd say that's accurate, but if HL2 is a 10/10, this game is an 8/10.

Most of my experience with this game was on Xbox 360, but having played a few hours of it on PC as well, I think I can review it.  The storyline of this game is pretty great. I found myself stepping into Corvo's shoes and letting the storyline suck me in. It's very different from most games out there, and you can tell that the developers put a lot of thought into it.  From a gameplay standpoint, I loved it. This game gives you the freedom to play it one of two ways; stealthily, which is always my preference, or you can go in 'guns blazing' and kill everyone that stands in your way. Either way, it's hella fun, and I didn't find myself running into too many bugs or weird glitches that hampered gameplay.  Visually and auditorily, this game is great. On ultra settings that game comes to life and looks pretty fantastic. The in-game sound effects are on point as well, and pair together with the graphics to create an immersive atmosphere.  All in all, I think anyone who's interested in this game should give it a go. I seriously doubt you'd regret it.

Acting as an arcade stealth more so than a simulator, dishonored doesnt punish its players for there choices. Although story shaping does occur, you can crawl through the shadows, traverse the heights or flatout grab the bull by the horns any time you want throughout.  Set in a steampunk city, a victim of injustice, the player sets out to right the usual wrongs only to discover yet again he has become an even bigger pawn in someone elses game. Your find unlike its stealth counterparts the player isnt accompanied by nifty bond gadgets, in dishonored these are replaced with upgrgadable powers. Ranging from xray vision to the ability to possess minds, your welcome there addition to smooth your path map to map. accompanying the cool powers and for any of us not really the mage type will be the familar gun, steal, arrow and explosives although a mixture of both ultimately lends to a better and more fun experience.  Both tool types are upgradable at the vendors but players are also rewarded with various power ups to aid there quest. Do be aware though regarding choice of powers as this game only has so many runes which isnt entirely a bad thing when you consider this and your choices pave the way for replayability.  Dishonored is still even now very pleasing to the eye graphically, fluid in action and reaction and a good experience to be had for any gamer. DLCs or not, this game easily and firmly ticks the thumbs up box.

Thousands lie dead in the streets of Dunwall. The rotting piles of corpses pile almost to the rooftops. Crows pick at the few bodies not consumed by disease. Two men remain, members of the palace guard. As they wade through the mounds of men, women, and children, they have only one thing to say. 'Shall we gather for whiskey and cigars tonight?' 'Never doubt it.' 10/10

One of the best games that I have ever played. Love the art style and the mood. You really feel like you're in a crappy, dying dystopia that's been struck with the plague.  Gameplay is pretty fun. There's stuff that you'd expect in a stealth game. Stuff like shadows affecting gameplay, sneaking, and detection from enemies if you're too loud. But the fact that you have magic to teleport, summon rats, stop time and other stuff at your disposal makes this game unique.  The levels for each chapter is one of it's best qualities because unlike other stealth games where the route is always the same, the levels in this game are designed to have multiple entrance ways, routes and methods of infiltration. With this trait, exploring the map is encouraged, especially if you're planning to do a 'no detection' route.  Another cool thing about this game is the chaos system that's implemented into to game. In a way, it could be compared to the karma system like in the PS3 game 'inFamous' (another favourite game of mine). The thing is... the amount of chaos you accumulate throughout your walkthrough not only affects the outcome of the game but it also determines the condition of the world. High chaos (kill lots) makes the world more crappier than it already is and more enemies are present (makes sense, cutthroat on the loose = more guards), while low chaos (no killing) makes the mood less depressing and less enemies are present. Long story short: your actions shape the fate of the world and its citizens.  But it's not a perfect game... it has a flaw: the story.  The story is decent, the classic 'I got blamed for someone's murder and now I'm out for revenge' type of story, but the problem is that there is only 10 story missions. Sure there are DLCs that sort of extend the story, but it just felt like it could've done better (like maybe add a M. Night Shyamalan-esque twist).   I would like to talk about the characters, but I suck at describing them.  Long story short:  Game is great  Go buy it if you haven't.

A game that is greatly affected by the choices you make, Dishonored is the amazing story of Corvo, the Empress's bodyguard who is framed for her murder. After escaping prison, your primary goal is to rescue Emily, the rightful heir and probably your best friend.  What you do past that is all up to you. Sneak around and diplomatically get rid of your enemies, or exact revenge with a bloodbath and plague of ravenous, infected rodents. The choice is yours. There's many magical upgrades and abilities Corvo can gain throughout the story that will help you either be a silent assassin or the feared destroyer.  10/10 a brilliant first person RPG.
This was a great game to play. I loved the story, the gameplay, the game length, everything can be rated a 100/100 in my opinion.

The world is gorgeous, and the music and sound complement it perfectly. I absolutely love the mechanics; you can really do some creative things in this. The lore, from the history of the empire, to the science of the world, is superb. On top of all this, the game has a ton of replayability. There are almost always several ways to go about traversing the levels, or taking out enemies creatively. The only thing I wish was a bit more in-depth is the detection system; it's so close to being very realistic (it's the best I've seen in any narrative-based game), but there are slight occasions in which I feel like AIs see me too easily, or don't see me at all.   That last bit isn't enough at all to persuade me from calling this my favorite game I've ever played.

I'm torn on whether I would recommend this game or not. It's fun, no doubt. But it's really nothing new or special. It's VERY similar to the new thief with more of a steampunk twist. If you're big into steampunk, then yes, get it. There is some replay value, but I couldn't force myself to play again. Don't get me wrong, it's a well made game, but put it on your wishlist and wait for it to go on sale, so if you hate it, you won't hate yourself.  When I first started the game, I tried to be all stealthy and get the highest scores, but toward the end I was so bored of it that I was just running through levels, slaughtering enemies as fast as I could. You won't be able to exercise all of your options with the first playthrough, which is where the replay value comes in. There are plenty of achievements for you hunters out there, but it's not my bag.   When it's all said and done, yes, I would recommend this game... IF you can get the GOTY for less than $20.

This is a typical one of those 'I originally got this on the 360 and beat it a few times before deciding my steam library also needs it'  When I was getting this game at first, I thought that I was getting a stealth game. And it's true that the stealth in this game is fantastic, with good ways to measure your enemies awareness, and easy to predict what you can/cannot do in terms of how the game will decide if an event triggers the awareness of an NPC (other games are very arbitrary in this regard, so it's worth mentioning)  All of that being said, it's very difficult to play this as a stealth game.  As I've said, it's not because there's anything wrong with the stealth per se. It's difficult to play this as a stealth game because the combat is just so satisfying, moreso the later in the game you are, when you're blinking around the map, possessing your enemies to make them shoot their friends and jerry-rigging the traps that were set to kill you so that they instead kill everyone that isn't you.  Fortunately you can replay missions to try for the stealth achievement after you accidentally slaughter everyone.

Dishonored is THE BEST Stealth game I've ever played, and here's why: -The plot and universe of the game are both engrossing, developed, and remarkably done, inspired by 19th-century London and Edinburgh and worthy of its own novel. -The gameplay combines awesome magic spells, customizeable gadgets and weapons, swordplay that is satisfying and robust, and enemies and NPCs that are believable and challenging. -Levels allow for multiple methods of completion, ones that are not always obvious and promote satisfying exploration and experimentation. -Detection is easy to understand and not easy to take advantage of, promoting skill rather than exploitation. -Everything looks beautiful, from character models to expansive, gritty buildings. -Your decisions matter. The game can end in multiple different ways.  You can cast a spell where you can stop time and walk around enemies frozen in time, plucking bullets and arrows from the air. You can teleport from ledge to ledge, shadow to shadow, as you stealthily move closer to your objective. And you WILL feel a rush of wonderful excitement upon success in this game, a success that comes often but must be worked for. I RECOMMEND THIS GAME WHOLEHEARTEDLY, ranking (in my book) above stealth games like Hitman, Deus Ex, and Metro.  The announcement of Dishonored 2 is no reason not to get Dishonored. It's a wonderful award-winning game that deserves playing. Corvo Attano has been Dishonored... What will you do?

This game is an action game at it's heart, with a lot of stealth elements built on top. Enviornements are nice and open, with several differant ways to complete your objective. I bring this up first, because that's one of the best parts of the game.   The story is about an assassin/bodyguard named Corvo, who's set out to right the wrongs that were done to the royal family he was supposed to protect. You get a sword, a gun, and plasmid-like (read: Bioshock) powers that let you do super human things. This leads in to the stealth aspect. All objectives give you a wide open path that you can choose to roll right up, unload your old timey pistol, and swordplay your way through a sea of corpses. You can also use your powers to teleport, possess people and animals, and slow down time to stealthily move past enemies. Or hell, do both. That's what I did.  This game is great. It goes on sale all the time, so you owe it to yourself to spend the 5 bucks or whatever and pick it up. It's a solid ten-hour romp with decently fleshed out characters, and a pretty good plot.

It draws immediate comparisons to the Thief series, but doesn't quite earn the pedigree. The problem with throwbacks is that they often dredge up vestigial gameplay quirks without managing to solve them in light of more recent game design. Mark of the Ninja, a standout among its stealth contemporaries, sees fit to exhume and discard most of its roots; what results is a much-needed course correction on how stealth games approach the ebb and flow of tension.  In the past, as it is with Dishonored, stealth games suffered from an emergent reliance on the player's foreknowledge of levels in order to succeed. Patient players who observed their surroundings could get by if they were not bothered by the glacial pace of such an approach, but the impulse to quick-load once spotted by a guard remained, especially in first-person stealth games.  Not that Arkane doesn't try to solve these issues; it's just that their approach is often self-defeating. Protagonist Corvo is is gifted with gameplay amenities such as Blink (the ability to teleport a short distance) and Time Freeze. He is also much more lethal than the stealth protagonists that came before him--a skilled player can dispatch several guards with ease, while such odds would mean certain death for the Thief series' Garrett.  While it is absurdly easy for the player to shoot and stab their way across Dunwall, the designers clearly want you to be sneaky. Killing people in Dishonored produces Chaos, the byproduct of the game's rudimentary moral calculus. So while the player can easily survive a run-in with a guard if they are spotted, the only real choice they are left with--despite the slew of abilities available to them--is whether or not to quick load the last save and try again.   In the end, the game's stubborn insistence on almost entirely diegetic stealth feedback negates any advantage the player might have had with Blink, etc. One wonders why they didn't go even further and write quick loading into the game narrative with a Foresight ability, ala Prince of Persia or Braid. At least then a game where the goal is to be stealthy--but getting caught is of little consequence--would respect my time.

When I originally saw this game and the gameplay I thought. Eh... It looks okay but not really stiring up any interest in me. I ended up buying it in the recent steam winter sale and Ive got to say... Its absolutely fantastic. Im currently about 2/3 through it and I am really enjoying it. It does extremely well with a feeling of player freedom. alot of games attempt to develop a sense of freedom when it comes to execution of tasks and alot fail. However Dishonored really give a genuine feeling.  Positives:  + beautiful graphics and world design (honestly the world feels great to move around in)  + Interesting and fun game mechanics (my honourable mention goes to the supernatural powers)  + Alot of dialouge from surrounding characters (they will talk with eachother and makes the world just more belevible)  + the world is credible  + Combat is fun  + Immersive story  + Replayable (I would happily replay it. This is heavily thanks to the multiple aproaches and player freedom)  Negatives:  - It is a bit short ( As I said above I am 2/3 through and this was done in an evening and a day. there is dlc that will expand the game by quite a few hours each that I will check out in the future. That is my only negative.)

This game is terribly overrated.   The biggest problem with the game are the powers, touted as allowing you to mix in a infinite variety of ways. Er, if a variety of ways means like 8. Also, all of those fancy powers? They're mostly about killing people and raising your 'chaos' level, pretty much guranteeing you the bad ending. It's like they designed this to be a first person shooter, then penalized you for killing anyone and slapped on stealthy so it wouldn't have to compete with Call of Duty.  While the art does have it's own intricate style, it's set back in the stoneage by cartoony characters which cycle through a very tiny limited set of animations.  My recommendation: play Thief instead. Even with the annoying loading screens and a story that wasn't as strong, the elements of actual game play were just better.  Stylish artsy scenery does not make a complete game.

I am writing this review due to the release of Dishonored 2 in five days. I am writing this solely off of the main game, considering that I do not have the DLC packs. Dishonored is a first person stealth and action based game set in a steampunk universe. You play the role of Corvo Attano, a man who was in the wrong place at the wrong time and mistakingly accused of murdering the Empress. You will encounter many types of levels, all ripe with a wide variety of ways to accomplish the mission. Each level is filled with interesting characters that have unique dialogue options ('Shall we gather for whiskey and cigars tonight?'). Corvo has a large arsenal of weapons that range from his trusty sword to a pistol, all of which can be upgraded to your liking.  On top of the standard weapons, there are also supernatural abilities. These powers add a new level of creativity to an already stellar game. Just like the weapons, they can be upgraded in whichever way the player chooses. The story takes place in the city of Dunwall, an environment that is battling the rat plague. The environment that you explore will reveal the past of Dunwall and give you insight into individual's lives and how they endure the plague. The one thing that many people worry about on the PC is graphics and optimization. I am happy to say that this game passes with flying colors in both sections. The graphics are absolutely stellar considering it being released in 2012. You will also have no trouble running this game because the requirements are not demanding.   With all of this in mind, Dishonored is an amazing game. It is absolutely worth the $10 that the game is set at right now. Dishonored 2 comes out November 11th, 2016 and I would highly recommend buying Dishonored and playing it. If you want to save money, you can Dishonored 2 before it comes out and obtain access to Dishonored Definitive Edition which has all available DLC. Dishonored easily earns a 10/10.

What a great experience.   I bought this game some years after it's release. At first the graphics struck me somewhat because it doesn't have that polished high-texture look we've come to expect from modern games. However, everything is clearly laid out and the age of the game doesn't hinder the experience at all.   The gameplay is very smooth and all the moves and actions have a nice flow to them. The skill-ceiling is also very high but it won't discourage bad players. You can be an animal like me and do every mission with 'high chaos' or you can improve your skills and be completely stealth. The game enables you to go either way both of which seem very satisfactory.  The story is great in my opinion and during the ending credits it left me hungry for more (good thing Dishonored 2 is just a few days away!). You do have to face some ethical dilemmas, however I don't think they affect the course of the game very much. The way the story is told is making you want to play the next mission ASAP as you want to see what happens next.   As for the duration, I did my first run in 20-21 hours, with lots of wandering around looking for coins, elixirs, runes etc but with almost no reading. If you start reading all the notes you find and If you are dead serious about stealth, this game will last you long enough.   Definitely recommend this game and the pirce it is right now, don't even think about it

When a game focuses on nice gameplay+story instead of a state of the art graphics game with a dull gameplay, you end up with Dishonored ! And graphics are not so bad by the way.

The third playthrough confirms what I already knew: Dishonored is just fun. Remember that? It's what games used to be about. Hardly any chat, hardly any cut-scenes, no quicktime events, big maps, great powers and loads of opportunities to play however you like. It's not a long game, but it's perfectly formed. The visuals are pretty low-tech, but impeccably designed and beatifully drawn with a painterly-like flair. The skills are few, but each is perfectly honed. Corvo's blink is an idea of genius on a par with Half Life 2's gravity gun. Other tricks like summoning rats or the DLC's grab/pull are gifts that keep on giving, and the controls are bang on the mark. This is one of those games where you soon begin to feel like a god, toying with your enemies and deciding which swift, horrible fate each one will meet at your hands. 'Watch me take that blade from you', says a semi-friendly NPC in an atypical lull in the carnage. Just you bloody try, mate. You have no idea what I can do. 9/10.  DLC: I can't imagine why anyone would want to play Dunwall City Trials: it's no substitute for a game (1/10). Knife of Dunwall and Brigmore Witches are better, but lack the gravity of the main game. Irritatingly, both steal levels from the main game to prop up the content. Frankly, I'd rather just play the main game again, but thinking back to the soulless tat of Thief 4, they're still getting 7/10.

Played it some time ago, thought it was alright, dropped it for other holiday releases.  Expected mediocre, stealth game, ala Thief but with super powers.  Was very pleasently surprised.  Loved the story, I could choose to take lives or spare them. That's a good feeling of power in a video game. In other games a lot of times youre pigeonholed.  Your actions actually affect how characters behave, change the world and how characters view you as a person.  This was awesome and realistic, vs other games try to give an illusion of affect. This felt genuine and made sense.  Some philosophical questions were raised, and the game made me think a bit between what was right, and what was wrong.  Sometimes whether revenge is worth the sacrificing of your own humanity?  I loved that I could play the game how I wanted to like the Developers said.  Didnt need to be stealthy, didnt need to be rambo. I chose to be inbetween and just use two powers whole playthrough.,  Overall, awesome game, what a surprise, and enjoyment. Make sure to play the Knife of Dunwall and Witches DLC, they set up story for DIshonored 2.

tl;dr - awesome game, awesome stealth gameplay and I recommend a pacifist playthrough for maximum challenge and fun! Now for the kind of ranty review. This game is now after finishing it, one of my favorite stealth-action games of all time, rightup with the Thief series and Deus Ex among a few other classics. I played it on a different account for a long time but never got around to finishing it due to various life reasons. Finally did a full pacifist playthrough in the last few days and hot damn am I impressed with the fun this game provides. The open levels and freedom to approach in ways you want to left me very satisfied. I've bought Dishonored 2 now, and then once I've played that as a pacifist, I'll come back to this and do a high chaos playthrough and then also play the DLC that I've heard nothing but praise about. All in all, I'd give this game a 9/10 to any stealth fan, and also recommend it to people who like background story hidden throughout levels in books and such, which is all totally optional but super cool!

I'll try to avoid spoilers. You're the royal bodyguard. You get framed. You are giving fancy spy tech and magical powers.  Will you bring Justice, punishing only those who are Guilty? Will you hold the high ground, not even taking vengance against those who have wronged you, but merely banishing them? Or will you cut a swath of carnage until all fear your name?  The choice is yours...  The game does a good job, it doesn't railroad you into being a good guy, or a bad guy. Instead it has a moral system. Killing people leads to darker outcomes.  Yes, you can argue it's artificial, but the city does have The Black Plague, so the more dead bodies there are, and the more paniced the citizens are, the more chaos and disorder allows the plague to run rampant.  The only real criticisms of the game, are that it's short. So get the Game of the Year edition, which has like 3 times the content for only like $10 more.   If you can't make up your mind, wait for a Steam Sale, and grab it then. But grab it, it's good.

This is by far the most disappointing game I have ever played. It seems great with it's promises of stealth game play, victorian aesthetic and level design by a Half-Life 2 guy. It just disappoints on every level. The graphics could have used a good 6 months of improvements. The levels are pretty meh. It doesn't really seem like your actions really impact the story in anyways even though that was a nother grand promise. The only thing they do is add more guards. The story is I dunno trite, uninteresting, and poorly developed.   The gameplay is merely okay the combat feels wonky and unresponsive. The stealth aspect is the one thing that was done reasonably well but if you want to go that route the levels will take for ever to finish. There is just nothing to keep me playing accept the fact that I spent money on it.   Feels rushed and poorly developed every step along the way.   4/10- what you can see of the aesthetic is pretty nice and the stealth isn't awful.

A must play.   I bought the game of the year edition in the steam sales, and am somewhat amazed I'd not heard more about it prior.  Play pure stealth, or unleash your rage; taking the conspiritors head on. Slash, stab, explode, trap, stun, tranqilize, and gun your way to vengeance. Weaving shadowy magic and an arsenal of steampunkish weapons, you play your way through this well woven flexible story. Even once completed, the diversity of playstyles and methods of mission execution make a second playthrough a very different experience.   Dishonored came out in October 2012, but given that no real revelations in DX11 have transpired, the game doesn't look the slightest bit dated. The only things that in any way detracted from the game were very occasional points were music will play too loudly almost drowning out a narritive, or as I experienced at the end of the main campaign, a very strange area trigger causing the end boss to active their final speach before I was even in sight.  Despite getting the game on sale, I'd say it's worth the full current price.  Oh, incidentally, if you've seen the new THEIF trailers, the new THEIF looks to be almost exactly DISHONORED, so if you can't wait for THEIF, give this a try.

Dishonored has a great art style that almost seems Borderlandsey. The dark atmosphere and aforementioned art style go along well with the setting. The characterization, let alone amazing voice acting makes the world of Dunwall very enjoyable. The plot however seems a little too repetitive. Each mission consists of going to location of target, killing target, leaving. The stealth system is rather unrealistic. It involves walking a good distance away from guards, and, depending on your play style, either killing them when you have the chance, or avoiding them all together. A good distance from guards is so close to them that they'd have to be deaf to not hear you. They also don't have peripheral vision. As long as you don't stand in front of them or sprint near them, you should be fine. As for hours, Dishonored is a little short. There is no multiplayer, and the DLCs won't stimulate you for long. On the up side, Corvo and Daud's* powers make you feel powerful. Dishonored's game-play, maps, easy stealth, graphics, and characters make for a very fun stealth game. I would definitely recommend to stealth fanatics.   (*refer to DLCs)

I've just completed Dishonored for the first time and have thoroughly enjoyed it so I thought I would write my first Steam review. I would highly recommend it to anyone who has played Deus Ex, as I found them to be similar. Whereas you have a choice, kill everything that moves or be a crafty b*****d and spare their lives. Dishonored takes the best things from Thief and Deus Ex and combines them into a original and beautiful game.   The city in which you apply your craft and upgradable abilities is inspired from London and Edinburgh.  I found myself playing a more stealth approach and have no complaints about the length of the game, however if you were to go around executing any moveable object you might complete the game rather rapidily. Even though i seemed to play with a more stealth approach, I did to stray from this path as you can kill in the most imaginable ways. Attaching spring razors to rats and watch them kill a room full of people is rather satisfying.  I wasn't expecting much from Dishonored, but was blown away.
My favorite game of all time. Just buy it and the two story DLCs, you will not be dissapointed.

If you love BioShock Series you will probably love this even more! Go in guns blazing? Sneak your way around them? Call in help from allies? You choose, anything is possible and you are left to make the choices you want. The choices you make actually affect the storyline Stunning graphics, great voice acting, Brilliant combat system and cool abilities.   All the DLC is worth buying so much extra fun and storyline to be enjoyed.  I can't wait for Dishonored II at E3 this year, Dishonored has to be my all time favourite game! I hope they continue the series and don't leave it in a ditch like Bioshock. Thank you Bethesda for an amazing game.

Good story, great characters and a facinating world to explore, this is worthy game for people who enjoy sneaking games like Thief´s and MGS.  8/10

This has been consistently one of my favorite games that I keep coming back to. While some people may complain about the graphics and stealth gameplay, the over all game and story are fantastic. The graphics do look a little muddy at times but I feel that it fits the environment. The stealth gameplay is a little spotty at times but once you get used to it , it is quite rewarding to finish a level without being detected. The DLC for this game is also superb, the Dunwall Trials offer interesting and new things to do and have, like the rest of the game, high replayablity. After beating the main story being able to play as Daud in the DLC is extremely fun. The game also gets credit for having full controller support ( I'm not a fan of using M/K ) and the GOTY of the game goes on sale quite often on steam making it a good game to pick up.

I can't stress how much I love this game. Exploring the multiple routes and hidden corners of each level is continuously rewarding, as is experimenting with all the different ways to exploit your powers and items to dispatch your targets. This is a game from an older era, where level design and freedom of play are king, brought into a slick modern package. I might even say you're doing yourself a DISHONOR if you don't play it. Get it??
The game is actually fun. A little predictable once you get the hang of it, but very open in allowing you the option on how to complete each stage.

Dishonored is a mechanically interesting game with a lot of varied ways to accomplish your missions. It is short, but at short I think it is about the right length. in the last two missions of my second play through, I was getting ready for the game to be done.  The story on the other hand leaves something to be desired, but it accomodates at least one replay, not just because it nominally has two endings, they are very similar, but because the game play can be so different and it is interesting to see what happens to people if you choose the other way of dealing with them.

Dishonored is easy to learn and hard to master. This makes it great for both new stealth gamers and stealth game pros. It has a nice art style, stealth is so satisfying, and the combat system isn't bad at all for a stealth game. The powers can both make the game interesting, and decrease the variety of gameplay at the same time. It's not too difficult to use blink to make it through a whole level no problem, so the powers are both a pro and a con. Many people will replay levels multiple times to get the best run possible, or try different play styles for fun. The game is loads of fun. I recommend Dishonored without hesitation.
Fantastic stealth game with a great story. Play it.
When you take the -nored off of Dishonored it says 'dis ho' and I think that's beautiful.

Dishonored is a fantastic game that does a great job of giving you multiple ways to complete missions, and provides you a number of options along the way. You can run in with your sword drawn, or you can sneak around in the shadows.  Well worth the buy!

Hands down one of the most impressive games of 2012  As a first person, action and adventure game, every upgrade and weapon carries a nice weight to it. The story is well written and the voice acting is top notch. Add in the supernatural elements and this game is nothing short of stellar. The originality of this game cannot be stressed enough. The world in Dishonored is its own, and while it borrows from varying historic sources, it’s a fresh breath of air in the stale genre of shooters/action RPG’s.  The longevity of this game is unmatched, other games that offer 'choices' usually fall short of their promises. Dishonored plays out very differently depending on how you choose to finish each mission. The action, stealth and RPG elements are so well refined that it's hard to say anything bad about this game.  The graphics might be lacking when compared to more modern titles but its incredible art style more than makes up for it.  I strongly recommend this game to anyone who is remotely interested in the action/adventure or FPS genre.

Amazing game. Great art, incredibly smooth, great story. A mix between Bioshock and Assasins Creed! Expect to spend a lot of time with it if you don't want to kill anyone. It's very easy to blast your way through sections if you want though. Highly recommended.

Dishonored is a stealth action adventure video game developed by Arkane Studios and published by the very reputable Bethesda Softworks. I picked it up over the Christmas period and honestly, I didn't expect great things. I've played it on console and felt it was very slow and 'clunky'. Although I have been converted, this title is well worth your time.  In a nutshell, and without spoilers. Your a bodyguard, Corvo, protecting an Empress, and she winds up being assasinated on your watch. Her daughter (heir to the throne) is kidnapped and your framed for the crime. I have to say that although the plot makes sense and is somewhat enjoyable, is escalates to quickly. In a matter of two missions you have went from humble bodyguard to reknowned assassin, it's just unrealistic. On the other hand, the game is quite short so maybe we can forgive them this time.  Dishonored is set in a fictional British area with a theme that can only be described as steampunk. With settings on high expect great looking visuals and a very fluid gameplay experience. I believe this game is very open-ended in that the player can attack a level in any way he sees fit, as an extensive arsenal allows for both a covert and guns blazin' approach. During my first playthrough I have chosen to go with the former. However as with most stealth games, expect to be spending up wards of an hour and a half to do an entire mission in a stealthy fashion. In my eyes this is part of the fun and can be very rewarding when you accomplish a task that at first glance seems impossible. In some levels, I had compelted the main objective in 20 minutes, but optional objectives and side missions gave the level an extra hour of playtime at least. Side missions also add another flavour to Dishonored and can be easily overlooked without a degree of curiosity. They enable the player to attack objectives in different ways or gain advantages they would otherwise not have had.  The heart of this game lies with the gameplay, it is excellent. Few games in the sub genre can give the player so much freedom in the routes they take, the way they do things and even how they take out (or in some cases don't take out) the target. Arkane studios have achieved this through superb level design that beautifully complements the supernatural 'powers' Corvo picks up. These powers are the life blood of dishonored and enable the player to have an unique experience and mold their playthrough around their play style. Powers can be unlocked and later upgraded through the currency 'runes'. Runes can be obtained in a number of different ways, as a reward, bought from certain NPC's and most frequently through exploration of the huge levels. There are a number of abilities that can be unlocked such as blink, this enables the player to instantly travel a short distance to help slip by enemies. Another would be possessing animals, or other humans.  Furthermore, Dishonored has added a system that is not found often in these sorts of games. This system is known as Chaos. At the end of each level you are given a chaos rating that is simply high, or low. This rating is based on the way you play, if you chose to kill people and be a cruel and unforgivening assailant you will be given a high chaos rating. Obviously doing the opposite will give you a low one. The rating itself not only affects the world around you (a darker world, more plague victims) but it also changes the ending to the game and to how some of the later missions play out. I see this as an ingenius way for Arkane studios to give their game replayability and overcome the issue of a fairly short story.  To conclude, the reviews here simply aren't long enough to go into depth about all the features that are an offer ( i.e.upgrades, blueprints, collectibles) but I highly recommend Dishonored to those who are fans of these titles and people who enjoy a challenge. At heart it is a fun, deep experience with a strong gameplay mechanic and a lot of replaybility. It is beautiful game and expect to be playing the game for 8 - 14 hours depending on how you play. The narrative may be lacking in length and plot but this is a very minor fault and is easily overlooked. Enjoy!

Pros: 1. Incredibly fun gameplay. 2. Well-crafted environments making for an immersive experience. 3. Many, many options for how you accomplish just about everything in the game. 4. Fantastic story and dialogue that you can really get into.  Cons: 1. Way, way too short.  [NOTE: I have not yet played any of the downloadable content.]

A first person stealthy steampunk/magipunk fantasy romp in a victorian era like whaling empire is surprisingly enough one of the best games I've played in a long time. The controls, powers, and gadgets all feel great and the mechanics themselves are awesome too short of enemy AI (then again it's a stealth game so this is fairly natural.) Ways to complete missions are varied and fun although do yourself a favor and play it through stealthily, it's no fun to rush it and fight everyone to the death. With that said there are a couple issues mostly dealing with your skillset. While there are a plethora of skills to use in your playthrough many of them can simply break the game or parts of it. One of them turns people you kill into ash that blows away which removes the purpose of hiding or disposing bodies. Likewise your gear for a stealthy aproach gets restricted as many powers are focused on rushing in and fighting and several weapons are the same. If they had simply given all the love and attention to stealth, and left fighting as a difficult yet possible alternative it woulda been better in the end. 9/10 for those who like numbers to their games.
Really nice game :)

Dishonored:  I was never a big fan of single player games. I always played multi-player. I dunno, I guess it's just the competetive nature in me. However, I picked this game up @ a bargain for $7.00. I didn't really think I had much to lose with that kind of price tag. But, to my surprise I had felt like I had spent the best $7.00 of my life.  This game is quite amazing. The graphics are very well done, and the mechanics + story had me hooked. If I was a fan of single player games I most definatley would not have had a problem paying the full price tag on it. It caters to both style of players, (low chaos) just sneaking around and trying not to get caught and, (high chaos) going in guns blazing killing everything in your path.  Pros: - Amazing campaign with re-playability (high chaos) or (low chaos) - Great story - Graphics are pleasing to the eye - Controls are not all over the place and the character handles quite majestically - Has controller support - DLC to play from other characters stand points  Cons: - Will be hard to walk away from computer - High Chaos can be a b***h at times  Enjoy!

Often you are asked to eliminate someone but other opportunities can come to light if you take the time to search around. It is one of the rare games where I have replaid it several times and at the hardest level. It is not impossible to complete at the hardest level, you just need a bit more patience :). Take time to explore each area, there is so much going on.

This game...I really wanted to love. I really did, and in many ways I still do! It is a new IP, it has stealth and moral choice elements in it, The world changes in ways that are so unique and subtle! But...Why did I not care what happens? Dishonored is a game where you play a bodyguard who does horribly at his job, as in the first few minutes playing as him you do not save the Emperoress from being stabbed and her daughter from being kidnapped. Oh, and you are accused of murdering her for reasons no one makes clear...Okay. So you escape prison...a long time later, and gain supernatural powers from a guy (who might be the devil in this world, not sure) Who does it because EH, WHY NOT. So you go on a quest to reclaim your honor...whatever the cost. Now, the game is fantastic in so many ways. The combat feels incredibly fluid, in both stealth and direct approaches, and your ability to teleport across sneaking points above people creates a sense of tension and drama where you must time your powers carefully and wisely. The ways the world change are just incredibly unique and subtle in so many ways by what you choose to do, and the game's enviroment creates a truly unique experience. But my biggest problem with the game, and it is one that almost makes me not recommend it is the villians you are set against. I have never seen a bunch of the most sterotypical jerks in a video game since Hitman Absolution where you fight against a Fat Cowboy and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥/Racist Cop. Okay, I'll let you guess who the villians are from the beginning of the game. Are they the bald, old, big nosed creeps who constantly look mad and keep making statements in front of not only to their 'friends' but to the public in general to how evil they are? I mean...the target at the masquerade was someone who SEEMED very sympathic in a strange way, and seems much more like a victim then the artist/scientist who admits to torturing and experimenting on poor commoners to find a cure for a rat infestation which...is obviously caused by the villians. I know this seems really petty, as they are not suppose to be subtle or a mystery to why you should kill them or hate them, but when your roster of villians include at least 3 rapists, then you might need to give me a better reason to spare their lives then 'OH, but you are a kind soul'.  Otherwise, I remember the devil character in this game...is just so fascinating. He is a creature that gives you powers for no plot or specific reason. He just wants to see WHAT you will do with them. He doesn't care about what happens to people, he just enjoys what people do with what they are given. If they use it to create puppies for orphans, he will enjoy it. But if they also use it to create rabbit puppies that eat children, he will enjoy it just the same. I want more characters who are just that amoral.   DO I RECOMMEND THIS GAME: YES With a complex stealth system as well as a fighting system, the world it allows you to explore and navigate is truly unique and deserves a sequel that will expand on the world it created.  SUGGESTIONS (FOR GAME DEVS): Please make more subtle or relatable villians! That way, I am more willing to put effort into silently taking them out.

This game handles stealth much better than any other similar game I've played. You feel like you actually do something playing stealthily, rather than just sprinting around at the exact time nobody's looking (I'm looking at you, Splinter Cell games)  Your actions affect the story in a way I hadn't honestly expected, but I won't spoil that. The storyline was really interesting to me, and the gameplay was great enough to keep me going through it. The only issue I had was that, with a lack of anything new being given to you late game, it did start to feel kind of drawn out. Having everything available from the start is a great idea in concept, but in practice not so much.  The visuals were beautiful, though in this case I'm not sure I actually like that. It has a more artistic than realistic style (reminds me sort of Bioshock), and I feel being more realism based would add some much needed grit to the combat. I was expecting a very gritty game and did not recieve that, though I was pleasantly surprised with how good the actual game was.  9/10
