Dishonored is a stealth game with some gameplay additions that improve and degrade the stealth formula, the overall result is an alright game that had the potential to be much better.  The story is ok, it could be more dramatic in order to add tension and surprise, but instead it feels as you are following a series of events as the story unfolds, even the plot twist is predictable and feels meaningless. One very good feature is that context shapes up based on your decisions, you can either kill or spare key targets, the city and other characters are impacted by your decisions. The variety of which you can kill key targets is also great, it invites you to check all variations, like poisoning, possessing, etc.  The ambience is one of the aspects where the game disappoints, a stealth game like this one should be dark, but most missions take place during the day, the enemies cannot see a guy in black running 1 meter from them if you are just above their heads. The AI feels very simple, guards hardly ever patrol or notice missing bodies, and they also do not react very well to thrown objects.  Complementing the AI, the map design does not allow the player to evade the enemies undetected, you will either have to use your special abilities, or knock/kill the guards. If you are playing stealthy you will find yourself spamming the blink ability, which allows you to teleport a short distance, and this feels as breaking the stealth purpose, if you do not do it, you may not proceed in certain areas due to map design and enemy placement.  Regarding maps, half of the game takes place in a small district, which is recycled for several missions. By the second or third mission you will have memorized all shortcuts and important locations, which in turn will make the following missions too easy and feel like the game is repeating itself.  The game overall is good and has a lot of creativity involved, but it is far from a true stealth masterpiece due to forced special abilities and ambience.

There are multiple ways of playing through the game, which means the it has great replayability value.  I chose to go with a non-lethal approach, which was a lot different to lethal and turns Dishonoured into a challenging, but rewarding stealth game. One of the most fun aspects of the game include the 'powers' you acquire throughout the game and how you use them to pass the certain missions. Although the game is somewhat linear, you can choose to do side missions within each area you are in within the main ongoing mission. Exploration is still awesome and the game encourages you to do so, as there are a multitude of items for you to collect to enhance your character and give him special powers.  The storyline and the setting of Dunwall is great if you're into steampunk/Victorian era stuff, either way it's still a fresh experience from other modern day backdrops.   9.4/10

Whether you enjoy hack and slash kill-everyone-and-their-mother (because you'll be damned if the ends certainly don't justify the means!) first person adventure games , or if you choose to be the dark sinister figure moving in and out of the shadows as you strategically take out your enemies silently Dishonored is the game for you.   Much like games prior to Dishonored (i.e. the Bioshock or Fable franchises; I would have said Mass Effect, but no matter how you choose red, blue, and green all taste the same) any action you take will influence the overall outcome of the story. Protect the innocent and punish the wicked, or stroll your way to the top as you casually step over one body at a time - but walk softly and carry a big stick (or maybe a few key bonecharms, slow time, and a really big gun) because you never know if The Outsider is watching you...
I loved this game. The different ways it allows you to combine powers and weapons to make more complex and subtle kills is astonishing.
Great Game

Dishonored is.......okay. It's not a bad game. It isn't a great game. It's very 'Thief'(if you played the 'Thief' game series from 1998-2000ish, you'll get this right away. If not, Steam has it and it is well worth playing). Graphically it is beautiful. Gameplay is easy enough to learn. Story is interesting enough to keep you playing, but gets a bit predictable. It ended up being a blip on the gaming world's radar, and I'm glad I didn't pay 60 bucks for it. $7.50 was about right.

absolutely wicked

I believe Dishonored to be nearly the perfect game. Absolutely play it on Very Hard. It is unforgiving but not unfair and one of the few games I've played that I've felt is rewarding playing on difficult. I'm a fan of stealth games and this is the best I've played, but the hand-to-hand is no slouch either. Controls and smooth and fluid and so satisfying pulling off a perfectly-timed sword block or firing off that gun.   My only gripe for the game is that some of the RPG-style upgrades are underwhelming. Perhaps they didn't suit my stealth style but I didn't find I really needed any of the equipment upgrades. The ability upgrades are much the same story - several are great. Perhaps if I were to go through it again and blast my way through the game it'd be nice to have more health and more ammo for the items. But the next replay I make will be very quiet. The way it is now, they seem to really emphasize stealth and no-kill completion with rewards for such after every level and badges for completing the entire game that way. So why not add more upgrades to facilitate that when you may not ever fire a shot through the entire game? I know when I have to fire a shot, it means it's time to reload a save. Anyway all that is disappointing but nowhere near close to affecting my enjoyment of the game.  The choice to finish as a cold brutal killer or as an unseen shadow is welcome and in a world of CoD sequels and copycats this stands out as a way to do action with creativity and beauty. Take all that and set it in a game with excellent art direction and you've got youself a classic.

Yes, I fully recommend this game. It's just awesome. There is one thing you should consider though. The original game didn't allow you to revisit levels with all of your upgrades. This was disappointing to me, as I had looked forward to revisiting these stages and experimenting with all of the new toys I had earned by the end of the game. Instead, a save file is created when you start each level to serve as your waypoint for return visits, meaning you will always return to that level with the same upgrades as your initial playthrough. Also, the two endings you can achieve are pretty lame for a game with so many options. If you do buy, I suggest the GOTY edition, as the DLC helps with some of the replayability issues.

Did you enjoy the darkbrother hood in oblivion and skyrim? Half Life 2? Bioshock Infinite Theme? Well I have great news for you. Dishonored is all that. Confederate post pre future dystopia, under 1984 influenced conspiracy. This game is rather generous when you structurize yourself, even on hard difficulty. I'd purely recommend only playing it on hardest difficulty to ensure it's stealth benefits are maximized. Plenty of potions, so if you suffer conservatist item attitudes, non worries for ourselves because most of the game requires only you to think clearly and effectively. This game is intended to be played three times, for OCD, never getting caught once and another as pascifist ghost, no kills. If you're a sadist you can do both at once. If you are a professional sloppy assassin like myself, I'd just rambosassin through, be sure to enjoy the rpg elements, I really got into character development and reading minds with the heart. I really recommend this game, it's really fun and great, good anti hero style characters, no pure good, no pure evil.

I do highly recommend this game, but I do warn you that it is one where you make most of the fun yourself. I say this because you are a near silent protagonist that is presented with multiple open, non-linear playgrounds with which to stalk and eliminate your enemies (if you so choose) and as is so with many sandbox games, the fun comes primarily from your own mind.  Use your imagination and explore each level. There are little bits of side-story and side-quests on nearly every mission so don't be afraid to go out and put yourself into a little danger to get the full experience.  I'm on my umpteenth playthrough and it still hasn't gotten old. A whorthwhile purchase, to be sure.

I give it a 9. There's a good depth of world background and theme that play through this. The story is a bit predictable, but still fun. Depending on choices you make (to kill or not), the world will be nicer or darker. Every level has multiple ways through it based upon playstyle, so it doesn't get too stale. It is marred by a somewhat dumb AI. The need for multiple solutions also makes it a bit easy; just crank it to max fdifficulty and enjoy. It's good for 30 or so hours; more with DLC or re-play. The gameplay system gives player a lot of tools to play with and it comes together to form a deep system. You can literally play this game however you like and the game will reflect your actions, similar to TellTale's The Walking Dead. While the plot is somewhat predictable, it doesn't make it any less interesting. One of the stronger games of 2012, no doubt about it.

Dishonored is well-crafted playground that gives you too much toys. Making use of all the tools, abilities and resources the game presented, the game is a power fantasy. On normal difficulty, I hardly felt vulnerable and the upgrades felt unnecessary.  Here are some tips to help increase the enjoyment of the game: 1] try to get through the slow start, it starts ramping up on the 3rd mission  2] don't worry too much about the chaos level, it is actually interesting to see the consequences of your actions. From what I understand, chaos reflects actual chaos you create, not number of deaths, ie silently killing everyone with no alarms would result in low chaos.  3] impose a restriction on yourself: total stealth, non-lethal, no abilities upgrades, etc. most are supported with achievements  4] if you like the challenge, you could turn off objective markers or start at a higher difficulty  The important question at the end of the day is whether it's fun and to that I answer: YES.

An immersive first-person stealth game with an emphasis on exploration, Dishonored is a game I highly recommend. Armed with an array of weapons and supernatural gifts bestowed upon you by the mysterious Outsider, you sulk around the grimy, plague-infested city of Dunwall as you seek revenge on the conspirators that murdered the Empress and framed you for the crime. Though the story is linear in progression, you are given the freedom to approach your missions however you see fit, capable of murdering every living soul on the map or completing the game without killing anyone at all and it is that freedom that makes the game a joy to play.  Featuring a heavily atmospheric world filled with dread and corruption, Dishonored is a great looking game with its own unique style that adds a lot of character. Levels are filled with books to read and resources to find, and you are able to achieve your objectives in multiple ways based on your own preferences and playing style. It can be difficult, but never fairs unfairly so, and it is always satisfying when you complete a mission without ever being detected. It is also refreshing that the game has no traditional boss battles, though your targets can be challenging if you go at them face to face.   The game has some weaknesses, mostly around the silent protagonist you play as, who would have benefited from having a voice to provide an emotional connection to the character. The voice acting is good and features some notable talent, but not as well utilized as it could be, and a real conversation system and some roleplay mechanics would have been welcome. There are also limited character models, so you will be running into the same faces a lot over the games running time. The game’s running time will also vary, averaging between twelve to twenty hours depending on play style, but thankfully has a lot of replay value as you try new combinations of powers and seek out new routes to achieve your missions.   The two DLC packs, Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches, are also great expansions to the world, and both benefit from the dry, world-wary performance of Michael Madsen as Daud, an antagonist from the main game that you now get to play as. These missions help develop the world even more, especially the supernatural elements, and offers up new environments to explore. I totally recommend them, and anything to increase your time in Dunwall is always welcome.

Dishonored is a Stealth/Action hybrid in the vain of deus ex and other similar games. At first I was a bit worried that either stealth or action would supercede the other, but as I progressed through the game I found that this was not a problem at all. Both are viable. Stealth is rewarded in many different ways throught the game, including a MUCH better ending, less weepers (like zombies), and less plauge rats. The very few problems it has are easily overlooked by the masterful story, characters, combat, and aesthetics.There have been concerns about the length of the game and how much it costs, I can confirm that the game can be beaten comlpletly with stealth in about 6-8 hours. If you were to use purely Action orentated gameplay, you would probably finish the game faster. Since this game has two different paths you can take, a second playthrough is recommended. There has already been confirmation of two story-based DLC's. Considering all of these things, I consider this a MUST-BUY. I recommend everyone to give this game a try. Conclusion - BUY IT NOW!!!

The game had me thriving to complete each level to upmost perfection, i felt oblidged to get every rune, every bone charm and every sokolov painting, it even had me scrounging for every single coin i could find. I loved the level design because it was so non linear even though it wasn't an open world, i felt so open to do what i wanted even though i was restricted. The powers were great, the blink being especially fun to use and it worked very well to be frank. If you play the game in a certain way it has an incredibly satisying feel of movement and momentum, if you factor in the blink. The story isn't a prize winner but its decent enough. The setting of the game was very interesting this steampunk world which is slowly being engulfed by the rat plague, making it feel somewhat connected to our own realities history. All in all a very good game with some great features, a must have.

When I first played Dishonored, I struggled to get into it. It took quite some time to grow on me, but when it did I couldn't put it down. This is another game that does stealth and player choice very well. It has a heavy Bioshock vibe to it, with the supernatural powers and ocean theme, but that's not a bad thing. Gameplay is fantastic. You can choose to sneak around everywhere, or you can use your sword, crossbow, gun, and all sorts of other gadgets to fight your way through the game's rather large levels. There's a real sense of verticality when you're running around Dunwall. This game has definitely taught me to look up more often, perhaps to find hidden items or an alternate route through a tough area. Level design is top-notch. Corvo's supernatural powers range from Blink - a short teleport that you start out with - to Posession, which allows you to posess rats, fish, and even people! My favourite power has to be Bend Time, which allows you to slow time when you first unlock it, but when you upgrade it to level 2 you can bring time to a complete standstill. During this period, try firing crossbow bolts at several guards, then when time starts again, watch all the bolts hit the guards at the same time! It's truly one of those satisfying game mechanics and it never gets old. I have only two complaints about Dishonored. First, it's a pretty short game - nine missions in total. Second, the PC port is pretty bad from a graphical standpoint. Muddy textures, low draw distance... They could have made more effort - perhaps an HD texture pack as DLC? It just doesn't look that great compared to other games that were released around the same time. Overall, Dishonored is a great stealth action game, and worth a playthrough or two. If you can get it at a good price, go for it!
One of the best stealth games I've played since Thief 2 and Deus Ex 1.

Dishonored is a game that is going to be around for a long time. It's changed a lot of things in the stealth genre, and some things in the RPG genre too. This game is one of the only games made by the developer Arkane, and it is one of the best games I've played. You step into the shoes of Corvo, the Empress's guard. But right from the beginning, things go wrong and you are framed for the murder of the Empress. Leading you to go on a journey to get revenge and get rid of the men that framed you for the murder of the empress. This game can be played without killing anyone at all, which is a real challenge. After you beat the game that should take you about 15 hours depending on how fast you play it, there are lots of DLC's to play to extend the time. And, you can play through the levels again completely differently. I have not encountered any problems with this game 10/10

A really good sneak game.

Do you like Deux Ex? Thief? Any game requiring you to stealth around? Then you will love this game. It is truly awesome.   If you like BioShock, you should love this game as well. If you DONT like Bioshock, this game should still appeal to you as you can play it without using the stealth aspects if you want.   Basically, this is an amazing game. The only people who probably wont like it are people who just don't care for First Person style games, or when they do play First Person games, want a plain-jain FPS like Quake/Doom or Call of Duty.   Anyways, I really enjoyed Dishonored. Taking my time to explore was a blast. The stealth mechancs are perfect and I had a lot of fun turning each encounter into its own puzzle, trying to figure out exactly how to knock out each guard.   The DLC is also very good and will obviously expand.   This is great. Easily up there with Mass Effect, BioShock, Uncharted, Last of Us, etc, etc as a 'must play' game.  It is one of the few games I am about to replay on a harder difficulty, maybe doing things 'assassin' style to see what happens.   It has me wanting to go back to Deus Ex: Human Revolution, which I didn't finish either, and replay that.  Can't wait for a sequel.

Dishonored is one of those games that you'll finish and start re-playing immediately. At a time when so many action games lead players through funhouse levels and 'set piece moments', Dishonored is content to let players explore complex non-linear environments and learn the game's systems at their own pace.  It was a pleasure to sneak my way through this game, relying on silent takedowns and tranquilizers, but I had just as much fun ripping enemies apart in a second playthrough.   The Knife of Dunwall and Brigmore Witches DLC are also a lot fun, and Daud is a cool character, although neither DLC has a particularly satisfying conclusion.

The fluidity and freedom of the movement Corvo possesses is this games greatest strength. Combine that with very intersting visuals, fantastic stealth options and a story worth investing in and you've got yourself a real treat!

This is simply my favourite stealth game (I've played it 5 times through) because of how it emulates amazing stealth titles like Thief II and Deus Ex before it and then proceeds to bring in modern RPG and FPS elements that revolutionise the genre. The sneaking, stealing, secrets and knockouts are a great homage to Thief. And then the powers and abilities that draw heavily from Deus Ex and Bioshock add an additional level to the game. Mostly them encourage lethal play (so I ignore them), but the Blink ability is the main selling point here, as it completely revolutionizes the stealth experience. Forget waiting in the shadows for minutes at end while surveying the room and taking out each guard one by one. Instead, just blink behind a guard and stab him, then blink silently back into the shadows to plan your next move. The powers here create a language of murder that allows you to mix up each situation by making the various systems work together: like possessing a guard shooting at you while slowing time and making him walk into his own bullets, or attaching a spring razor trap to a plague rat and then possessing it and scurrying into a group of enemies. The story here engages but misses on the chance to explore themes only hinted at: like power, corruption and duty, mainly because most characters are bland at worse, underdeveloped at best. The focus here seems to be on the cliched revenge plot. The game is of reasonable length, and the 2 newest DLC packs, which add some welcome difficulty and some new powers plus a new story, are worthy purchases.
My personal GOTY 2012. Awesome game, with probably the best *moral choices system* I've ever seen. Incredibly fun to play.

Everything works perfectly or nearly so, everything fits together. The level design and architecture are the biggest winners, art design and sound design are superb. There is a lot of choices with consequences, some of them advertised, some hidden. A lot of details in this world, be it in the books, hidden diaries, graffitis, overheard dialogues. The levels are full of secret nooks, crannies, apartments, balconies.    This is without doubt the best game of the last decade, the return of the lost genre.  If you loved either of the big three - Thief, Deus Ex, System Shock, you will love this.
One of the best atmospheres in games today. The art, sound, dialogue, level design and so much more are top notch and well worth experiencing.
It is the best solo game ever crafted, Steam has never had a game this good before.

One of the best games I've played on a long time, I thought Dishonored was a truly outstanding game. While the plot was fairly predictable, the fantastic setting and outstanding voice acting made the whole game feel truly big-budget. Similarly, the open-world approach to the missions and the imaginative range of special powers made for an atmospheric blend of tension and sudden violence that was great fun from start to finish.  One criticism that I've seen levelled at Dishonored is that it's too short. I find that a bit strange - maybe if you blitzed through it with crossbows blazing you could finish pretty quickly, but that would be missing the point. I played with a mostly-stealth approach, but without going for the extreme pacifist achievements and I clocked around 24 hours over a week - collecting most items without being a completionist. I guess I'm lucky that I can afford to buy new games fairly regularly - but I would much rather play a short, perfectly formed, game than something padded out just to make it longer (looking at you, Skyrim) And 24 hours isn't exactly short.  So if you're worried about value for money, don't be. If you're not a fan of stealth games, neither am I - Dishonored is definitely worth playing, especially at the discounted prices you can generally get now!  (Note that I originally wrote this review in January 2013)

Very highly recommended. If you liked games such as Deus Ex, The Witcher, Thief, or Dark Messiah, and you haven't played this game, you are making a mistake. If you've never played any of those games, this is a good place to start.   Dishonored is a first-person game in which you play an imperial bodyguard named Corvo. Your job is to do what the Empress tells you to do.   Then she gets stabbed to death, right in front of you. Spoiler: she didn't tell you to do that. So now you're in trouble. Nice work, Corvo!   From there you have to redeem yourself while protecting those you care about and deciding the fates of your enemies. Note that I said, 'deciding.' This is very important; you don't have to murder everyone! I, however, played Corvo as a man with a folding blade and anger management issues. Dishonored is very good at giving you excellent reasons to shank everyone you meet. Some of them are jerks, some of them are trying to kill you, and some of them are directly in your way. However, the game is quite up-front about letting you know that violence begets violence. And darkness in general.   And darkness is something the city of Dunwall doesn't really need right now. Their beloved empress has been brutally murdered (again, nice work.) They're also under the effects of a fairly mysterious plague that is killing people by the trainfull (literally.) The government's response to all this has been a draconian crackdown on freedom, which may or may not be some sort of analogue to what is happening in America, but I chose to ignore that statement, if indeed it is intended as one. Harder to handwave is your own effect on the city; your decisions directly affect the state of the streets, as you either pile up the body count, resulting in increased rat and plague activity, or you angelically save everyone, which probably does something else less horrible.   I chose to risk it, by which I mean I went into each mission with the best of intentions, but sooner or later I'd run out of sleeping darts, or I wouldn't be able to figure out how to sneak past a checkpoint, or a guard would cough, and the result would always be frenzied stabbing. But the point I'm trying to make here is that you can choose to do otherwise, and it matters! People's lives are changed, their reactions are different, and the game as well as the ending are affected by your choices.   I personally turned the sweetest most innocent person in the whole game into a Sith Lord. Perhaps you can do better.

Fun game if you like stealth action. The blink ability is amazing in how it makes what would otherwise be a normal stealth game much more fun. Want to get right behind that guy across the room before he turns around? Use blink. Want to escape from a guard that is turning to face you? Blink away. Want to get to that alternate path so you can avoid fights altogether? Blink up to the roof. That one ability really makes the game so much less frustrating than most other stealth games. If you're trying to go for a murderless run be aware that the rat swarm ability, dropping bodies from too high up and dropping people into water or other hazards will count as you killing them, things that I didn't realise at first.
Here's the true heir not only to Dark Messiah, but also to Thief.

One of the best single player games I've played in a long time, the story is very dark and interesting all the way through, combat has plenty of variety and fun supernatural powers to experiment with, Stealth mechanics are well executed and the game has multiple endings based on how you play, giving it good replay value. I would reccomend it to anyone...so long as you don't have a phobia of rats.

Dishonored is a stealth-action game based in a Steampunk-like world. (things run off of whale oil, so I guess that makes it Whale-oil punk?). You play as a former bodyguard turned assassin known as Corvo. He works with a group of men and women loyal to the late empress who Corvo was framed for killing.  Dishonored plays like a blend of Deus Ex and Hitman. These are to game series I really like, so Dishonored is certainly my type of game. This games biggest strength is the amount of choice the player is given. You can go on a throat-liberation marathon, teleport and avoid guards, or just go crazy and murder everything. Granted that last option is very hard to pull off, but if you do make a mistake, you can turn it around without loading again.   Corvo can equip a crossbow, pistol, grenades, mines and a sword. These weapons aren't really all that unique feeling, which is somewhat disappointing. Despite this, the combat feels good, considering it's quite simple. The sword feels like it has impact, and blocking is a very useful tool.   What makes Dishonored stand out is Corvo's magical powers. To begin with, he can teleport, but he can also posses rats, see through walls, and summon a swarm of rats to eat enemies, just to name a few. You acquire these powers through runes, which are often hidden in out of the way places. You also get Bone Charms, which provide mild boosts in your abilites, but to be honest, I didn't really notice the effects much.   Movement itself feels smooth, which is important considering you're suppose to be a nibble assassin. If you can't climb up it, you can probably teleport to it. The insta-kill animations only take about a second, if that, which is great, as I don't need to watch five seconds of some dude getting torn apart. Just a simple knife to the throat.   Sneaking is fine for the most part. My only complaint is that in one level I played I was hiding in a bush but enemies could still see me. This bush covered me head to toe. Apart from that, the stealth was fine.   The story is pretty solid. I have a few minor issues with the story, but nothing went full retard. My only real complaint is that it felt a bit rushed, and honestly, the game could have been placed a little slower. This would have given the game a little more length, and that would have been nice. Granted, their are multiple endings, and choices/playstyles to add to replay value. This is also one of the few games that made me change my approach for moral reasons. For example during an early mission, I was given the option of branding a target a heretic, over killing him. This made me change my approach from a simple murder, to a chaotic attempt to get the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ branded.  The atmosphere is great. I really enjoyed the world. My only complaint is that I wanted to see more of Dunwall, and the surrounding area. Even though I had to lower the settings a little to make sure it'd run smooth, the art style still carried through.   This game really does what it sets out to do. Tell an engaging story in a desperate world with fun, open ended gameplay. I really hope the sequel lives up to this game. I give Dishonored a 9/10.

Dishonored. What a fantastic game. You see, I had never heard of this game but in passing before and so it was never something I had thought to play before. The other day Steam updated and this game was a whopping 75% off it's original value of $19.99, that made it $4.99! There was no way I could pass up that kinda deal.  It was worth every cent and more.  The game is a combination magic and stealth combat. There were a couple puzzles to solve, but the best part about it was the magic system. WHile there weren't really many 'magic spells' to use, the ones that existed were great fun. I'd be up fo rplaying this game again and do my best to be as stealthy as possible, but my first playthrough I was amazzed at the assassination styles. Perhaps amazed is a buit too strong a word, but it was still pretty close to it. If they come up with a second game then I am all for buying it, too. I absolutely recommend this game to others. = )

Historically, stealth games leave me feeling like 'I'm doing it wrong'. That I haven't followed the path the developer planned, leading to mass shoot-outs when all else fails. If that sounds familiar to you then Dishonoured might just be the perfect remedy. Set in a steam-punk universe were swords and pistols live along side whale oil powered machines, you play the role of Corvo, guardian to the Empress. After the Empress is murdered before your eyes, you set out to find her daughter Emily and exact revenge on the perpatrators.   A wealth of powers assist you on your journey, boosted by collecting runes and bones to upgrade as you go. Slow down time, teleport with blink and even possess living beings. The story takes several twists, some depending on the actions you chose earlier in the game, adding replay value to an already sizable game.  Highly recommended 9/10

I can't believed I waited two years before playing 'Dishonored'! The game's visuals were appealing, a mix of Victorian and future-tech that was not quite steampunk, with a touch of the cartoonish look from 'Team Fortress 2'. The game's design was surprisingly impressive and had to be experienced in order to be fully appreciated.  The freedom with which players could go about completing missions as Corvo was very enjoyable. Whether it be with aggression (high chaos) or with stealth (low chaos), there were always multiple ways to traverse the varied environments to one's liking. (But, anyone who had played 'Dishonored' would likely agree the teleport power, 'Blink', was the BEST aspect of the gameplay.) This individualized experience made completion of each mission very satisfying.  Two of the game's DLCs featured Daud, leader of a group of assassins in the main game, in his own side story during the events of 'Dishonored'. Daud's story was less engaging and consequential than Corvo's, but allowed for a few impressive set pieces and slight variations to his supernatural powers to make the DLCs somewhat worthwhile to play. Enemy AI seemed to have had a bit of tweaking for the DLCs, making the transition from the main game a bit jarring.

This game is awesome. I highly recommend it. As it is a console port, the aliasing is horrible, but you can fix it with nvidia inspector. Likewise, the colors are a bit washed out and the textures are small. Do a little searching on the internet to find some ini tweaks to fix the texture problems and use Sweetfx to fix the lackluster dynamic range. As far as the gameplay goes, the AI isn't amazing, but the game can be challenging enough to be fun on the highest difficulty. Try doing a pacifist run. That's where this game really shines for me.

A short but fun game with a great art style and a fantastic setting. The combat is simple, the stealth is passable, the dialogue ranges from mediocre to great, and the movement -- despite some minor problems with ledges and stray geometry -- is smooth and fun. Teleporting around with the Blink power is the most fun I've had simply going from Point A to Point B in a video game.  My main complaint is with the Chaos system, which is pretty much just the same hackneyed morality system that infests so many games. Despite killing scores of people being so fun and easy, doing so will give you an ending that's very dark in tone, while blinking around to knock people out and deposit them in out-of-the-way places becomes samey, dull, and a bit silly.  Despite this, I still recommend this game, especially to people who enjoyed Dark Messiah of Might and Magic.

I played this game on the hardest mode available on the two day free weekend. And beat it. Twice.  This game, is, addictive. Period. It's a stealthy combat game meant for the best of assasins.  In it, you play as Corvo Attano, the royal guard to the Empress of the city in which you live. (Sorry, forgot the name.) I won't spoil a drop of this story. It's too good. Honestly, it is a driving story with the constant fear of being discovered by one of the many different kinds of enemies that keep this game playable more than a single go around. I'd gladly play this game again, and intend to purchase it to do so.  A few things to note:  -Some of the voice acting is... Well... Bad. The character almost seems disconnected from the world when they speak in certain segments. This isn't a singular character, and honestly isn't such a major issue as to make the game unplayable. -Non-lethal routes, though entirely possible (I killed a total of two people my second time through.), aren't as well set as the lethal routes. You're given mines, grenades, guns, crossbow bolts, and a few special ways to kill people, but limited ways to do so without so. Recommendation to anyone who can alter the path of future games like this, try to offer more upgradeable ideas for the non-lethal side as well. -If there is a body, it will eventually be found. If you don't want to raise alarms, remove the bodies. Simple as that. Non-lethal: If it's hidden, hide it better.  Aside from that, the game is a fantastic stealth shooter that allows the player to do quite a bit of customization and the likes. With a compelling story line, and fantastic AI systems, the game is worth the money.

Overall, this game has been given the thumbs up. It has a unique style and theme, almost steam-punk-assassin-victorian amalgamation, a simple, clear-cut story with a few plot twists inside, and a host of characters and interactions that make it worth to play. What REALLY sets this apart from other FPS stealth games are the power combinations and manipulations you can have in this game. With a good variety of abilities, and good timing, you can make impossible tasks seem like child's play. In some instances, you can manipulate time, and other people, to make a man shoot himself. Combine that with the great variety of weapons available in the game, you can create a 'rat bomb'. This little trick involved summoning a few rats, freezing time, attaching a mine to one of them, taking over the mine-strapped rat, and then moving the rat into a group of enemies. Then, kaboom.   However, sometimes too much of a good thing can kill a game. This was almost the case with Dishonored, as it implemented a morality engine that forced players who wanted a good ending to find other ways to take out targets without killing people or being seen. While this puts great emphasis on an otherwise great stealth engine, it now limits the player from using all the cool weapons and abilities he's been given, for fear of not getting the ending he wants. This, in my mind, kills the whole mood of a game about an ASSASSIN. I feel like Dishonored tried to implement something unique, but took good ideas from others games as well (I.E Deus Ex: HR, Thief) and sadly killed alot of the amazing things about it.  TL;DR: Buy this game on sale, play it a couple times, gaze at it in your library for a long time until you forget all about the game.  6.5/10

Steps forward!  So this game isn't the perfect stealth game, but it's better than most (looking at you new Thief game). You have numerous ways to approach a situation and kill, and you can choose to be the powerhouse murderer, or you can walk through the shadows and dodge enemies while finding pacifist, but just and cruel ways to dispach your targets. The latter proves to be more fun, and the World of Dunwall is GORGEOUS. Playing this game on its highest graphical settings is a must if you can. I slides past realism and goes for a cartoonish aesthetic that only helps make it feel more real.  Since it's an older title now (or rather, not brand new), you can probably get it for cheap during a sale, and if you're into single-player campaign games, then this is a must. Wonderful visual style, great mechanics, and well-balanced gameplay. The story is a little bit predictable, even for my first play through, but it was well written nonetheless and is quite unique.  Pros: -I loves me some well-animated stabbing people in the necks from behind <3 -Looks great, though that's to be expected from the visual art director behind Half-Life 2. -Great combat mechanics, though I didn't have to fight close up very often. (Thank you Skyrim.) -Unique abilities and weapons, both of which I naturally wish I could have x.x  Cons: -A.I. could have been a little bit better, but well done in the whole scheme of things. -Only slightly buggy, came across some problems but not once a game-breaker. -Bit predictable with the story, but the end truly determines whether or not you kill everyone in sight or sneak around like a ninja. (Yes, the game's end and gameplay changes on kill count.)  With the time I've spent playing it, I can easily say this game was worth the purchase price. I would feel like a complete a** if I didn't give it a 10/10.

Gameplay:   The gameplay is what makes this game for me: fun, diverse, cathartic and rewarding. Only real problems are that there are some invisible walls and floors that will literally leave you floating in the air over buildings. Also, I wish there was a New Game+ mode for more fun high chaos runs.  I really like the fact that leveling up powers is simply done by collecting runes. It doesn't matter if you're merciful or psychotic during the game, your power is only dictated by how willing you are to hunt around for runes and bone charms.   9/10  Presentation:   This artstyle can be hit or miss. I like it personally, but sometimes I think of Half Life when I look at character models. I've never even played Half Life.   The levels are pretty damn cool though.   7/10   Story:   Unfortunately this story only really happens because the main character is a victim of circumstance. Making him a silent protagonist just kind of ruined the chance of me taking anything the story threw at me seriously.    I wasn't even mad or shocked when your loyalist companions poison you and leave you for dead. I was just left being completely apathetic.    The only real character that can make some kind of emotional connection is Emily, the one you're supposed to protect so she ends up being empress someday. Moments with her do feel kind of nice and cute, but they're short lived.   There's a moral choice system in this game, and it's not a bad idea (it actually makes a bit of sense) but with Corvo being completely mute, the only real consequences happen to the robotic companions you meet throughout the entire game. I really could not give a damn about them. Live, die, I don't care. I just wanna kill people in creative ways.  5/10  Fun:  9/10  Play this game for the gameplay, it really is that awesome.  Overall Score: 7.5 / 10

It took me a little while to warm up to this game, but I ended up really liking it. There are numerous paths you can take to complete each level; you can choose to be stealthy, trying to sneak through without being noticed, or you can just rush in and kill everything in sight. The choices you make have effects on later parts of the game, too.  It's probably best to choose early on whether you want to be stealthy or violent (similar to how you can choose to be good or evil in, say, Infamous) as this choice will influence the upgrades and equipment you purchase as the game progresses. Also, if you choose to be stealthy, it will definitely help to make use of the quick save (F5) and load (F9) keys :)  You can definitely feel some thematic influence from Half-Life, especially in the later parts of the game. It's much less linear than Half-Life, though, and there are plenty of side quests you can choose to complete. I'd say these are worth completing, too, since a lot of the characters you encounter make appearances in later missions.  Overall, a very good game that made me want to play through it again using different techniques. Beautiful art style too.
mindblowing...fantasic....dont miss it ever.........best game i have played till now

You begin the game as Corvo, Lord Protector of the Empress of Dunwall, but soon find yourself stripped of that title and imprisoned for her alleged murder. You must escape, clear your name and ultimately restore her daughter, Emily, to the throne.  You'll take on a string of missions through a city riddled with plague and corruption, taking out those in power by assassination or indirect means. Each mission involves several openly designed zones, where you may freely explore to find upgrades, ammo, coin and optional objectives along the way.  Both stealth and brute-force playstyles are viable, with a wide array of weaponry and powers at your disposal. Blink instantly from point to point; possess rats and fish to tunnel your way in, or guards to walk them to a secluded area for disposal; stop time to sneak past a group of enemies or slaughter them all undetected; or just go in guns blazing.   A lot of fun, looks amazing, well-optimized, and has great level design. Highly recommended. 420/10, Would Play Again

Sometimes you play a game that's so good that you don't really know how to write a review for it. This is one such game. I've been a bit jaded by gaming in recent times and I've instead been playing smaller titles such as Mark of the Ninja. AAA titles seem so fancy and big and overdone. I found myself avoiding them. But then I tried Dishonored. It starts off merely okay. First 1-2 missions are nothing great. You wonder what the fuss was about. But then you keep playing and start understanding the genius behind the game. By mid-game, a singular level is more interesting and unqiue then most full games. It's just a fantastic game. It's art. Especially on a good PC, it's art. It really is. I haven't enjoyed a game this much in a long, long time. And it's never frustrating. That's the best part. It's tough and tests your intelligence but there is always a way to get the mission done. It's the game the new Hitman wishes it were. The game respects you like games of the early-2000s did. I honestly don't know what I can say to prove that this game is the best of maybe our generation.

I absolutely love Dishonored. That's honestly all I can say. I have purchased 2 of the DLCs where you play as Daud, and I have completed the game at least 4 times before. I loved Dishonored, and I honestly don't know why I've fallen in love with the story and gameplay. Dishonored kept me entertained for so long, and I know I'm just one of many people out there that understand where I'm coming from.  I'll stop talking about how delightful Dishonored is, and I'll tell you about the game itself: Dishonored is a Stealth game where you're on a mission. (No Spoilers beyond, don't worry) (One more thing though: If you don't want to know the storyline, move on please) Basically you play as the Empress's Guard, and as you're returning from a journey to learn more about the rat plague currently going on, the Empress is killed.  I will let you figure out the rest. As for the DLCs, I find the stories just as interesting. The DLCs are of course, shorter, but still have stories. But they mainly focus on missions, not storylines. The 2 DLCs I own are: The Knife of Dunwall & The Brigmore Witches. Both of these DLCs are excellent, and if you buy Dishonored and enjoy the game, I would recommend buying these 2 DLCs as well.  That's really all I have to say about the game. As I mentioned before, I love Dishonored, and I have no complaints about the game. I know there are flaws in the game, but I was very impressed with the game, and had fun playing it the entire time. I won't mention any flaws in the game because I simply can't think of any at the moment.  On further note: I would recommend this game to anyone interested in buying it. AND if you're looking for a Stealth game, Dishonored is probably one of the top games that you should have on your list.

Even though the main story is kind a meh but the overall gameplay AND The Knife of Dunwall DLC makes up for that , the gameplay is super fun with playstyle that you can choose , want to go sneaky and don't kill anyone ? sure !! , want to go ham and just slaughter everyone ? SURE !! both gameplay is fun using these'void' power is super fun and both have a different ending since the ending is about how much 'Chaos' you did and Chaos comes from a lot of killing .  Even though another 2 DLC is kind a pointless but i highly suggest you play both The Knife of Dunwall and The Brigmore Witches it's just really great DLC i think the story , characters in The Knife of Dunwall is actually a lot more interesting than the main story , The Brigmore Witches is okay still worth it but not as great as Knife of Dunwall for sure.  Still Dishonored is a really great game and it's getting sequel already !! So if you like what you see just buy it and you won't regret it.

I've played this game quite extensively on the PS3, and finally decided to pick it up on Steam too after one of the latest sales. so I could re-live it and play it more easily. I LOVE this game. It's a great game, the world has been so extensively thought out and built, you can tell they've put a lot of effort into it. The story is somewhat typical, but still good: you play as Corvo, who was once the Lord Protector for Empress Jessamine Kaldwin, until she was killed by the infamous assassin Daud before your very eyes and you were framed for her murder and the kidnap of her daughter, Emily. Knowing your innocence, and helped by those who believe your innocence too, you seek to find Emily to restore her to the throne, as well as seek revenge on those who framed you. There's a host of cool powers and weapons in the game, and it's worth playing with them all, but personally I think it's the stealthy approach where I think the game truly shines. The characters are great and well rounded. Dunwall itself is based around a steampunk-y England, but there's a definite dark and gritty tone to it. The main campaign can be played quite quickly if you want to, but there's so much replayability about it.   The DLC is great too. I haven't played much of the City Trials but they offer a new challenge for veterans of the game. But the real prize are the Knife of Dunwall and Brigmore Witches DLCs. Here you play as Daud (the assassin who killed the Empress), and learn his story. His story is so much more gripping and interesting than Corvo's, and he has so much depth to him, as he struggles with the guilt of what he's done, and faces his own enemies. Daud has his own powers to use, and visits completely new locations, and so it's definitley worth playing. Maybe I like a bit of a redemption story, or an anti-hero type character, but I really loved Daud's story and the DLC missions to the main game.  Overall, a great game, one I thoroughly recommend.

Great, great game that had me completeley engrossed. Can be played guns blazing or as a stealth game (which I preferred and recommend as it makes the game a lot more challenging) with a simple and predictable yet well-crafted story and great believable characters. One of the best things about the game is that it manages to create a believable world that feels lived-in and real thanks to the gorgeous environments, presence of moving, talking NPCs that react to your actions as well as its rich lore that you learn about by listening to the announcements from the loudspeakers or by picking up and reading the many sources of information scattered throughout the game. The kick-♥♥♥ abilities that you get are also an absolute blast to use and experiment with and make this game unlike any other of its kind. Best.movement.aka.teleportation.ability EVER! You can also play the entire game without killing anyone and the manner in which you deal with the stage 'bosses' without resorting to lethal force is always different, creative and highly entertaining: bad people seriously get their comeuppance here xD. Add in a simple yet effective upgrade system and stage collectibles that serve to further enhance your abilities and you can stretch this into several hours of gametime. I also highly recommend the 2 story DLCs as they add more depth to the story and are a lot of fun as you get to learn more about Daud the leader of the Assassins and his road to redemption (or not). And if you've paid attention to the lore in the game you'll finally be able to encounter the Witches of Brigmore and they are badass. Also, the manner in which you can deal with their leader without resorting to lethal force and without being seen at the end of the second dlc is downright f***ing cool.  9.5/10

In all honesty, this is one of my favorite games, but it needs to be played right to really present a challenge. You can turn your character into a demigod of meat-grinding-spinning-executions pretty easily; the most basic skill in the game is pretty overpowered. The REAL fun in Dishonored is never resorting to that- this is a game that makes stealth challenging but richly rewarding. You can literally go through the game and not kill a single person and watch as fate and karma catch up to the worst of the worst, or take their fate into your own hands and play the roll of the truly witty assassin and take only those you feel need to meet their end by your own hand.  Gameplay aside, the storytelling and environment in this game is immersive and both excessively beautiful and grim. Make sure you use the Heart often- its whispers are more than interesting. I strongly suggest this game over others like Assassin's Creed where real stealth isn't much of an option.

Dishonored is without a doubt one of the best games i have played in a long while, even though it was released in 2012 and this is 2014... But that´s not the point. And i don´t quite understand why the main character Corvo never talks for the hole game, and this is something i´ve never quite liked in video-games with a few exceptions like skyrim, where it doesnt really matter if your character speaks or not, because you don´t really care. But nonetheless this is still a great game and should be one that every stealth game enthusiastic should definitely play. It definitely earns a 8/10.

Once in awhile, you come across a game that you would play from start to finish and at the end of it, you don't totally hate it because you sorta enjoyed it but you can't say it's something you would replay or recommend wholeheartedly to someone else. Dishonored is one such game.  Don't get me wrong. this is a good game. Gameplay is smooth, PC controls works, graphics is cool, storyline is sorta serviceable. But it somehow lacks a spark somewhere. I'm not sure what it was myself. This is supposed to be some kinda stealth game, but frankly, you could just blast your way through the whole thing Duke Nukem(TM) style pretty easily. The lack of a 3rd-person view angle makes stealth gameplay frustrating. After the 10th time getting caught hidding in a place where i swear the guard can't possibly see me, i pray to 3DRealms, transform into Duke Nukem(TM) and never look back.  The game world frankly is also kinda weird. It's a sorta steampunk + mystical world where industrial machinery coincides with the mystical fantasy of the occult. The world is a bunch of island empires and you're in one of the biggest ruled by a monarchy. Whaling is the main industry and whale oil powers all the machinery. But there is the mystical 'Outsider' who is foreign by all accounts and deals with magic. Yup, magic.  Also, all the talk about empires and power struggle seems a bit odd when throughout the game, all you saw were discrepit buildings, soldiers or some zombie-ish commoners struck by the plague. Yup, they got zombie-ish thingy threw into the pot too :-|  While the game is executed very well, the content is a letdown. The world is shallow and frankly, a frankenstein of steampunk, magic, shooter, swordplay, stealth and zombies. They try to 'pad' the content background by having books/notes on the backstory where you can pick up and read and i read every one of them that i came across. Still, it felt like the content is really thin and you don't know much more about the game world after the first 2 levels. Neverthless, i actually quite enjoyed the game and did a run through but i wont be replaying this since the world/content just doesn't feel 'right'.  Still, i would recommend this game solely because it's a well executed game and also an enjoyable experience. Just don't expect too much depth from the game world.

This is, simply put, a very superb game.  Stealth gameplay is well thought-out, there are numerous approaches to your mission and a lot of powers and gadgets to help you on your way. This game enables you to endlessly (ab)use your environment for sneaking, takedowns etc. During my first playthrough, I went for low chaos and it was (gadgets and powers aside) still challenging enough to keep me occupied and fun enough to not be frustrating. The ending on Low chaos is also immensely satisfying.  My second playthrough was guns (swords? powers?) blazing high chaos madness. This is very fun as well, the shooting and crazy running, sword fights (you can really see Arkane's touch here) and I'm pleased to see a game where all the weapons and gadgets are equally deadly if used right. However, this is also one of my gripes: a lot of the things in this game are overpowered. Now, I'm not really a huge fan of games like System Shock 2 where your character is really puny and helpless, but Dishonored is another extreme: you're virtually indestructible (once you reach a certain point in the game). I did not try to up the difficulty, but I doubt it would've made a huge difference; a Level II Windblast or a Bend Time/Bloothrirsty massacre would still probably wipe enemies with ease. Also, the High chaos ending is really, REALLY dark and depressing, so think carefully about what playing style you choose.  Another thing I've noticed about this game, which is a huge bonus for me, is that it has this 'Half-Life' vibe to it; I dont' know why, but it just reminds me of Half-Life 2 for some reason and even the original Half-Life. Perhaps it is the pacing: there's a really good balance between story, action and exploration.  All in all, a great game, one of those games sure to be on 'must-play' lists in the future. If I had to sum it up in one sentence, it would be 'BioShock and Half-Life 2 had a steampunk baby whose occasional nanny was Dark Messiah of Might and Magic'.

Unique, well-realized world, solid action/stealth with light RPG elements and an intriguing story. Solid purchase.   Dishonored is a first-person action/stealth RPG created by Bethesda Softworks. The player assumes the role of Corvo, personal bodyguard to the Empress of the Isles. Corvo embarks on a long quest for revenge that takes the form of missions that revolve around assassinating various targets and gathering intel to help Corvo in his quest.  The atmosphere is awesome - the setting is pretty distinctly 18th century, but with some neat futuristic technology and magic sprinkled in. It's tough to talk about the story without giving anything away, but I was immediately sucked in to it, and I had a difficult time putting it down.  There is a nice variety to the missions, and they never felt boring or repetitive. The quests offer multiple means of achieving objectives that merit several replays (there is an option to replay individual missions). In addition to main quest objectives, there are always interesting sidequests and jobs to pursue.   Corvo has a variety of gadgets to aid him in his quest. Grenades, traps, a pistol, a small sword/dagger, and a crossbow with incendiary and sleep-inducing darts. Corvo also has powers that allow him to see through walls, teleport, slow time, and more. Corvo's gear and powers can be upgraded through in-game currency and through runes and bonecharms that you gather in each mission.   Generally, the player is offered lethal and non-lethal options while playing through missions. A lethal playstyle will lead to increased enemy presence and the addition of other obstacles to future missions; to be honest, it feels as if the player is penalized for a bloody playthrough, and stealth is flat out more entertaining and challenging.   Overall, I highly recommend Dishonored, and I rate it a must-play. The world is interesting, and the story engaging. The gameplay feels tight, and the content of the missions is wonderful.

Unlike many people that happen to rave about this game, I cannot in good conscious recommend it to others. Yes, the story is great, yes the idea is quite well made, and the environment is beautiful...but that's about where it ends.  Here's a big thing. You get demerits of sorts for killing people. Rats and the plague spread more if you kill more. Yet...there are only two ways to knock out an enemy. 1 being in VERY limited supply and expensive to procure, the other being inefficient if you're near any shape or form of a group of enemies.  So you get two choices really. Be a murderer with a hard game, or be a cheater. Kill everything in sight or keep on reloading those save files/ running away like a madman.  Add that with the fact that outside the detail of the outfits the actual models of the characters are rather poor unless they are extremely important, and even then it's lackluster in comparison to the beauty of the environment.  All in all, it was a great idea, but the execution wasn't the best. If there were more ways to take out enemy non-lethally...instead of 'Here's you sword, gun, explosives, arrows, and everything you need to kill people horribly!' this could actually work its way really high up as a game, but as it is I cannot say I recommend this. In where it does things well there are things that it does horribly too in turn, and those horribly done things glare in contrast to the good. Hopefully they can further improve it for the sequel as it really does have great potential.

One of the very few games that has managed to blow my mind.  Dishonored places you as a Magical Assasin out for revenge after being betrayed by the ones he once thought of as friends. On the day you were meant to be executed for your supposed crimes, you were broken out of prison by a group of people calling themselves the Loyalists, people who knew the truth about what had really happened the day you were betrayed.   The gameplay itself is sex. You have acess to a variety of gadgets and abilites that can be chained together to preform intense combos against enemies, or prehaps you want the good ending, and want to sneak around and kill no one. Use teleportation to blink from ledge to ledge, or slow down time and fire a crossbow bolt at everyone before they can blink. Place a springrazor on a rat and watch as enemies are cleaved apart as the rat runs through them... Dishonored gives the player many options on how they would like to play.  The story is amazing, easily the most detailed world EVER introduced by a game. Find books and learn about the world, read a persons last note to their loved ones before they died of the plague, easedrop on guards to learn about events happening in the world. The game is vast and delivers a satisfying story that will leave you with a sense of wonder.    EASILY the best game I have ever played, and the only game I can honestly give a GatheredforWhiskeyAndCigars/10.

Ive played through Dishonored two times now, and here is my list of pros and cons.  Pros: - Smooth Gameplay - Graphics quite like The Walking Dead Video Game (Which I love) - Fun assassinations and many fun ways to kill guards and assassinate targets - Great plot and storyline - Well designed levels - Great dialogue and voice acting - Lots of places to explore - Many upgrades for weapons, spells, and tons of abilities to discover (bone charms) - Dozens of ways to approach and complete levels (Non-Lethal, High Chaos) - Lots of replay value  Cons: - A bit too easy - Save/Quicksave system is horrible   As you can see there is very little wrong with this game. This is definitely one of my favorite games by far and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes stealth games. Make sure to check out Dishonored 2 when it is released this year!!

TL;DR: In sum, please buy Dishonoured if you are thinking of it. I would say the base game is enough, although GOTY version is not much dearer so go with that, but wait for a good sale, not on full price. It has a very distinct art style, and I fell it really captures the human heart of a pandemic situation.   Dishonoured is not a long game. You will not play it throughg over and over again for the story. Do you know then, how I managed to put over 100 hours into this? I will tell you why and you might do as well:  Dishonoured has environments that are extremely rich with detail. There are these characters, and a mostly forgetable tale about them, but what really captivated me was the City of Dunwall, and it's story. It is the story of a town that was prosperous and powerful, then a terrible illness befell it, and it is engrossing how that affected the man on the street, which you see quite often.  In the very first level, I remember well there are two putrid corpses of a man and a woman hugging, one of them wrote a note about how they had to hide here and they have run out of medicine and they just want to spend their last moments together. In another level you find a house with letters wtitten by a woman who lost first her husband, then her daughters too, before she finally fell. These stories of the lives of regular people is the single most engrossing thing for me in Dishonoured, and why I explored every level thoroughly, strived to find every rune, every secret, pick up every coin, etc. When I played the game, I really felt for all those poor people, and it made me think about those who suffer similarly in our worl, for instance, from ebola, or smallpox in it's day.

A first person adventure game with fun and unique mechanics. 'Dishonored' gives the player multiple possible ways to interact with the world in order the achieve a certain goal. These character abilities are well mixed with the surroundings and it is easy to get ost in the different paths one can take.   All of these mechanics are enveloped in an interesting revenge story, which drives the narrative forward and for the most part it works pretty well. We are not left questioning the choices undertaken by the protagonist, because they feel well reinforced by his current predicament.   'Dishonored' is a well blended mixture of stealth, action and storytelling. It is totally worth a look!

In a nutshell: Dishonored is short-ish, but sweet. Definitely worth the price, as is the story DLC.   Although it's short, Dishonored has a good level of replayability, with the addition of a 'missions' tab where you can revisit any level you like (with the powers and skills you had at that point in your playthrough, naturally).  The combat is very basic, yet enjoyable, and you can make it more fun with the aid of your powers. Speaking of which, powers aren't just for combat, either. You can apply them in stealth and navigation, along with finding new and unique ways of reaching your targets.   And the way you play the game does affect the way the city changes around you. If you're a murderous psychopath, plague and the weepers (zombies) that come with it becomes much more rampant. This can cause problems for you in some circumstances.  If you're a sneaky peacekeeper, the problems you face along the way will be less dire, and the City Watch will not be as zealous.  To summarise; why are you still reading this, buy the game ffs, it's amazing.

Dishonored is a fantastic game.  Since I usually play through games once, I wanted to get the most out of my run and liked the option to finish the game non-lethal I decided on a Clean Hands/Shadow run.  It was awesome to go through the levels slowly, trying to not get noticed.  Sometimes it got frustrating because you aren't notified if you fail the requirements until you finish the level. This means you often have to play through the whole level again, because you don't know where you failed and can't reload from a specific save.  There's nothing wrong with the gameplay, the shooting feels good, takedowns are alright, blinking around is pretty great.  The story is pretty basic, nothing great but it does it's job.  I definitely recommend this game, especially with the upcoming release of the sequel. It's totally worth it.

I almost forgot how good Dishonored really is. The story itself is a tale of revenge and it does it well. Even though Corvo (the main character) does not talk, it is easy to understand why he desires revenge, and in that respect the story is very compelling. The voice acting for the other characters is good. It is not amazing, but it does the job. The gameplay however, is fantastic. If you played Bioshock, you'll be able to slip right into Dishonored. The game gives you A TON of freedom to play how you want. You can go through the enitre game and not kill anybody or you can kill everyone if you want. Depending on which path you chose, it will effect the story in a profound way. The powers you are able to use are pretty cool, but some are much better then others. Blink, Dark Vision, and Slow Time were the only ones I used, and even if you plan to kill everyone, the more agressive powers are not all that useful. The stealth mechanics are great and mesh very well with all the powers. Even though the game is almost 4 years old, the graphics and sound design have held up very well. The whole game looks like a water color painting. Overall, Dishonored is a fantastic game and a purchase you will not regret.   FINAL VERDICT: 9/10  BEST ASPECT: THE MULTIPLE GAMEPLAY OPTIONS  WORST ASPECT: THE VOICE ACTING...IF I HAD TO PICK SOMETHING

Dishonored is a 1st person experience for those players who want to feel the thrill of being the classy assassin who is never seen by your enemies in the most pacifist manner or the ruthless one who doesn't leave a trace of his victims (doesn't matter if is friend or foe). You enter in the shoes of Corvo Attano. A man stripped of his honor as Lord Protector in service of the Empress who mysteriously is assassinated and her daughter kidnapped. With the perpetrator on the run. Corvo is framed by a crime he didn't committed and its your mission to correct this grave error. Engaging Characters with a thrilling and suspenseful story. This game will make you feel like you can't truly trust anybody. If you're into Stealth games or looking for a game with deep story about betrayal similar to The Count of Montecristo, look no further. Highly recommended!

Way, way, way too short.   Probably one of the most 'flexible' games, in terms of how to kill stuff, which is awesome. But it's way too easy and short if you actually use any of these tools and abilities, and even trying to be mostly stealthy only increases the playtime by a few hours.  For the price (now around $20 prior to any sales), I still have to recommend it, as there's a lot of creativity in killing stuff. But the campaign is way too short unless you are a 100% stealther and 100% completionist. Really, I found probably 70% or more of the runes, goodies, etc., and did some side quest stuff, and even tried to rely on stealth as much as possible, and it still took just 7 or 8 hours to get through.  Overall, it's got a good story, and playing stealthy or playing brutally affects the ending, and it's always a fun playground for figuring out new ways to kill stuff. Missions themselves are also very well done.   But the length is very short, and without any DLC there's very little in terms of just going around killing stuff for fun. And certain abilities are just absolutely OP... teleport, for one, is super powerful, as I personally had 2 missions (of maybe a total of 12) where I found ways to simply teleport through or around the hardest sections. And sleeping darts are more scarce than you'd think, so, again, you would rather rely on some (admittedly cool) traps and gadgets, but this only makes the experience shorter.  Very good game, and now at decent price for it's length. At initial release it was too expensive for the play-time you probably would get out of it beating it while trying to find everything, but definitely worth it now.  EDIT: My total play-time of something like 14 hours actually includes beating it *twice*. It's that short. I played it mostly stealthily for about 8 hours while trying to find stuff and really get into side objectives, and it took maybe 4 more hours to beat it while playing it like it was Doom 2. Last two hours were spent re-playing parts just to mess around killing stuff.

Dishonored is a game I would rate among the best I have ever played. I purchased the game in early 2013 and have been playing it ever since, sometimes emphatically. The story arcs are tasteful and well thought out, and the fact that Corvo is a silent protagonist only adds to the experience, as you are allowed to have your own individual perspective regarding the events that are occurring in-game without a scripted voice telling you what to think, like so many other games do. The gameplay is phenomenal, and the graphics are impressive while retaining a very distinct style, which truly sets the tone along with the magnificent soundtrack that highlights everything you do perfectly.   The emphasis on the Chaos system makes for an interesting experience while Corvo tries desperately to clear his name and remove the usurpers from the throne, while his parallel, Daud, the legendary assassin who slew the Empress, has to deal with his own brand of betrayal while simultaneously having to worry about The Royal Protector coming for him. Every character in this game is dynamic, and each one reacts to the level of Chaos in the world differently. The Victorian-esque steampunk setting is quite unique, and you can change that setting to be very dark or relatively peaceful, (compared to what it could be) and everything in between. On top of all that, the DLCs rival the main storyline, coming with new mechanics and a very different perspective on the world. Overall I recommend this game far more than almost any other, and if you have not bought this game this is an excellent time to do so. I very much look forward to the second installment in this beloved world of ours, and you should too.

... What to say about this game. Well, it's fantastic with a huge amount of replay value, every mission can be completed a different way, every Corvo can be different. The graphics are still amazing to this day. There is almost no story, but that's not a big problem. As I said above, every mission can be completed differently, every target killed with a different weapon in a different spot. The magic and the combat in this game fuse beautifully. Wanna teleport behind people and slit their throat? You can do it! Wanna slow time and kill everyone? You can do it! Though, I find the blocking a bit shoddy. Personally, I'm tired of games telling you what to do, this game doesn't!! You don't have to kill anyone, you can kill everyone, whatever you want. Use your environment to your advantage! Play the game however you want to play it. In my opinion the only dlc worth buying is the Knife of Dunwall and the Brigmore Witches. Those two dlc are like games of their own. The Void Walker Arsenal and the Dunwall City Trials. They give you extra money and some new weapons and well, trials. Personally I don't recommend the Void Walker but you might enjoy the Dunwall City Trials. I just don't like 'trials'. Definitely #3 on my top ten favorite games 9/10

Despite being retro rather than futuristic, Dishonored feels like the proper sequel to the original Deus Ex. It gives the player imaginative, open levels to tackle with a set of diverse and wonderfully 'video gamey' powers.  At times, the game feels a little easy. With your powers, you're laughably more powerful than any regular enemy you will run into, though the game can be completed without using them. My advice for a regular playthrough is to own your mistakes and only use autosave. It makes the game's Chaos dynamic much more meaningful, too. In Dishonored, your mistakes don't often end with your death and a reload, but with a room full of your dead enemies.

Pros: 1) Combat is fun. 2) Stealth is fun. 3) Level design is quite strong. With the exception of the very first gameplay section, all of the missions may be approached in different ways. You will likely do things the hard way on your first playthrough (unless you just shoot everyone), but there are many other routes and approaches to most of your targets, which keeps things interesting on later playthroughs.  Cons: 1) The game is quite short. You will likely finish your first playthrough of the game in well under 20 hours, which is a bit disappointing... That said, the game has a degree of replayability due to its level design and the moderate diversity of spooky magical abilities. 2) The story is mediocre in most places, and the characters aren't very interesting. It isn't a big deal since the gameplay is strong enough to compensate. 3) The morality system is dumb. It feels like someone pitched it early in development as part of a marketing gimmick, but nobody seems to have found a good way of implementing it. Basically, the plague gets worse if you kill a bunch of people. There doesn't seem to have been much thought put into this though. You are either a thoughtful and disciplined individual who puts aside their own personal troubles for the good of others, or you are a vengeful monster that only wishes to see the world die in agony. There is very little grey area inbetween. It is quite annoying and more than a little bit silly.  TL;DR : The gameplay is fun. The 'morality' system is absurdly black-and-white, and should arguably never have been included. Buy it if you want a fun stealth game, but don't expect much from the story.

First things first,before I say anything, I want to say that this is an incredible game. Now this game casts you as Corvo, the body guard of the royal empress of Dunwall. After tradgedy strikes the city Corvo is forced to become an assassin and lead the fight to free the city from it's new oppresive leader. This game features primarily stealth gameplay though it is optional, you don't have to sneak if you want. It's fully possible to beat the game running and gunning and murdering everyone that stands in your way. It's also possible to complete the entire game without killing a single person. There are side quests you can complete within each level and many collectibles that can allow you to upgrade your sneaky assassin powers. The gameplay is incredibly smooth and addicting, the game's graphics aren't the best so it doesn't take a powerful PC to run it. Thankfully, the graphics don't hinder the overall experience. The music is great and the overall atmosphere is incredible. I would fully reccomend this game to any gamer who likes great games.
