'REVENGE SOLVES EVERYTHING'  Dishonored was developed by Arkane Studios, and published by Bethesda Softworks known as TES or Fallout series.The story unfold itself in Dunwall City based around steampunk and occult.The game line proceed on FPS and you can use strong supernatural powers like magic, novelty gadgets.You complete the assassination task with using them.The so‐called 'stage passing system ' but each stage exist many infiltration routes in all the upper/lower/left/right directions so you can capture them flexibility.This game focus on assassination but was designed for killing nobody on the other hand. That is no exception to the target.Your playing style have great effect on ending.   Dishonored is a splendid game but I think if there is the new game+ mode, it become more fantastic.That is way, to acquire or upgrade supernatural powers, you need Rune.I enjoyed exploring stages and finding Rune in the first playing, but I felt slightly laziness finding them after the new game+.You can also collect Bone Charms which impart permanent boosts and buffs to your character, but the grate part of them are not effective, I think.  DLC There are 4 DLC. Dunwall City Trials, The Knife of Dunwall, The Bridgmore Witches and Void Walker Arsenal. Dunwall City Trials is like challenging mode which is appointed the task and equipments. The Knife of Dunwall and The Bridgmore Witches are spin-off stories features more of legendary assassin who play important roll in the main story. They help you with understanding the story more deep. Void Walker Arsenal is pack which gain immediate access to four content bundles previously available only through pre-ordering Dishonored.  To start DLC, you select 'MISSIONS' in the menu and sellect 'DLC' next to 'CAMPAIGN'. This is a littele perplexed in a system side...  Something extra To skip logos which you can't skip, you have to edit ini file. (C:\Users\Username\Documents\My Games\Dishonored\DishonoredGame\Config\DishonoredEngine.ini) After you open ini file, you need to find [FullScreenMovie].Then you turn 'bForceNoStartupMovies=FALSE' into 'bForceNoStartupMovies=TRUE' in third line from [FullScreenMovie].  Conclusion If you like stealth action, steampunk or are emphasis on a process, you can enjoy this game greatly !

It's quite a short game as it only has 9 missions after all. But each of those missions will take you in a hell of a ride. Every mission gives you a lot of choices and freedom on how to approach and accomplish the given goal. You can either spare or murder everyone. Go break in the front door or sneak in as a rat, a fish, or a human. You could even disable the traps or rig and use them to your advantage. Not only that, but each of your actions have a consequence. Such as by murdering everyone, the upcoming levels will have a tighther security, more rats, and more weepers. The fate and treatment of the NPCs will also be affected depending on the overall actions that you've performed. There are also 3 different possible endings that will also be based on your actions, which I think makes up for its short game length as it adds a bit of a replay value to it.

So I finally finished this game, and decided to do a review on it after I'm actually done with it. I must say, this game is amazing; I've waited so long for this game to be on sale, and now I'm really tempted to buy Dishonored 2.   This game has a rich storyline, with a lot of plot twists and leave you wanting more. Of course, a game this good is bound to have tons of bugs etc. One of them being a glitch where I think I attempted the mission wrongly, and was not given the subsequent missions even though I've completed it and had to restart just so that I could continue the game; and there are certain parts where it is really glitchy, like for example I tried to toss the body, and it glitched at the fence instead of being tossed over the fence. However, this game provide a lot of action (basically you can kill anyone) and puzzles to solve. The decision you make (be it killing someone, doing a favor for them etc) will actually affect how the game will be played (but the ending will be the same). I didn't know about the hagfish & weepers until they attacked me, which should have been hinted to us, as well as the River Krusts which I never knew was a thing until I heard it's creepy noises and then it started firing at me.   Overall, a really good game; something similar to Thief, and a must have for anyone who is interested or have played Assasins' Creed before. I'm rating it 8/10

[This is my honest opinion. If you're the type of person that gets offended by opinions different from your own, DO NOT READ OR RATE MY REVIEW]    I've heard some persons have some difficulty getting into the game, and I do agree with them as someone who also didn't like the game at first. It's clear that this game IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. I don't believe it's just one thing of it, but varying things I've noticed in the game. Before I get into the good, let's sit down and talk about what could be turning some people off about the game:     Story is  okay . As far as first impressions go, the story doesn't get you hooked either. At most, it's quite good, but there's only like ONE moment that will surprise you in the storyline.    Stealth kills are so...boringly unsatisfying. First time I prefered not killing an enemy in a stealth game.    The only character I can see people liking is Emily   (and she's only present like 7% of the game)  . The rest of the characters don't really bring much life to the game at all.    Also a silent/mute protagonist? Doesn't help the game's appeal when it could have.    The game punishes you for killing enemies by comprimising its already generic story.     For a game that wants you to NOT kill anyone, there's only TWO ways to do so: Stealth choke or Sleep dart.    Potential Spoiler:    End boss was underwhelming? Probably because I spared their life too.       Potential Spoiler:    Good ending isn't really that good. Just feels like a normal ending to me. Kinda disappointing if that was your goal for not killing anyone.      Now you're probably asking: 'It sounds like you didn't like the game. Why rate it positive then?'. That's because I found  MY own way  to enjoy it. If you find yourself not liking the game, then at least try switching your style of play like I did. Usually when I play a stealth game, I always aim for killing my opponents steathily, however, this time I enjoyed rendering enemy AI unconscious and aiming for nothing less than the 'Ghost' achievement. Will this suit you? Maybe, maybe not, but what's important is that you try.  Now there is really only ONE positive of this game:  The gameplay . To some that may not be enough, but for others, it's enough to justify experiening the game. As far as stealth goes, it's pretty good.      Satisfying to get the 'Undetected' achievement and the 'Didn't kill anyone' achievement.     Rendering enemies unconscious other than killing them, is a better experience to me.     Different ways to kill enemies.     The powers are AWESOME. More stealth games should have them. Once you get the hang of using them, they're very useful.    It's also fun to abandon going stealth and just rip apart enemies like a mad lunatic. [This is my honest opinion. If you're the type of person that gets offended by opinions different from your own, DO NOT READ OR RATE MY REVIEW]    I've heard some persons have some difficulty getting into the game, and I do agree with them as someone who also didn't like the game at first. It's clear that this game IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. I don't believe it's just one thing of it, but varying things I've noticed in the game. Before I get into the good, let's sit down and talk about what could be turning some people off about the game:     Story is  okay . As far as first impressions go, the story doesn't get you hooked either. At most, it's quite good, but there's only like ONE moment that will surprise you in the storyline.    Stealth kills are so...boringly unsatisfying. First time I prefered not killing an enemy in a stealth game.    The only character I can see people liking is Emily   (and she's only present like 7% of the game)  . The rest of the characters don't really bring much life to the game at all.    Also a silent/mute protagonist? Doesn't help the game's appeal when it could have.    The game punishes you for killing enemies by comprimising its already generic story.     For a game that wants you to NOT kill anyone, there's only TWO ways to do so: Stealth choke or Sleep dart.    Potential Spoiler:    End boss was underwhelming? Probably because I spared their life too.       Potential Spoiler:    Good ending isn't really that good. Just feels like a normal ending to me. Kinda disappointing if that was your goal for not killing anyone.      Now you're probably asking: 'It sounds like you didn't like the game. Why rate it positive then?'. That's because I found  MY own way  to enjoy it. If you find yourself not liking the game, then at least try switching your style of play like I did. Usually when I play a stealth game, I always aim for killing my opponents steathily, however, this time I enjoyed rendering enemy AI unconscious and aiming for nothing less than the 'Ghost' achievement. Will this suit you? Maybe, maybe not, but what's important is that you try.  Now there is really only ONE positive of this game:  The gameplay . To some that may not be enough, but for others, it's enough to justify experiening the game. As far as stealth goes, it's pretty good.      Satisfying to get the 'Undetected' achievement and the 'Didn't kill anyone' achievement.     Rendering enemies unconscious other than killing them, is a better experience to me.     Different ways to kill enemies.     The powers are AWESOME. More stealth games should have them. Once you get the hang of using them, they're very useful.    It's also fun to abandon going stealth and just rip apart enemies like a mad lunatic. Once you get used to it, you get better at using the game's weaponry, as playing the game for the first time can wield a challenge.   Rating: 7 out of 10.

A action-stealth game of epic proportions, Dishonored is a game about choice, stealth, and that little panic that happens whenever someone looks your way at the wrong time.  In Dishonored you can make your way through the streets and sewers of the city of Dunwall as you sneak or slaughter your way through patroling foes and plagued citizens to accomplish your missions and explore a city on the verge of ruin. To help you on your way you have a number of otherworldly powers allowing you to teleport, manipulate time, summon rats, and other useful abilities.  You also have an arsenal of equipment to assist in your endevors, state of the art weapons, high tech gadgets, and a telescopic mask that will allow you to choose weather to fight your way through your enemies, or take a more subtle appoach and mearly knock them out.  Choice takes a major part of this game as you must not only choose your appoach through the missions and their multiple paths, but you must also choose how to deal with those who wronged you and caused your dishonor.  All in all Dishonored is a great game that will captivate stealth fans as well as offer something even for those who prefer a more direct route, as you explore a wonderful world on the brink of collapse.

This game is the best combination of the best story with awesome gameplay that I have ever played. You can completely choose your own playstyle and have a lot of different ways of achieving your goal. The design of this game was way infront of any other game from around 2012. If you were going to play Dishonored 2, I highly recommend that you first play Dishonored Definitive Edition (because the Daud DLC's give an amazing other side to the story about the killed Empress and her daughter that had to follow up the throne). This is one of the best games I have ever played and I really hope that Dishonored 2 will be as good because that would make my day :).

Edit: Note* After playing the DLC, The Game of the Year Edition is well worth it  There is one thing that sets Dishonored above the rest: level design.  Throughout the 9 levels, there are tons of ways to play: you can sneak through the sewers and come up through the kitchens, get on the roof and jump through an open window, posess a rat and sneak through a tunnel, find a guard house and rewire the traps, or even charge in with a sword and pistol, flinging wind and rats at any who oppose you. If you take your time to look, there is always another way to approach a mission, with both slaughtering everything in your path and leaving no trace of your presence being equally viable options, with the game even encouraging two playthroughs to accomodate both playstyles.   Aside from level design, the implementation of a simple ability, Blink, is fantastic. You have it by default after the prologue sections, and it just completely opens up the gameplay and adding a lot of depth to the level design. You can go up, over, and around obstacles quickly and efficiently and, if ever spotted, can get out of dodge with a little bit of foresight to backtrack quickly.  Another strong aspect to the game is the atmosphere. Dishonored takes place in the city of Dunwall, the heart of an empire in a steampunk era running off of whale oil. A rat plague has engulfed the city, killing or displacing most of the population. The entire game has a sense of dread, with homes abandoned, corpses everywhere, and the City Watch enforcing martial law to 'keep the peace' (read: slaughter anybody infected with the plague and blackmail everybody else to line their pockets). There is no hope, yet you are fighting for a better future by toppling the corrupt government that stole the throne -- just kidding, you're just trying to get revenge for your friends with benefits Empress getting murdered and clearing your name so her (and possibly your) daugher can take the throne.  It's the little things throughout the game that really make the game come to life. The letters to loved ones, the street gangs trying to scrape together a living, locked chests and hidden compartments that send you scrambling to find little scraps of information in order to pop open a secret area. The potions that heal your health and mana are competing elixirs designed to fight the plague. Multiple factions exist, trying to survive in the rat-infested city.  Collectibles in Dishonored are better overall than most games, as they actually have a function. Runes allow you to unlock more abilities granted by the Outsider, Bone Charms add small little boosts to make life a little easier, and gold and ammo are everywhere, allowing you to purchase a crapload of upgrades that are overall pretty terrible (almost every monetary upgrade improves your fighting capabilities, which means that stealth be damned).  The graphics are extremely dated, feeling like a mid to late 2000s game. It definitely feels like it was made with consoles in mind, including controls. Speaking of, controls work fantastically for both keyboard + mouse as well as controller.  Overall, Dishonored is one of my favorite games from this decade and spurred my interest in stealth-first action games. I plowed through to a platinum on the playstation, and it's even better a second time on PC. I give it a 9.5/10, and highly recommend it for both the casual and hardcore stealth players, whether you want to assassinate everybody in the city or make the entire government disappear without a trace.

I avoided Dishonored when it was being advertised, years ago, because by one look at it I knew it would be 'Half Life 2 meets Bioshock'. The art by Victor Antonov was very clearly 'butthurt because they didn't use my ideas in HL2 so I'll take it over here'.  I was not off the mark there, in any way. In fact, many lines of dialog, all the vehiclular designs, color schemes, and whole battles, arenas, events, and visual constructions of levels are blatantly Half Life 2. (let's see, 'you were in the wrong place at the right time', the entire 'strider battle' with tall boys, 'nova prospekt', 'captive in the metal transport cage/battle at the top of a tower', every single combine-i mean sokolov- vehicle's appearance, the blue metal structure walls blocking off streets.... I could go on?) Throw in the visually steampunk Bioshock aspects, and add in the Plasmid use... Toss a pile of Thief stealth aspects, and you have Dishonored.  Oh yeah, I was kind of expecting Corvo to have a voice actor? I guess they wised up in 2 and gave him one. Yet Another Mute Protagonist. While Corvo can be pretty amazing, when you look at him he's absolutely the blankest of blank slates, and has zero personality aside from the clear adoration of Emily. All the rest of the characters in the game - and specifically the DLC with Daud - have far more attachment and engagement with what's actually going on. I find it hard to believe that Corvo himself isn't dumb as a bag of hammers, given that he, as the Lord Protector and lover of Jessamine... *went out for months* while the clearly devious Spymaster was busy engineering the Empress' demise. I mean, how about 'no, sir, this is my post and it would be completely insane to leave it' comes to mind. With the flimsiness of that plot however, it also seems like the rest of the city is exactly as vapid as the protagonist.  There is so much potential in this game's world for story telling. So much, completely wasted with this game. However all that said:  It was an enjoyable game, fun to play, and fun to play again. While the quirky specifics of the achievements are indeed pretty weird (i'm going through a second time trying for clean hands, but not ghost and definitely not flesh and steel) I like exploration and definitely like the stealth aspects. I only wish that they'd allowed for more of a non-lethal Corvo! Playing the DLC as Daud at least you get the ability to increase the number of sleep darts you can use, but Corvo cannot?! Well, at least that still plays well enough with being able to use takedowns.   Even though visually the game is shamelessly HL2+Bioshock, it's at least internally consistent. However the art itself is garbage, undetailed, might as well be low-rez in many cases because they don't stand up to close inspection. If I look at it as 'they're all paintings', that's not bad at all, because the character design and lighting supports that pretty decently.  The clunky UI is clunky, the radial menu difficult to use at best, and the lack of hotkeys for certain things was dismaying.   I think my biggest beef with it is that you just don't get one straightforward story even though there's a shockingly linear progression through the game. There are hints in all the books and notes you find that there's something much more deep and entertaining, but *none* of it surfaces, ever.   The DLC and challenge levels are actually far more engaging than the main game, though the level design of Daud's story is far less clever and much more limited than the main game. I wish that the level design had kept up in terms of exploration and complexity, but that the main game had the personality of Daud's dlc.  Anyway - I do recommend the game, but don't expect anything other than highly derived locations and visuals, and if you've played either Bioshock or Half Life 2 understand that this game WAS designed by the same guy doing HL2's work... and it showed.

As person who loves the stealth genre and doesn't have a history enjoying Bethesda's products this pleasantly caught me off guard, an excellent game. Incredibly rich and interesting world, slick and responsive controls, inventive and fun powers, this game has it all. I have heard the sequel is even better can't wait to play it. Some things that stick out despite all my enjoyment: The voice acting is distractingly bad, which is surprising considering how much polish the rest of the presentation has. There are also elements that either seem half baked (quest giving NPCs found around the city) and some balance issues (the rat summoning ability is way too overpowered, killing people with this doesn't alert other enemies which makes no sense). These are all minor complaints, though, sneaking around has rarely felt this good.
Dishonored is the game that you want it to be.
